column2: When Gus Migliore took over for Jerry Lewis as soccer coach at Hackensack five years ago he found that, like the entertainer, this Jerry Lewis's act was a hard one to follow.

CLOSTER "I GREW up in Plainfield," recalled Bill Evans, the jazz pianist who has won the Grammy Award five times. He was in the den of his house in Closter, the Bergen County community to which he moved a couple of years ago after an apartment in the Riverdale section of the Bronx proved oppressively small for his growing family.

It was a bad week. Leopold Stokowski died, to be followed three days later by Maria Callas. The soprano's death was a real shocker. There had been no reports of ill health, and she should have been around for many years more teaching, perhaps directing opera, living the legend that she had so richly earned during her great years as the most exciting opera singer of her time.

THE Washington political novel was once the more or less exclusive province of journalists Allen Drury, Fletcher Knebel, Tom Wicker, Les Whitten and Ward Just come to mind but in recent years the newsmen/novelists have faced stiff competition from an unlikely source: Presidential assistants who, upon emerging from the White House, have produced works of fiction rather than traditional nonfiction memoirs.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 24 (AP) A 69-yard touchdown pass from Mike Fallon, the quarterback, to a wide receiver Dennis Dent in the second period today keyed the University of Massachusetts to a 17-0 victory over Harvard.

Aside from its simple commercial success with four shows Friday night and last night at Carnegie Hall, the two bands might well have sold out a single performance at Madison Square Garden the Brothers Johnson-Floaters double bill was interesting for two reasons. One was the way these two mightily popular new soul groups' live acts differed from their records. And the other was the different genres of black music each represented.

A powerful Greenport team defeated Stony Brook, 28-8, yesterday, for its second League A-2 victory. The Porters picked up 266 yards, 254 on the ground, in handing Stony Brook it, second straight loss.

MINEOLA, L.I School taxes in Nassau County can be expected to rise in the future, despite a continuing declining enrollment, because of the present method of financing public education on a district-wide basis through the local property tax, the County Planning Commission said in a report last week.
TORONTO, Sept. 24 Rain became the feature attraction in the Yankees' part of the pennant race today, and the rain won.

NOW THAT summer is officially over, it won't be long before homeowners in this area activate their heating systems again and at today's high prices for fuel and electricity, they'll want to insure full value for every dollar's worth of fuel consumed. This not only calls for additional insulation and weatherstripping where needed, but also requires a heating system that is operating at maximum efficiency.

Susan Merrill Lehrer, a psychotherapist, was married in New York yesterday to David Thomas Jones, a Washton architect. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Morton Lehrer, by Civil Court Judge Louis Okin. The bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John R. Jones, reside in Key Biscayne, Fla.

When you couple terrorism with a nuclear device, as is almost de rigueur, still another worrisome subject is encompassed.

FASHION has let me down. It has ignored my aging 4-foot, 11-inch, 92-pound frame. Its practitioners have cut off my breathing with turtleneck sweaters that cover my nose, exposed my navel with V-neck dresses and immobilized my head with mandarin collars. Their long-sleeved dresses have left me handless and their off-the-shoulder creations have rendered me topless.
SUFFOLK COUNTY'S first comprehensive health-maintenance plan became a financial reality last week when it won a mortgage far the health center it will open next year.

Last month the American sculptor Reuben Nakian observed his 80th birthday, and to mark this event a small, well-chosen exhibition of his work has been mounted by Robert P. Metzger at the Stamford Museum in Stamford, Conn., where Mr. Nakian has lived and worked since 1948.

QUEBEC, Sept. 24 In foreign dealings the provincial government has given priority to cultivating opinion in the United States, butit acknowledges that it has an uphill struggle to elicit American understanding and sympathy for Quebec's nationalist aims.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24 Quietly but definitely in the four years since its admission to the United Nations, West Germany has become a skillful and increasingly influential diplomatic force here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, says he would accept a United Nations Security Council Resolution acknowledging the right of Israel to exist if it were supplemented by a resolution specifying recognition of the right of the Palestinians to an independent homeland.

Hal Woolfolk, a 6-foot, 190-pound senior halfback, rushed for three touchdowns yesterday as Westfield opened its season by crushing Summit, 28-0, in Westfield. Woolfolk sprinted 56 yards in the second quarter and tacked on touchdown bursts of 1 and 5 yards in the second half. Owen Brand darted 35 yards for Westfield's other touchdown and K.C. Knobloch kicked all four conversions.

By far the major portion of Robert Schumann's piano compositions are the work of a very young man. Between 1830 and 1840, when he was in his 20's, Schumann directed almost all of his creative energies toward the keyboard and wrote at least two-dozen large-scale pieces, mostly in the form of suites, that are a basic ingredient of every serious pianist's repertory today.
Patrick Tambay, the young Frenchman who can clinch the Sports Car Club of America Citicorp Can-Am driving championship today in Sonoma, Calif., may not get a chance to defend that crown next season.

The Giants may have taken the "NY" off their helmets and moved their team and offices to New Jersey, but to the rest of the country they still represent New York, and that is one of the reasons they should expect trouble today from the Irving Cowboys.

Chicago is far and away the nation's first city of architecture. History books tell how modern American architecture came of age here through the work of Louis Sullivan, Frank Lloyd Wright, John Wellborn Root and others, but no book can equal the thrill of standing at the corner of Dearborn and Adams Streets in the heart of Chicago's Loop.

Susan Berwind Schiffer, director of communications for the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission, will be married in December to Aubrey Theodore Stautberg Jr., who is with the investment banking firm of Butcher Singer in Philadelphia.

Diana Jeanne Stanton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Oliver Stanton of Laurel Hollow, L.I., was married yesterday at the home of her parents to Albert Grant Thornbrough, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Adam Thornbrouph of Boca Raton, Fla. and Toronto. Villege Judge James Eisenman of Laurel Hollow performed the ceremony.

Leslie Jo Wemyss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Wemyss of Needham, Mass., was married yesterday to Louis Hall Higgins, son of Mrs. James H. Higgins Jr of Providence, R.I., and the late Mr. Higgins. The Rev. William D. Hayes performed the ceremony in St. Eustace Episcopal Church in Lake Placid, N.Y., where the couple's families have summer homes.

Depending on what kind of bulbs are planted, the flower parade can begin soon after the last patches of snow melt until the balmy days of May when it's time to shed heavy winter coats.

Norton, chairman for 40 years of Norton, Lilly Company, shipping agents and one of the oldest shipping concerns in New York City, died Friday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I., after a short illness. He was 78 years old and had lived in Locust Valley, L.I. for the last 54 years.

DENVER, Sept 25 (AP) Operations at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant northwest of Denver produce "unavoidable releases" of radioactive materials that present a potential danger, according to a report of the Energy Research and Development Administration.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 25 A number of factors contributed to the decision by the United States Olympic Committee to select Los Angeles over New York City as its choice for the 1984 Olympic Games New York's uncertain financial situation, conflict over leasing Shea Stadium, a low budgetary projection by the West Coast city and its clear-cut edge in training facilities.

Libya has agreed to pay Texaco Inc., and the Standard Oil Company of California for their subsidiaries, nationalized in 1973 and 1974, the two petroleum producers announced yesterday.

Besides stirring our empathy, the event illustrates a basic tension that will continue to exist for the Grand Canyon, and indeed for most of America's other spectacular wonders.

TAVERN OFF THE GREEN Fraunces Tavern was built in 1719, but it takes its name from its West Indian owner, Samuel Fraunces, who bought the building and opened it as the Queen's Head Tavern in 1762. As many know, George Washington bade farewell there to his officers in 1783. The Sons of the Revolution restored the building in 1907 and now it functions as a restaurant and a museum.

It is not, in short, "action-packed."

One-powerful protest leaders in the hot summers of the 1960's William H. Booth, the Rev. Dr. Eugene Callender, the Rev. Milton Galamison, Jesse Grey and Livingston L. Wingate have become minor actors in smaller dramas as new issues have taken hold in the black community.

New York State's Acting Commissioner of Mental Retardation confirmed yesterday that he had entrusted his own retarded daughter to a rehabilitative residential program operated by United Cerebral Palsy.

"Anybody got a ticket?" a man pacing up and down outside Madison Square Garden was saying last night, an hour before Muhammad Ali's heavyweight title defense against Earnie Shavers. "Who's selling tickets?"
NAPA, Calif., Sept. 29 (AP) Dale Douglass, whose last tournament victory was in 1970, shot a 66 today for they first-round lead in the $200,000 Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 29 (AP) Albert (Papa) French, banjo-strumming leader of the Tuxedo Jazz Band and a well-known New Orleans musician, died Wednesday after a brief illness. He was 66 years old.

WASHINGTON When an experimental nuclear facility at Elk River, Minn., was dismantled, the cost ran to $6.2 million although the plant had cost only about $6 million to build. AtOyster Creek, N.J., a nuclear plant could be safely dismantled for an estimated $100 million; but that's more than 150 percent of the original $65 million cost.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 (AP) Phil Garner batted in three runs with two singles and a triple as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the New York Mets, 5-2, tonight behind the pitching Terry Forster and Kent Tekulve.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) Common Cause, the public affairs lobbying group, said in a statement today that in the three months after the so-called Sunshine Act took effect most meetings of Federal agencies were still being conducted behind closed doors.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 You can agree or disagree with President Carter on policy, but some personal things you can't deny. In good times and bad, he faces his critics with more regularity, more precision of fact and language, and more patience and courtesy than any other President of the television age. So it would be a bad idea to sell Jimmy short.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Dr. Brian Brewer Blades, an internationally known thoracic surgeon, died yesterday at George Washington University hospital after a brief illness. He was 71 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 President Carter is faced with a difficult political and human question of whether to veto or acquiesce in legislation that would deny veterans' benefits to almost all veterans of the Vietnam era who have sought to erase less-than-honorable discharges from their records this year.
Earnie Shavers hurt Muhammad Ali last night. So did many of the 14,613 spectators at Madison Square Garden.

ONE OF THE great secret sights of New York in the 1950's and 60's was the private collection of Judge Irwin Untermyer. Devoted to the decorative arts between 1200 and 1789, it was not a specialized collection. Nor had it set fast once and for all. Judge Untermyer bought what most took his fancy in a wide variety of fields, and he went on buying almost until the day of his death in 1973.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 At precisely the appointed moment, the entered stage right, a Johnny Carson smile on his face, a Jack Benny bounce to his stride.

The Government's report yesterday on the most recent performance of its index of leading economic indicators should deflate the nervous tension that was building up in some circles over this year's summer slowdown in gen- eral economic activity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Senate moved tantalizingly close to a compromise this afternoon in the six-day-old filibuster over natural gas pricing, only to reach a new stalemate that dragged on through the evening with no sign of resolution.
The International Longshoremen's Association went ahead yesterday with plans for a dockworkers' strike at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow amid a flurry of moves aimed at forestalling a walkout.

The Dean Witter Organization Inc., parent of Dean Witter Company, a major diversified securities firm, reversed its declines of the two previous quarters with an 8 percent gain in net income for the fourth fiscal quarter ended Aug. 31, the organization reported yesterday.

Rainy weather over some parts of the Middle West and forecasts of more rain over the weekend led to a substantial increase in soybean prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The nearby November delivery closed at $5.44 a bushel, up 15 cents.

AMERICA and Jimmy Webb, who shared a concert at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday, fought against one of the worst sound systems that this reviewer has ever heard. Levels went up and down without rhyme or reason, there was much distortion, and the band backing America sounded hopelessly muddled.
Muhammad Ali won a unanimous 15round decision last night in a rugged fight with Earnie Shavers to retain his world heavyweight boxing championship at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 President Carter, asserting that peace in the Middle East was of "vital national interest" to the United States, said today that a settlement was impossible "without adequate Palestinian representation" at a peace conference.

There will be storytellers and folksingers, a plant sale and demonstrations of sheep shearing and spinning Sunday at the Wave Hill Center for Environmental Studies in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, beginning at 1:30 P.M.

The American people emerged the poorer last week when two worthy principles came into conflict and the State Department refused entry to two Rhodesian tribal chiefs. The principle that lost was the right of Americans to hear all sides of any argument. The one that prevailed was the nation's obligation to adhere to resolutions of the United Nations Security Council. The lesser principle won.

LONDON, Sept. 29 Good wine seems to be getting more expensive all the time. Today, for instance, Addy Bassin of Washington paid the equivalent of $14,442 for one bottle of Chateau Lafite, vintage 1806. In May 1976 a similar bottle fetched only $14,200 in New Orleans.
Muhammad Ali won a unanimous decision in a rugged fight with Earnie Shavers to retain his world heavyweight boxing championship at Madison Square Garden.

Fred R. Field Jr., a leader of the International Longshoremen's Association, was convicted yesterday of obtaining $124,500 in cash payments from the United Brands Company to maintain "labor peace" and assure the unloading of banana shipments during dock strikes.

NEWARK, Sept. 29 Robert L. Prodan, the former Bank of Bloomfield president whose nine-week trial last spring for alleged bank fraud ended with's hung jury, pleaded guilty today to conspiring to defraud the Bloomfield bank in 1975.
FOR A LONG TIME, Annl Albers was in threads. A celebrated weaver, she produced elegant tapestries and fabrics that pioneered in bringing the craft of weaving to the status of an art form.

It was shortly after 10 A.M. The cavernous and stately chamber in the United States Courthouse on Foley Square was nearly empty. The scattered few on hand rose as Judge David Edelstein marched in and settled into his padded chair. A pudgy court clerk called the session to order.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) A Government index of future economic trends showed a sharp upturn in August after giving signals early in the summer of sluggish economic performance, the Commerce Department said today.
The Securities and Exchange Commission alleged yesterday that the New York operations manager of a Puerto Ricobased bank violated Federal securities laws in stock dealings using insider information.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Treasury Department estimates that the changes it is urging President Carter to propose in the tax law would increase Federal income taxes for most families with incomes above $100,000 a year and cut taxes for almost everyone else.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 29 The phone rang, hardly making a noise today in the carpeted, soundproofed exclusive club known as the Giants' locker room.

WORKSOP, England, Sept. 29 (AP) Peter Butler of England started his round early in the day and birdied three holes in a row before strong winds swept over the Lindrick Golf Club course. He went on to shoot a two-under-par 69, which gave him the lead by three strokes today after the second round of the British Masters golf tournament.

BURBANK, Calif., Sept. 29 Shareholders of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, who have gone without dividends for nine years, were told today that there was no immediate hope for resumption of dividends, but gave the company's departing chairman, Robert W. Haack, a standing ovation just the same.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Leon Jaworski, the special counsel to the House ethics committee, delivered today the strongest demand yet made by an American official to the South Korean Government to cooperate in the investigation of the covert Korean lobby here.

Repeatedly, the Senate's handling of energy comes out sounding like Monday Night Football; Carter suffers another loss; Carter game plan gutted; Carter must come from behind. True enough, the Senate has treated the Administration's National Energy Plan brutally so far. But the game is not mere politics; the losses are not merely Jimmy Carter's.

BONN, West Germany, Sept. 29 (AP) West German defense authorities are investigating reports that a group of army lieutenants staged a mock "burning of Jews" last February at the Armed Forces University in Munich.

Bert Lance, who resigned under fire nine days ago as director of the Office of Management and Budget, was greeted with repeated applause and at times whistles and shouts of approval as he appeared before nearly 1,000 investment bankers here last night.

For the enthusiast who likes to read everything possible about the game, there are six major periodicals and a host of minor ones published in English. One of the most interesting, in part because of its profusion of photographs of the players referred to, is England's Popular Bridge Monthly. The annual subscription of $12 for 12 issues may be sent to The Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street, New York, N.Y. 10025.
AQUEBOGUE, L.I., Sept. 29 With a scratch of pens and a toast from a bottle of local wine, 215 acres of Long Island's shrinking supply of farmland was saved today from developers' bulldozers.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 29 Gerald Weinstein, whose appointment to an Atlantic County judgeship was blocked this year and last when Senator Joseph L. McGahn of Atlantic City invoked "senatorial courtesy," said today that the Senator's brother had suggested something in return for support of the appointment.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 30 The hijacking of a Japan Air Lines DC-8 to Bangladesh by five persons believed to be members of the Japanese Red Army is the latest in a series of destructive and often bloody international incidents initiated by left-wing extremists.

ANDREW DAVIS, the young British conductor, had his turn with the New York Philharmonic last night. Is it coinci dence that there was a big Berlioz work on the program? It was England that sparked the Berlioz renaissance after the war, and Colin Davis soon became one of the world's most prominent exponents of the French composer. Perhaps Mr. Davis plans to follow in his footsteps.

There was a fist fight in Madison Square Garden last night scheduled for 15 rounds or less. Muhammad Ali fought a lot less, won a unanimous decision over Ernie Shavers, and escaped at the end of 15 with the heavyweight championship of the world still in his flabby grasp.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Michael Pertschuk, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, today announced the formation of a task force on corporate accountability, the first of its kind within the F.T.C.
TEL AVIN, Sept. 29 (AP) Meyer W. Weisgal, a longtime leader of the Zionist movement and the founder of the Weizmann Institute of Science, died of cancer today. He was 82.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Council on Environmental Quality, a White House agency, recommended today that the United States defer further development of nuclear power until it was clear that safe methods for the storage of radioactive wastes could be devised.

Trading in Port Authority bonds came almost to a standstill yesterday as bond dealers and their customers studied news that the agency might advance refund much of its outstanding debt to pave the way to expand its mass transit facilities.

Paintings and sculpture by 50 artists, among them Alexander Calder, Willem de Kooning and Louise Nevelson, will go on view Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M. at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art, 258 Main Street in Ridgefield, Conn., in a show called "Fall, 1977: Contemporary Collectors."
About that second straight division title: It will have to wait at least another day.

The Xerox Corporation introduced yesterday a more sophisticated version of its complex 9200 copier-duplicator, as well as a small plain paper copier. The company also lowered prices on a number of its machines.

IF A READER is in luck, he encounters John Fowles strolling in the English Channel resort village of Lyme Regis, which served as the background of his "The French Lieutenant's Woman" several novels ago. He lives there in an 18th-century house, tending his tropical plants and collecting rare books and pottery fragments from the Dorset coast.

Andrei Serban is a man not afraid of silences. The young director whose productions of "Fragments of a Trilogy," "Agamemnon," and "The Cherry Orchard" brought an invigorating element into recent New York theater seasons, is now an associate director of the Yale Repertory Theater and has directed August Strindberg's "The Ghost Sonata" for the company. The play is opening tonight in New Haven as the first play in the repertory theater's 12th season.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 29 The Republican National Committee is expected to adopt at its meeting here tomorrow a resolution opposing ratification of the Carter Administration's new Panama Canal treaties.

The first East Side Festival, canceled last weekend because of rain, will try again on Sunday, when antiques, crafts, food, entertainment and information will be offered at booths stretching along Third Avenue from 65th Street to 93d Street, from 9 A.M. to dusk.

Vera Bocco, a former personal secretary to Louis J. Lefkowitz, New York State's Attorney General, received an unconditional discharge yesterday as the sentence for one misdemeanor count of perjury, to which she had pleaded guilty.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (UPI) A mysterious glowing light in the shape of a jellyfish sighted in the Soviet Union recently, probably was an unusual type of rocket booster, a spokesman for the Center for U.F.O. Studies said today.

Governor Byrne said yesterday that because of the debt refinancing plan of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, designed to clear the way for the agency's financing of new mass-transit projects, he would stop vetoing the agency's actions.

The passage of time is notoriously swift. Last night in Madison Square Garden, Willie Pep stuck his hand through a shower curtain and shook hands with Alexis Arguello. The young and classy Arguello, who relinquished his world junior lightweight title because he had conquered all opposition, had just scored the 44th knockout of his brilliant boxing career.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) President Carter signed today a wide-ranging $10.5 billion farm bill that he once threatened to veto as too expensive but finally accepted to obtain food stamps reforms.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The House of Representatives approved funds for the so-called neutron bomb today, supporting President Carter's efforts to develop the controversial weapon.

The Soviet Union orbited yesterday a new space station, Salyut 6, in what could be a prelude to a manned mission in time for the 20th anniversary of the birth of the space era, the flight of Sputnik 1 on Oct. 4, 1957.
The General Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday a 12 percent decline in earnings for the third fiscal quarter, but a rise of 15 percent for a record in the nine months to Aug. 31.
In the chilly winds that whipped across the Brooklyn waterfront, 120 work gangs were loading and unloading cargoes yesterday morning. The normal figure is 60 or 70 gangs.

A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday refused to increase the amount of bail for a man who was indicted on Monday on charges he assaulted, raped and sodomized one woman at knifepoint and attempted to rape another. The suspect was released on Tuesday after posting $2,500 bail.

Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said here yesterday that President Carter's "international authority" in dealing with Latin American nations would deteriorate if Congress failed to ratify the Panama Canal treaty.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) An agreement was announced in the House Interior Committee today to move ahead with a coal-slurry pipeline bill that had been tied up in a subcommittee.

Two New York copywriting pros quietly opened a new agency a month ago in Greenwich, Conn. Called Posey Parry, it already has about $4 million in billings from Continental Oil's corporate account and the American Security Bank, Washington, for corporate and retail.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) Haywood Sullivan, a former catcher for the Boston Red Sox, and Edward (Buddy) LeRoux, a former trainer, announced an agreement today for their 13-member group to purchase the American League team.

A grand jury yesterday began investigating the bizarre murder of the diamond broker Pinchos Jaroslawicz. Detectives fanned out through New York City and Nassau County meanwhile to check on the statements of a diamond cutter who said he saw two masked men kill the broker during a robbery last week.

NICE, France, Sept. 29 (Reuters) A former Free French Air Force pilot, Roger Sauvage, who was credited with shooting down 16 German planes during World War II, died here on Monday at the age of 60, his family announced.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29 China attacked the Soviet Union today as the most dangerous source of war but also protested against a "strong trend toward appeasement in the West."

Clifford Roberts, a co-founder and for 43 years chairman of the Masters golf tournament, was found dead yesterday at the Augusta (Ga.) National Golf Club, apparently a victim of a self-inflicted gunshot wound.

ATLANTA, Sept. 29 (UPI) State health departments across the nation are virtually swamping the diagnostic laboratories of the national Center for Disease Control with blood and tissue samples from patients suspected of having the type of pneumonia known as legionnaires' disease.

MARSTON MILLS, Mass. Before the Bert Lance affair fades from the mind of the public, someone should call attention to an aspect of the episode that the spotlight techniques of the news media conceal in deep shadows: The behavior of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee was scandalous.

The Justice Department disclosed yesterday that a Government investigation would begin shortly into the proposed takeover of Miles Laboratories, maker of Alka-Seltzer and One-a-Day vitamins, by Bayer AG of west Germany, the giant international chemical company.

Robert J. Wussler, president of CBSTV, said yesterday that ABC was winning the prime-time ratings this year with "junk," and predicted that his network would make larger profits than the others this season, even though its nighttime programs were running third.

It was the fashion industry's night to shine. The annual presentation of the Coty American Fashion Critics' Awards is always an excuse for celebration. This time the event combined some of the elements of a charity ball with an elaborate theater spectacle and generous dispensing of awards.

TAKAKO ASAKAWA and David Hatch Walker were two of the leading dancers in the Martha Graham Dance Company until last year. Now, in an engagement that runs through tonight, they have joined forces to present their own choreography.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 In a set of confidential policy memorandums for President Carter, the Treasury has outlined a two-pronged strategy possibly including a quick tax cut next year for achieving the broad tax cuts and revisions considered vital to Mr. Carter's goals of high employment and a balanced budget.

Justice Leonard H. Sandier of State Supreme Court found yesterday that evidence before a special grand jury indicated that the Rev. Louis R. Gigante did nothing "criminal" or "culpable" on behalf of a reputed organized-crime figure, James Z. Napoli Sr., who was in a New York City correctional facility.

It is hard enough to take baby teeth seriously, since they're going to fall out in a few years. It is even harder to imagine worrying about a baby's gums before the first teeth erupt.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 29 (Reuters) India and Bangladesh reached agreement today on the sharing of the Ganges River waters after protracted talks between the two countries, a Foreign Office spokesman announced.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) The Immigration and Naturalization Service today extended from Saturday to Jan. 31 the deporation of 500 Mennonites who came to Texas from Canada and Mexico and bought land in hopes of establishing a religious community.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) The Soviet Union's 1977 grain crop will be smaller than expected, the Agriculture Department said today.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the fining and disciplining of three members for accepting bets on sporting events while working on the exchange floor. The disciplinary action completes an investigation begun last April.
TRENTON, Sept. 29 Two measures that could have scuttled New Jersey's efforts to clean up the state's waters appeared today to be headed for burial in a committee of the State Assembly.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29 The Security Council approved tonight the appointment of a United Nations representative to help obtain a cease-fire in the guerrilla war in Rhodesia.
MANILA, Sept. 29 A United States mission on its way to Hanoi to recover the remains of 22 Americans who died in Vietnam arrived here today.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 29 Public hearings on the emergency rule of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi opened here today with three of her former Cabinet ministers testifying that they were unwilling parties to some of the orders that came from her office.

Almost half of the 5,000 Cosmos soccer fans who paid for tickets to Pele's farewell game tomorrow, but did not receive them, will be able to attend the match, the New York Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday.

SEATTLE, Sept. 29 Norman Guthmiller, who was reared in North Dakota, believes that home-grown vegetables and fresh eggs are healthier, tastier, cheaper and more sensible than produce bought in stores.

The nation's basic money supply declined $1.1 billion in the week ended Sept. 21, according to preliminary figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 29 (AP) Wilbert Snow, poet, teacher and governor of Connecticut for 12 days, died yesterday at his summer cottage in Spruce Island, Me., the seacoast where he was born and which was the subject of much of his poetry. He was 93 years old.

The New Haven line will run a special rail and bus service from New York City to the Great Danbury State Fair. Trains will leave Grand Central Terminal every day at 8:05 A.M. and 12:05 P.M., and stop for passengers at 125th Street, Stamford, Noroton Heights, Darien, South Norwalk, Wilton, Branchville, Redding and Bethel, arriving in Danbury at 9:59 A.M. and 1:59 P.M.

The Carter Administration proposal to cut in half the tax deductions allowed for business lunches and other expenseaccount activities "would be very bad for the city," Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, said yesterday.

The dollar fell to a new low against the Swiss franc in foreign-exchange trading in Zurich yesterday and also lost value against the Japanese yen and other foreign currencies, The Associated Press reported.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 29 (AP) Jesse James, the Texas official with a train robber's name who had served as State Treasurer since 1941, died at a hospital today after a heart attack. He was 72 years old.

ON MAY 29, 1906, a photographer named George Laurence lifted a 46-pound camera 800 feet in the air over San Fran cisco by means of a kite, then tripped its shutter with an electrical impulse. A device in the camera swept its lens across a 90-degree path, exposing the view below to a large negative. The result was a magnificent panorama of San Francisco in ruins after its famous earthquake and fire.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The first movement in a three-month deadlock between the House and Senate over the use of Medicaid funds for abortions occurred today when House members agreed to consider a Senate compromise that would significantly increase the number of abortions that could be federally financed.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 29 (Reuters) The military Government today moved against the supporters of the ousted Prime Minister, Zulfiker Ali Bhutto, by arresting his daughter, warning his wife to keep quiet and hinting at postponement of elections that are to restore Pakistan to civilian rule.
Hundreds of Orthodox Jews yesterday jammed the chapel and hallways of a funeral parlor, and the street outside, for the funeral of Pinchos Jaroslawicz, the murdered diamond broker.

Eva Evdokimova, who makes her United States debut in American Ballet Theater's production of "Swan Lake" tomorrow night at the Metropolitan Opera House, is one of Europe's best known young ballerinas.

FOR SOME REASON the canoeing season in this part of the country is like the swimming season: It seems to end on Labor Day. And that's just as well. It means the rivers are uncrowded for those of us who love to paddle in the early fall when the air is cool, the water is high and fast and the leaves along the banks are already starting to turn.
Three Democratic citywide candidates who went their separate ways in the Democratic primary, united briefly yesterday to endorse one another and then returned to campaigning their separate ways.

DRESSED LIKE an Egg," JoAnne Akalaitis's enthralling excursion into the life and art of Col ette, returns tomorrow night for a limited run of weekends at the Public Theater. VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 29 (Reuters) Laos has given a new stimulus to its close relationship with Vietnam by sending a military delegation to Hanoi.
HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., Sept. 29 (AP) Virginia Wade of Britain outlasted Evonne Goolagong today, 6-4, 6-7, 6-3, to capture the women's singles title of the World Invitation Classic.

Eleven hundred passengers were removed from a northbound IRT Lexington Avenue express train through an emergency exit at 74th Street yesterday evening after it broke down and filled with smoke, Transit Authority officials reported.

NEWARK, Sept. 29 The Italian-produced sets have arrived from the Miami Opera and been spruced up with some fresh paint, several thousand dollars in new stage lighting has been erected, six months of weekly rehearsals are over, and the New Jersey State Opera is set to open its 12th season Saturday night at Symphony Hall here.

Sitting in his office, Victor Wademan looked very much the buttoned-down man. Closely cropped hair, dark blue suit, a white shirt with just the proper roll to the button-down collar and a conservative striped tie.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) Inspectors will check 91 dairy herds in nine states because of an outbreak of bovine tuberculosis in milk cows owned by a Missouri college, the Agriculture Department said today. The stock market, propelled by signs that the economy has picked up steam, moved higher yesterday in accelerated trading.

The New England Patriots are favored by two touchdowns over the Jets for their game at Shea Stadium on Sunday, and the Giants will also be underdogs against the Falcons in Atlanta. The latter game will be televised ...

President Carter said yesterday that the problems of the nation's steel industry were "chronic" and tied to a slowdown in the world economy. He said he opposed making basic changes in the import laws or easing environmental standards to aid the industry.

In the days when New York harbor was filled with sails, the distinctive rig of the schooners was the most prevalent. They were the pilot ships, fishing boats and coastal cargo carriers. Tomorrow schooners will return to the Hudson River, where about 30 of them are expected to compete in the South Street Seaport Museum's 11th annual race for the silver Mayor's Cup.

Carter Hawley Hale Stores, the Los Angeles-based retail chain, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 20.5 percent interest in the House of Fraser Ltd., for $76 million to Lonrho Ltd., a British company, partly Arab owned, which is engaged in manufacturing, mining and publishing.

THE GREAT DANBURY State Fair opens in Connecticut to morrow for its 108th year. If not quite so rustic as it was a century ago, it promises to be as showy and exciting as always, and bigger and gaudier than ever before.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 29 (Reuters) President Alfonso Lopez Michelsen today accepted the resignaion of Interior Minister Rafael Pardo Buelvas, which had prompted a walkout by most of the Cabinet and plunged Colombia into a political crisis.
A three-judge Federal panel in Manhattan yesterday upheld a lower-court decision to remove the ban on flights of the supersonic Concorde jetliner to Kennedy International Airport.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 29 Judy Cooperstein of Glen Oaks, who won the Metropolitan title at Metropolis earlier this year, today moved into the final round of the Long Island women's golf championship at The Creek Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Administration forces favoring continued regulation of natural gas prices lost a key test vote on deregulation today but showed increased strength since a similar vote a week ago.

Miriam Bockman was unanimously elected the first woman leader of the Manhattan Democratic organization yesterday in a move that signaled the transfer of political power from Mayor Beame to Representation Edward I. Koch, the Democratic candidate for Mayor.

The Yankees did not win their 100th game last night. They did not win their second straight division title either. Today the Yankees will try again to win their 100th game. Today they will try again to win their second straight division title.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 President Carter ordered Assistant Agriculture Secretary Robert H. Meyer today to stop seeking preferential treatment for farmers in California's Imperial Valley, where Mr. Meyer owns or leases more than 2,500 acres of valuable irrigated land.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 (UPI) The Federal Government filed suit yesterday against the McDonnell Douglas Corporation on behalf of about 100 embloyees who say they were not promoted at McDonnell while they were in the armed services.

BETHLEHEM Pa., Sept. 30 The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced today that it was eliminating the jobs of 2,500 white-collar workers. They were the latest layoffs in the troubled steel industry, which have now grown to 18,000.

A 54-year-old Brooklyn lawyer was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of defrauding the Government of thousands of dollars by filing false claims, on behalf of herself and others, for Federal tax refunds, Social Security payments and unemployment insurance.

Among 50 women runners who set out yesterday on the first leg of a 2,500-mile relay to Houston were Judy Carter, a daughter-in-law of President Carter. Mrs. Carter, who is married to Jack Carter, left Seneca Falls, N.Y., with other runners and headed southeast. Eventually, 2,000 women will take part in the long-distance run to dramatize the fight for enactment of the equal rights amendment to the Constitution.
An elderly man stood up at the Harlem Young Men's Christian Association yesterday and spoke in a trembling voice to Secretary of the Army Clifford L. Alexander Jr.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-A Senate committee, after adopting several exemptions, approved legislation today that would raise from 65 to 70 the age at which employers may require their workers to retire.

PALO ALTO, Calif. Sept. 30 Bay area tax lawyer Harry Margolis has been acquitted on five of the six remaining counts of Federal tax fraud against him in a landmark prosecution involving the use of offshore tax havens.
Two French ready-to-wear designers interrupted work on their spring collections to come to New York this week to present their fall styles.

WASHINGTON It is all very well to lead children to Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, but how do you make them listen? One basic rule, for the people who just put together a 10-part television series designed to get the young in listen and love it is, "Don't tell them that it's good for them."

Amid behind-the-scenes pressure for his withdrawal, Irving Anker, the Chancellor of New York City schools, notified the Board of Education yesterday that he would retire at the end of the current school year, when his present one-year contract expires.
The stock market advanced sharply yesterday, encouraged by a drop in the nation's money supply announced late Thursday.

Adam K. Levin, director of the state's Consumer Affairs Division, said yesterday that a recent ruling by the United States Supreme Court that led to the removal of prohibitions against advertising by professionals was the "most important action on behalf of consumers in the last decade."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The scene was the baroque reception room just off the Senate floor, where flocks of painted angels sweep across the ceiling and portraits of august Senators adorn the walls.
WASHINGTON, Sept.30(AP) Like a private spender who has lost his credit cards, the Treasury began today to scrape up cash to carry on the Government's business without borrowing.

While television executives gleefully reported record ratings for his latest show, a subdued Muhammad A1i conceded wearily yesterday that he was entering a boxing "twilight zone" as world heavyweight champion.

Elizabeth Burgard Dater and Wm. Mitchell Jennings Jr., both of New York, were married yesterday evening at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jennings of Byram, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Joseph Bishop of the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

The Falls City Ramblers, a string band from Louisville, Ky., that is making its first New York appearance at O'Lunney's, 915 Second Avenue, through tomorrow, offers something out of the ordinary in bluegrass and old-time country music. With is members hailing from Kentucky and Ohio, the group purveys harmony-singing and irstrumental-playing that are authentic.
ALBANY "Hi Pay, No College" the lure of private vocational schools becomes siren-like this time of year as new high school graduates find that there are not enough jobs for everyone who wants one.
Dave Jennings and John James figure to be worth their weight in shoes tomorrow when the Giants play the Falcons in Atlanta.

Tony Franklin, the bare-footed placement kicker for Texas A. M., has Bo Schembechler, the Michigan coach, more than a little worried about today's game between these undefeated teams at Ann Arbor, Mich.

ATLANTA, Sept. 30 (AP) Fifty-four children of employees at a battery factory in Raleigh, N.C., have been found to have excessive levels of lead in their blood since February 1977, the National Center for Disease Control said today.
A "litigation explosion" is backlogging cases in record numbers and denying justice to thousands of New Jersey residents, the state's administrative director of the courts said.

Leo M. Cooper, the founder and board chairman of White Swan Uniforms Inc., a leading manufacture of women's dresstype uniforms, died Wednesday night at his home at 30 West 54th Street. He was 92 years old.
Alexander Tcherepnin, composer and pianist, died Thursday in Paris. He was 78 years old.

Barry Farber, the Conservative candidate for Mayor of New York City, upstaged his rivals at a Chinatown forum by speaking Toisanese, the dialect of Canton, in replying to some questions put to him by representatives of 1,000 Chinese-American municipal employees.

OTTAWA, Sept. 30 The Canadian Government announced a revised language policy today for federal official functions that will require more use of French, the first language of about onefourth of the nation's population of 23 million.

Followers of form wondering whether Forego would clinch horse-of-the-year honors for the fourth straight time today as well as become thoroughbred racing's leading career money-winner will have to wait.

The Village Independent Democrats, the home political club of Representative Edward I. Koch, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, has voted overwhelmingly to reject the Democratic candidate for Manhattan Borough President, Andrew J. Stein, and to support instead Robert F. Wagner Jr., who is running on the Republican and Liberal lines.
BOSTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Boston's Jim Rice drove in five runs and hit two doubles and two singles tonight at Fenway Park, where the Red Sox edged the Baltimore Orioles, 11-10.
Hans Habe, a leading European novelist and journalist, died Thursday night at a hospital in Locarno, Switzerland. He was 66 years old and lived in nearby Ascona.

For the roster of great barren controversies of government, we submit the current turmoil over Eskimo rights and the endangered bowhead whale. It is a splendid example of why Federal bureaucracies are in no danger whatever of extinction.

BONN, Sept. 30(AP) The West German Parliament approved today a bill that prevents detained terrorist suspects from seeing their lawyers or other visitors.

Concurrent actions by the Emergency Financial Control Board and a justice of State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday guaranteed New York City's 18,000 police officers that the 6 percent raise about $19 a week that they had expected to begin receiving last July will be reflected in their next paycheck, next Friday.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 30 To Joe Fields, the Jets' center, every punter he snaps to is upside down.
KOOBI FORA, Kenya Kamoya Kimeu trudges across a rocky a rocky slope in this desolate but strangely beautiful wilderness, his sharp eyes methodically scanning the ground for pieces of ancient bone.

A link with the moon, and with the past, was severed yesterday when American scientist shut down operations of five automated lunar stations set up by the Apollo astronauts.
DACCA, Bangladesh, Saturday, Oct. 1 (Reuters) Japanese guerrillas released four more hostages yesterday and a fifth early today from the Japanese airliner they hijacked to Dacca Wednesday.

SAN DIEGO, Sept. 30 Former Presi dent Gerald R. Ford entered a stronghold of Republican conservatism today and unequivocally reiterated his support for the Panama Canal treaties, but acknowledged "it's going to be a tough battle" to win ratification.

Miriam Bockman was unanimously elected the first woman leader of the Manhattan Democratic organization yesterday in a move that signaled the transfer of political power from Mayor Beame to Representative Edward I. Koch, the Democratic candidate for Mayor.

TROY, N.Y.-It is decided. While his mother is reordering her life in Philadelphia, I will shepherd the three-year-old for a month. He is Yanni, a transliteration of Ioannis, named for his Greek grandfather. I am Poppy, the residue of Papoo, a name selected by his mother.

HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., Sept. 30 (UPI) Virginia Wade won the World Invitational Tennis Classic today when she and Vitas Gerulaitis rebounded from a mixed-doubles deficit of 3 match points to defeat Roscoe Tanner and Kerry Reid, 6-7, 6-3, 7-6.
The International Longshoremen's Association announced last night that lastminute contract negotiations had failed and that dock workers on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts would strike today.
FRANKLIN, Mass., Sept. 30 A judge's threat to jail all striking teachers in this town, the birthplace of Horace Mann, brought an end to a bitter two-week school strike just after dawn today.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 30 The Republican National Committee voted overwhelmingly today to oppose the ratification of the new Panama Canal treaties proposed by the Carter Administration.

Individual investors often have the same portfolio objectives as institutional investors, but they cannot always draw on the same expertise as institutions. That appears to be one of the reasons why the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's recent tender offer for Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company 9.75 percent debentures brought in only 65 percent of the issue.

NAPA, Calif., Sept. 30 (AP) Tom Watson, seeking his sixth victory of the year, charged into contention in the $200,000 Anheuser-Busch golf tournament by finishing today's second round with a 40-foot eagle putt that left him four strokes behind the coleaders, Mac McLendon and Grier Jones.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 For most people, tomorrow will be nothing special, nothing more exciting than the first day of October or the first day of the weekend. But for the Federal Government, it is New Year's Day, the start of the money year of 1978.

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Sept. 30 The head of the Episcopal Church in the United States, Presiding Bishop John M. Allin, offered tonight to resign if his fellow bishops were unwilling to accept his outright opposition to ordaining women as priests.

ROME Seized, censored, appealed and finally absolved, Pier Paolo Pasolini's "Salo, 120 Days of Sodom," was even kidnapped before it was released to the mild enthusiasm of the public and the praise of the critics here. Along the way, in and out of the courts in Italy, the film created a furor.

Trading in Port Authority bonds resumed yesterday following the lull that developed as bond dealers and investors studied the bistate agency's refunding proposal made public early Thursday. Some Port Authority issues climbed sharply and others sank even more decisively.
Although a state law requiring the registration of all mopeds went into effect today, officials supervising the program are telling police agencies to ignore the law for a while.

YAPHANK, L.I, Sept. 30 Although Parr Meadows is beset with financial troubles and has been closed since last Monday, officials said today they hoped to reopen the quarter-horse race track next Friday night. But the chances seemed slim.

Amid behind-the-scenes pressure for his withdrawal, Irving Anker, the Chancellor of New York City schools, notified the Board of Education yesterday that he would retire at the end of the current school year, when his present one-year contract expires.

Governor Carey indicated yesterday that he hoped to get the Legislature working next week on measures that New York City needs to sell notes on the public market before the end of this year and put off more difficult issues relating to the sale of long-term bonds.

Thea Musgrave is a British composer, now resident in this country, whose operas are beginning to attract a great deal of attention. Last night the New York City Opera introduced Miss Musgrave's "The Voice of Ariadne" to this city. She herself conducted the performance.

Jeff Williams is a young black man at Haaren High School, sharp on the street, coltish in the classroom. He is only months away from his graduation into one of the most depressing statistics in a land that brags of opportunity the 40 percent unemployment rate for young minority-group males.

The United States and the Soviet Union pledged their "utmost effort" yesterday to overcome Arab-Israeli differences to enable the convening of a new middle East peace conference before the end of the year.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 30 (UPI) Jerry Tarkanian won a court order today to remain head basketball coach at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, in a legal decision that may shake the foundation of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's investigatory procedures.

As the material witness in the case of a diamond broker who was robbed and slain came forward yesterday with a new twist to his bizarre story, it was disclosed that another broker had been missing for more than two months, with possibly as much as $300,000 in gems.

HANOI, Vietnam, Sept. 30 (AP) The remains of 21 American servicemen who died during the Vietnam war and those of a civilian who died in Saigon a year later were turned over to United States officials here today in a brief ceremony.
SALVADOR, Brazil For three hours several hundred admirers of Jorge Amado stood in line holding copies of his new, 590-page novel, "Tieta do Agreste," to have it autographed by the author.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Nineteen Latin American nations have agreed to establish a new bank, with $99 million of authorized capital, to finance exports from that area, a Panamanian official disclosed today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 (AP) Bruce Boisclair drew a bases-loaded walk and Roy Staiger followed with a two-run single to highlight a four-run sixth inning that sent the New York Mets to a 6-3 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight and a split of their twi light-night doubleheader.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 President Carter ordered Assistant Agriculture Secretary Robert H. Meyer today to stop seeking preferential treatment for farmers in California's Imperial Valley, where Mr. Meyer owns or leases more than 2,500 acres of valuable irrigated land.

PARIS, Sept. 30 A gunman hijacked a French airliner today and after forcing it to land here exploded a grenade, killing a passenger and wounding at least two others as the police stormed the plane and captured him.

Saul Levitt, whose plays about the morality of war were produced on television, on Broadway, across the country and in theaters throughout Europe, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 66 years old and lived at 320 Riverside Drive.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP) Government hopes of lowering Britain's soaring inflation rate and restoring economic stability received a blow today when the Ford Motor Company Ltd. offered its workers a pay settlement above Government guidelines.

TRENTON, Sept. 30 Governor Byrne has apparently picked up some support among independent voters over the last three months in the gubernatorial race, according to the poll released today by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University. However, the poll, in which the Governor was given fairly high marks for his performance in office, showed that the Governor still trails State Senator Raymond H. Bateman, his Republican opponent, by seven points.

WACO, Tex., Sept. 30-A former Texas police chief, his wife and sister-in-law were found guilty by a Federal jury here last night in a case based on violation of the civil rights of a Mexican-American who was killed while he was in the chief's custody.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 A Senate committee, after adopting several exemptions, approved legislation today that would raise from 65 to 70 the age at which employers may require their workers to retire.

THROUGH A GLASS COLORFULLY The belief is that stained-glass windows developed in the Middle East, where the glass industry began. HONG KONG, Saturday, Oct. 1 Two major figures in Chinese Communist cultural circles who were purged during the Cultural Revolution as enemies of Chiang Ching, Mao Tse-tung's wife, were rehabilitated at a banquet last night celebrating China's National Day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The Justice Department announced today that two senior officials would soon visit South Korea to seek an agreement under which American investigators could question Tongsun Park, a central figure in the covert Korean lobby here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The poorer nations are saddled with debt and alarms have been sounding from various quarters, including a harsh report recently by a Congressional committee. But are the world's international bankers worried?

JERUSALEM, Sept. 30 Prime Minister Menahem Begin was hospitalized today for what aides said was fatigue resulting from a strenuous schedule. Mr. Begin, leader of the right-wing Likud blec, suffered a severe heart attack this spring during the election campaign. He was hospitalized again for over a week shortly after his surprise mid-May victory for what was described as "chest pains."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 House conferees rejected today a Senate proposal that would significantly increase the number of abortions that could be paid for with Federal funds. Instead they drafted a counterproposal that would allow payment for "medical procedures" for victims of rape and incest.
Gerald F. Maulsby, a longtime executive with the CBS radio network in New York, died Sunday at his home in Tucson, Ariz., after a brief illness. He was 71 years old.

NEW PALTZ, N.Y., Sept. 30 The first women forest rangers in New York State reported for work yesterday in the Catskill mountains.

WASHINGTON A French civil engineer has invented a noise-reducing square-mesh screen and other devices to protect occupants of buildings along railways and highways. Andre L. Desenfant has reported constructing a sound-attenuating system in a noisy section of Highway A-4 leading to Paris from Strasbourg.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 30 (UPI) Sir Edmund Hillary climbed Mount Everest in 1953, but the Ganges River has defeated him.

DETROIT, Sept. 30 The General Motors Corporation announced today base-price increases averaging 2.6 percent on its redesigned, trimmed-down, intermediate-sized passenger cars for 1978 considerably less than the 4.6 percent rise that G.M. disclosed five weeks ago for its 1978 fleet as a whole.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 President Carter said today that he planned to wait at least three months before naming a successor to Bert Lance as director of the Office of Management and Budget.

WASHINGTON, Sept.30(AP) The prices that farmers receive for their crops fell an average of 1 percent between midAugust and mid-September, the Agriculture Department reported today. It was the fourth consecutive monthly decline.

That is a radical prescription and it seems to us radically premature. But the council's concern, as articulated by one of its members, A. Gustave Speth, is justifiable.

WASHINGTON--The technical name for Social Security is Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance. But the extent to which Social Security should be considered an insurance sys- tem, rather than a form of welfare, is a matter of long-standing debate.

The year he was admitted, about 20 places out of a class of 400 were reserved for students with lower test scores.

Steel production for the week ended Oct. 1 was up 0.1 percent to 2.4 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The slight increase reflected the continuing flat demand for steel and the competition from imported steel with the domestic industry.

AFTER YEARS of benign neglect or, if you will, thin-lipped tolerance, opera has been discovered by public television. More specifically, opera has been discovered to be a potentially strong fund-raiser. A Metropolitan Opera production of "La Boh me" starring Luciano Pavarotti and Renata Scotto, broadcast live from the opera house last season, brought in $1 million to station coffers from grateful viewers. Public television executives have suddenly seen the operatic light.

The European tour that the Cosmos had been planning for some time and that was supposed to start next week has fallen through, and the Pele-less Cosmos maintain it was their decision.
Bernard Bergman, the nursing-home operator who served a four-month Federal prison sentence for Medicaid fraud, was ordered yesterday to serve an additional one-year state sentence for bribery.

Sales in August among 35 of the nation's largest retail chains rose 14.3 percent from the 1976 month, with the biggest year-to-year increases occurring in discount stores and in stores selling household durables and "do-it-yourself" building materials, a monthty survey showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 Federal District Judge John J. Sirica sharply reduced the prison sentences of three principal figures in the Watergate case today after all confessed in tape-recorded statements that they were guilty of wrongdoing and said they were sorry for what they had done.

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Oct. 4 A proposed major capital funds drive today became the focus of conflict over priorities and leadership that have sharply divided bishops of the Episcopal Church in the United States, who are meeting ere.
Silver futures prices rose yesterday, continuing a recent upturn that reflected in part the weakness of the United States dollar abroad and the nation's recent poor trade balance figures.

HARRISBURG, Pa. Corruption and taxes are the chief concerns of the Democratic-controlled State Legislature as it prepares for its second major budgetary struggle this year and statewide elections, including a gubernatorial campaign, next year.

The murders of two more men in the Manhattan diamond district came to light yesterday as the police resumed questioning a material witness in the twoweek-old murder and robbery of the diamond broker Pinchos Jaroslawicz.

"WHATEVER happened to lyrics?" Joshua Logan asks at the beginning of his first nightclub show, which is running at the Rainbow Grill through Oct. 15. "I think we should bring lyrics back, I mean lyrics that fit music and music that fits lyrics."

MISSION, Kan., Oct. 4 (UPI) Portland (Ore.) State University and the University of Houston were placed on one year probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association today for infractions in their football programs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 U.S.-Israeli relations are strained again for reasons that run much deeper than their latest disagreement over the U.S.Soviet formula for convening a Middle East conference at Geneva.
WASHINGTON, Oct.4 Organized labor won an initial skirmish in the House of Representatives today over legislation designed to strengthen the National Labor Relations Act.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 4 Ralph J. Perk, who has been this city's Mayor since November 1971, was defeated tonight in his effort to win a fourth two-year term.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Oct. 4 (AP) John Jardine, who recently retired as day traffic chief in the Vancouver bureau of the Canadian Press, died last night when his car left the road and plunged into the Fraser River. He was 65 years old.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) Despite conservative complains, the House passed today and sent to President Carter an increase in the national debt ceiling to $752 billion.

A Queens wholesale grocer and his son were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of smuggling more than 90 pounds of cocaine into this country inside one-pound chocolate bars.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 After more than two weeks of delay and debate, the Senate approved a controversial proposal today that would free newly discovered natural gas from price controls.

In the red-leatherette surroundings of a hotel meeting room in Buffalo last week, Governor Carey found himself under verbal siege by a group of labor leaders angry about unemployment. "If you give us work," one of them shouted at him, "we'll keep you in Albany forever."
MAPUTO, Mozambique, Oct. 4. (Reuters) The Mozambican authorities said today that heavy fighting was in progress in the northern district of Tete between Mozambican forces and Rhodesian troops.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 4 As 10,000 Mormons poured into this clean mountain city over the weekend to celebrate their faith at the church's 147th semiannual general conference, much of the private conversation revolved around a violent offshoot of a long-outlawed Mormon practice, polygamy.

After a seven-month battle, the Great Western United Corporation, a leading sugar beet producer, appeared last night to have cleared the way for its takeover of the Sunshine Mining Company, a major silver producer.

While her husband discussed state affairs here yesterday, Rosalynn Carter threw a little party. She entertained about 200 women and one man from the United Nations family at a "moving buffet" luncheon in the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 (AP) Conrail, the nation's largest rail freight system, announced today that all container cargo bound for New York, Boston, Philadelphia and Baltimore would be halted at midnight Thursday because of the longshoremen's strike.
THIONVILLE, France, Sept. 30 Serge Valli, a Communist labor leader in this economically depressed steel town in Lorraine, says he has a recurring nightmare.
The dollar rallied against most major world currencies in active trading yesterday, partly recovering from its steep losses Monday, The Associated Press reported.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 4 The delegates of 33 European governments, the United States and Canada met today for a full-scale review of the 1975 Helsinki accord on European security and cooperation.

A declarer who is trying to complete a mental picture of an opponent's distribution can often succeed by reviewing the actions of that player in the bidding and play. With certain distributions, he would perhaps have bid differently or played differently.

FACT: "The Alice Crimmins Case" is the title of a none fiction book by Kenneth Gross, a journalist, that will be published by Ballantine Books next month. It is an account of a "notorious woman accused of murdering her two small children." After various trials and a conviction, described in the book, Miss Crimmins, a former cocktail-lounge hostess in Queens, served time was on a work-release program, and remarried. She was recently granted parole.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) HouseSenate conferees agreed today on a compromise $80 million authorization for the plutonium-producing Clinch River breeder reactor project in east Tennessee, making major concessions to the Carter Administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 Senator Robert Dole, Republican of Kansas, made public today a confidential State Department cablegram that he said demonstrated "vast differences of interpretation" between the United States and Panama on key points in the new canal treaties.

PURISTS may argue that curry powder is not a proper ingredient for dedicated cooks. I demur. I have dined at several Indian tables both in private homes and in restaurants where the food has been something to marvel at. And yet I see nothing wrong with a first-rate commercially blended curry powder, if it is not used on a static, day-by-day basis.
LONDON, Oct. 4 Another $2.32 billion poured into Britain's foreign-exchange coffers last month, an inflow so great that it may force the Government to take steps to choke it off.

IT WAS LATE AFTERNOON, and the shoppers were beginning to straggle in. In twos and threes they strolled through the lobby of the small, elegant midtown hotel, walking into the bar and sitting down to order. Then they began to stare, or giggle. Do double-takes. Poke one another in the ribs. And point, to a table in a corner. There sat Richard Burton, looking debonair and sipping tea.

MONTREAL, Oct. 4 For the first time since he took office last November at the head of a government dedicated to the rights and independence of Quebec's French-speaking majority, Premier Rene Levesque braved a direct confrontation last night with the province's alienated and angry English-speaking minority.

Expenditures for research and development by United States industry totaled $14.8 billion last year, or about 1.8 cents of each sales dollar. A special study covering the 403 companies that account for 92.5 percent of all private research and development spending, Standard Poor's Industry Surveys publication reported that the amount was an 11.5 percent increase from the $13.7 billion spent in 1975.

Rollie Fingers of the San Diego Padres received a sterling silver fireman's cap before the opener of the National League championship series in Los Angeles last night as winner of the league's top-reliever competition for 1977. The 31-year-old right-hander's 35 saves were the most in the major leagues since John Hiller's 38 for Detroit in 1973.

Thirteen years ago when the first Gres collection was shown in New York as a benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund, most of the women in the audience wore Chanel suits. Yesterday, the view from the stage was far more eclectic. There were stoles, peasant outfits, challis prints and the blouses with tiny ruffles at the wrists and neck, all signatures of the current season.

The central thrust of President Carter's policy in the Middle East is the reconvening of the Geneva conference in the near future. This is a laudable and wise goal that should actively be pursued by the United States provided the reconvening is not accomplished at a price that would make difficult, if not impossible, the achievement of peace agreements between the parties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) The House today narrowly approved a $52 billion increase in the national debt ceiling. The vote was 223 to 194 to approve a Senate-passed measure and send the measure to President Carter for his signature.

Yields on high-grade tax-exempt bonds, reacting to the recent rise in short-term interest rates, climbed fairly sharply yesterday as Oregon and Tennessee sold big bond issues. The increase, however, apparently was enough to satisfy investors because almost 80 percent of the bonds were reported sold by late afternoon.

New York City's deficit for the fiscal year that ended last June 30 was $308 million, the city announced yesterday, $378 million less than Mayor Beame had projected in his financial plan. Most of this reduction was a result, the city explained, of increased revenue.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) Congress is a step farther from deciding when tax money will pay for abortions as House and Senate conferees admit failure after three months of trying to reach a compromise.
John Lewis Craddock, a former copy editor at The New York Times who also worked for other publications, died on Sept. 24 at his home in Tryon, N.C., after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

Say your hot dog just doesn't cut the mustard anymore? For some frankfurter lovers the juicy sputter, spicy zing and nostalgic aroma of old has been replaced by a product that may be shriveled, scorched, oversalted and full of steam-table fatigue. For others, staunch hot dog defenders, the old American standard is one of the few foods that still tastes the way it did the day they took their first bite at baseball's season opener.

Maybe not a billion-dollar sure thing, but a 400-people-times-$50 sure thing, because that's how many people bought tickets and that's what the tickets cost.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 The Commission on Federal Paperwork has issued its final report and quietly terminated its two-year "fight against paperwork."
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 4 High bids of $27.15 million for oil and gas leases on about 290,000 acres of state-owned lands were received by the Texas School Land Board today.

MENTOR, Ohio Grandmaster Walter Browne of Berkeley, Calif., increased his lead in the United States Championship Tournament by defeating International Master Andy Soltis of New York in the fourth round here in the Mentor Inn. Browne has now taken 3 points.
Officials of several large Japanese trading companies said yesterday that the Treasury Department's finding of "dumping" would severely cut imports of steel from Japanese producers.

One of the major witnesses against a man accused of firing a pistol through a woman friend's bedroom window was killed at his Queens home Monday night with a shotgun blast fired into his face, the police said yesterday.

The Simmons Company, the Atlanta mattress maker, is reviewing its agency relationships, has already decided to leave Young Rubicam and may split with the J. Walter Thompson Company. Simmons spent about $3 million in media advertising last year.

Former Assemblyman Antonio Olivieri, the Democratic candidate for Manhattan Councilman at Large, traded charges last night with an official of the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene about the prospects for releasing more inmates of state mental hospitals.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 The House Ways and Means Committee voted today for increases in Social Security taxes in the next several years that would fall primarily on people earning more than $16,500 a year.

TRENTON, Oct. 4 The Casino Control Commission, which will regulate gambling in Atlantic City, gave its chairman, Joseph P. Lordi, extraordinary powers today as the panel held its first meeting in a less than amiable atmosphere.
DENVER, Oct. 4 (AP) A city councilman was stabbed in the stomach and chest early today outside an apartment building, and the police later arrested the son of a late Colorado Governor in the case.

Ilr. President, I wtsh to offer first my congratulations on your election as President of the 32d General Assembly. The Correction Officers Benevolent Association yesterday protested the suspension of two guards at the Men's House of Detention on Rikers Island following the escape of 10 inmates on Sunday night. The guards were charged with negligence.

Annoyed at Representative Edward I. Koch's plan to hand him a letter challenging the Administration's stand on the proposed Middle East peace talks, President Carter delivered a series of snubs to Mr. Koch yesterday during the President's visit to speak at the United Nations.

Twenty-four traffic control agents have been assigned to expedite the flow of vehicles in the Queensboro Bridge area as the first step of a new clean-air plan for Manhattan, Alexander J. Mautner, the City Transportation Commissioner, announced yesterday.

Concorde flight in London, flown at supersonic speed and high cost to Dulles Airport here and distributed that afternoon to politicians and newsmen.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. The Senate adopted an amendment tonight that would require utilities to offer "lifeline" electricity rates for senior citizens as a cushion against increasing electric charges.

DENVER, Oct. 5 (AP) A Federal judge in Utah has been accused of improper judicial conduct, insulting United States attorneys and ignoring all rules of judicial procedure in a Justice Department move seeking to bar him from presiding over Federal cases.

TWO YEARS AGO, when he was 17, Peter Corey, guitarist, gave a very successful debut recital in Carnegie Recital Hall as a winner of the annual Concert Artists Guild competitions. Now a teacher at the American Institute of Guitar and still only 19, he played a return engagement in the same hall on Tuesday night. His performances were just as rewarding as they had been on the earlier occasion, perhaps even more so.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 Shortly before 10 P.M., a power outage cut off all electricity in a three-by five-mile corridor of the downtown section here, affecting some 25,000 to 30,000 people. Three hours later, power had been restored to nearly all the area except for several blocks in the Back Bay section.

In an unusual set of stop-and-go rulings, the State Racing and Wagering Board suspended the license of one track yesterday and denied another's request to close its meeting seven weeks earlier than scheduled.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 Temporary subsidy payments to American sugar growers, which should hold down retail prices for the next two or three months, were announced today by Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland.
Nothing ages worse than graffiti. "Hair," the hippie musical, was a raffish slogan scrawled in day-glo upon the institutional walls of the late 1960's.

September's retail business in New York City rose 5.5 percent over the yearearlier level, reverting to what has been normal 1977 growth after an exceptionally strong August and only keeping pace with the inflation rate.
THE RUSH to cosmetic surgery continues. Women are having their eyes "done" as casually as they might have a tooth capped. Prematurely bald men agonize about embarking on a hair transplant.

The Federal Reserve indicated yesterday that it did not want short-term interest rates to slip back down in the wake of their August-September climb. The central bank drained reserves from the banking system and said it would drain more today.

LOS ANGLES, Sept. 12 A group of pediatricians in La Jolla, Calif., have added a professional grandmother to their staff because they found that few parents have extended families to advise them about child care.

THERE ARE MOMENTS in our serendipitous meanderings through life that suddenly, like Gestalt, add up to more than the sum of their parts. Such a moment occurred in my meander this summer when, on a mindless day browsing in Southampton, I let my daughters aged 6 and 8 get their ears pierced.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 Vice President Mondale said today that his own views on Senate filibuster rules and the requests of the Senate majority leader, not any instructions from President Carter, caused him to help silence the filibuster Monday over deregulation of natural gas.

IT'S BEEN RAINING in Connecticut and all our friends are divorcing. We're worried, my wife and I. We don't want to be sticks in the mud, the only married persons in the neighborhood. Dr. Michael Selzer, a member of the political-science faculty at Brooklyn College, who had been accused and then cleared of association with the Central Intelligence Agency, has filed a $2 million suit against colleagues who recommended that he not be promoted or granted tenure.
A 2-year-old boy was killed and his parents and 4-week-old sister were injured last night in a fire in their apartment at 252 West 21st Street, according to Fire Department officials.

Jan Garber, the dance orchestra leader who organized his own band at the age of 21 and led one for 55 years, died yesterday morning at the Highland Hospital in Shreveport, La. He was 82 years old.

The Sony Corporation of Tokyo said it had signed an agreement with the RCA Corporation to provide RCA with technology on the 1-inch helical-scan videotape recorders and related equipment. Financial terms were not disclosed.

JUDY PADOW is nothing if not adaptable.
