A monkey, a raccoon, five snakes and three iguanas were recaptured early yesterday after escaping from a circus truck that was damaged when it struck an overpass on the Northern State Parkway in Hicksville, L.I.

Renewed fears of rising interest rates weighed upon the stock market yesterday and sent the Dow Jones industrial average to a testing area only slightly above its 21-month low set Wednesday of last week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI) Leon Jaworski, chief counsel for the House ethics committee, has been denied any access to classified information in the panel's Korean influence-peddling investigation because he still needs security clearance, the Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed today.

ATLANTA, Oct. 5 (UPI) Martina Navratilova easily defeated Wendy Turnbull, 6-2, 6-1, tonight in the second round of the $75,000 Wyler Classic tennis tournament. Miss Navratilova has now defeated the Australian twice since Miss Turnbull upset her at Forest Hills.

IN LATE JUNE 1940, shortly after the surrender of France to Nazi Germany, a French colonel angrily watched several other French of ficers laugh and joke with a highranking German. It was, I believe, the distinguished Nebraska financier Father Edward J. Flanagan who professed to having "never met a bad boy." Having, myself, met a remarkable number of bad boys, it might seem that either our experiences were drastically different or we were using the word "bad" differently. I suspect neither is true, but rather that the Father was appraising the "inner man," while I, in fact, do not' acknowledge the existence of inner people.

Suzy Chaffee, former captain of the Olympic ski team, is carrying a torch for the women's movement. So is Cheryl Toussaint, Olympic silver medalist. And Katherine Switzer, the first woman to finish the Boston Marathon officially.

The credit markets dropped decisively in price yesterday, pushing interest rates higher in response to news that inflation heated up in September, Municipal bond prices showed their biggest weekly loss since February.

Helen Sperry Lea, who helped her father and brother perfect the automatic stabilization of aircraft in 1914, died last Friday at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital on long Island. She was 89 years old and lived in Bellport, L.I.
Any stretch of land has value for a politician, even the South Bronx with its dark building shells and idle constituency.

HARVEST DAY AT THE HECKSCHER FARM, from 10 A.M, to 4 P.M. on Sunday, will include harvest activities of the olden days, including bread and butter making, cheese making, wood lore, music, scrimshaw, honey harvesting, dried flower making and other activities, at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center Inc., 39 Scofieldtown Road, Stamford, Conn. Entrance fee, $2; Stamford residents, $1, (203) 322-1646.

ALBANY, Oct. 6 Taking issue with his Democratic, counterparts, the Senate majority leader Warren M. Anderson, said today that he did not want the State Legislature to consider extending or replacing the Emergency Financial Control Board for New York City until its regular session next year.
Richard Morton, a sales representative for Scientific American, died unexpectedly Sunday night in his home in Hilton Head, S.C. He was 63 years old.
Schenley Industries, one of the nation's , largest distillers and importers of liquor, was accused yesterday of paying $500,000 in kickbacks and rebates to its distributors in New York State.

The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's nuclear forces in Europe are largely an anachronism. These tactical nuclear weapons, so-called because they are intended for use on or near the battlefield, now number several thousand, many of them larger than those mounted on strategic missiles and bombers. They reflect a long and convoluted history, not careful analysisof NATO's current needs.

As expected, Artrtur Levitt Jr., president of Shearson Hayden Stone Inc., was elected yesterday vice chairman of the American Stock Exchange. Mr. Levitt, who was named to a two-year term on the Amex board of governors in 1976, is chairman of its programs and policies committee and a member of the committee to recommend a new chairman for the securities and options exchange.

American steel companies and unions won a small victory this week in their fight to shield domestic markets from foreign competition. In a move designed to reduce Congressional pressure for tougher protectionist measures, the Treasury ruled that Japanese producers were selling carbon steel plate in the United States at less than cost, and were thus subject to tariff penalties.

Shelley P. Smith, daughter of Harold Smith of New York and Miami Beach, and the late Ruth Smith, was married yesterday to Roy Warner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Warner of Fresh Meadows, Queens, and Hollywood. Fla.

The Internal Revenue Service plans to increase to 17 cents a mile from 15 cents the tax deduction it allows people to claim when they use their personal cars for business travel, sources close to the I.R.S. said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 In a highly unusual maneuver, the Senate Finance Committee tentatively agreed today to eliminate all of the major taxes proposed by President Carter to conserve oil and natural gas.

PISCATAWAY, N. J., Oct. 6 (UPI) The New Jersey Nets opened the new Rutgers University Athletic Center tonight with a 94-89 N.B.A. exhibitiongame victory over the Indiana Pacers before a crowd of 2,130.

Eight corporations and 26 individuals in Queens have been indicted on felony counts of stealing electricity and natural gas by jumping meters, the most severe charges lodged here so far in the rapidly growing crime of trying to avoid paying utility fees, John J. Santucci, the Queens District Attorney, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 Edvard Kardelj, the putative successor of President Tito of Yugoslavia, said yesterday after a week of talks here that Yugoslav-United States relations were better than ever before, in part because of a shift in American attitudes.

The Foreign Minister of India said yesterday that a "new chapter" of friendly relations had opened between his country and the United States, accompanied by many messages between President Carter and Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai on "important world issues."

Fred F. Finklehoffe, film, and stage producer, playwright and screenwriter, died Wednesday morning at his farm in Springtown, Pa. He was 67 years old.

DETROIT, Oct.6 (AP) The Chrysler Corporation is raising prices on its new cars an average $354, or 5.8 percent, from comparably equipped 1977 models, the third biggest United States automaker announced today.

GREAT AUCTION SEASONS have started with less activity, and poor ones have opened with more than what is scheduled for the weeks ahead at galleries in New York and around the world. It is, of course, too early to determine whether the art and antiques auction season now moving into high gear will be memorable. What is clear in reviewing the events announced so far is that the pace of public sales has definitely quickened.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 In a highly unusual maneuver, the Senate Finance Committee tentatively agreed today to eliminate all of the major taxes proposed by President Carter to conserve oil and natural gas.

The Citizens Union gave its backing yesterday to Representative Edward I. Koch for Mayor of New York City in the November election and to his Democratic running mates, State Senator Carol Bellamy, for Council President, and to Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who is seeking another term.

If you-hear screams, shots and moans in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel this weekend, it will not mean more mayhem in the diamond trade. It will not be the board meeting of a television network with slumping ratings. It will not be an Arab sheik who was served gefilte fish by mistake.

Ira Neimark, Bergdorf Goodman's president, was having a busy evening. At 5:30 he gave a party for the store's employees to celebrate the biggest September in the store's history, one that included the two best days and the best week of sales ever.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 6 The latest legal skirmish between former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and the Government has left Mrs. Gandhi in a clearly improved political position, with dazed supporters of the Government wondering what went wrong.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 6 By this time next week, 21-year-old Susan R. VanHattum, a junior at the University of Michigan here, could be viewing the world from the inside of a jail cell.
How many players are we going to be permitted to carry?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 A big change has come over Washington in the last couple of weeks, and as Henry Kissinger wise-cracked in Chicago the other day, "You have to give Bert Lance credit." After being preoccupied for months with personalities, bank balances, filibusters and other trivialities, the capital of the United States is finally talking again about the fundamental problems of national and world politics.

Alfresco art has become nearly synonymous with autumn in New York. East 64th Street from Madison to Lexington Avenues will become an-arcade of fine art and crafts this weekend, as more than 100 painters, sculptors and craftsworkers converge upon two of Manhattan's most beautiful residential blocks to display their creations.

When the telephone began to jangle yesterday in Vicente Aleixandre's Madrid villa, he left it off the hook. When a television crew asked to film an interview, he declined, saying that he was going to bed to conserve his strength for his writing.

TRENTON, Oct. 6 Although more than 300,000 people were out of work for most of 1976, New Jersey ranked second among the states in per-capita income last year, according to figures compiled by the United States Department of Commerce and released today by the state's Department of Labor and Industry.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The Senate voted tonight, 76 to 14, to increase the minimum hourly wage from the current $2.30 to $2.65 in 1978, with yearly increases to $3.40 in 1981.

Governor Carey and Mario M. Cuomo shared the dais at the Liberal Party's annual dinner last night as Mr. Cuomo, who was the Governor's original choice for Mayor and still is the Liberal Party's candidate, attacked the Democratic candidate, Representative Edward I. Koch, who is Mr. Carev's present choice.

A course of study in the Holocaustthe slaughter of Jews by Nazi Germany was introduced by the Board of Education yesterday, and board officials said they hoped it would be made mandatory in all New York city high schools next year.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 The United States and Vietnam went through the motions today of disagreeing publicly but did not dispel the impression that they were edging toward smoother relations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 President Carter assured a delegation of Jewish members of Congress and supporters of Israel today of his commitment to Israel and he also made a gesture of friendship toward Edward I. Koch.
NEWARK, Oct. 6 (AP) The Mayor of Jersey City, Thomas F.X. Smith, has said he will go to court if the state attempts to develop any part of the Library State Park.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 With a warning from the mine owners that a failure to reach a "growth" labor contract could bring the extinction of the nation's oldest union, leaders of the expansion-minded coal industry and the United Mine Workers of America opened negotiations today on a new wage agreement.

A prisoner who had escaped from custody twice before got away yesterday from a detective who had brought him to the Manhattan District Attorney's office for questioning. The prisoner made his escape after spraying ammonia in the detective's face and seizing his revolver.

POET SAINT LUCIE, Fla., Oct. 6 The Episcopal House of Bishops acted today to combat the growing schism in the church by passing a resolution that "deplores and repudiates" the efforts by retired Bishop Albert A. Chambers to aid the separatist cause.

AUDIENCES that have been packing Alice Tully Hall for the programs of the New York Film Festival are, like the audiences at film festivals everywhere, unreliable. They have any number of reasons for behaving the way they do, only some of which have to do with whether they like the film they're watching.

The Department of Health, Education and Welfare accused the New York City public school system yesterday of maintaining several thousand illegally segregated classrooms, and ordered the school authorities to submit within 45 days a plan for desegregating them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The nation rate of inflation, as measured by whole. sale prices, picked up again in September after moderate increases in the summer, according to Government figures made public today.

The Central Intelligence Agency has rejected a second request by The New York Times under the Freedom of information Act for information on any relationships between the agency and past or present employees of the newspaper. A similar request was turned down last year.

Jane L. Albert, who served 20 months in prison for her part in a 1969 conspiracy to bomb buildings in New York, received an additional four-month sentence yesterday despite a vehement renunciation of her radical past.

The Carter Administration is pressing for the reconvening of a new Middle East peace conference in Geneva. This effort has evoked considerable controversy and a good deal of confusion. Following, in question and answer format, is a discussion of some of the major issues.

Three years ago, the tan brick apartment house at 1186 Washington Avenue in the Morrisania section of the Bronx looked so much a part of the square miles of desolation around it that city officials were loath to lend $310,OO0 to the young people who wanted to restore it.

Major retailers reported yesterday that consumer buying in September rose sharply across the nation, giving some of the chain stores their biggest monthly sales gains of the year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The Senate voted tonight, 76 to 14, to increase the minimum hourly wage from the current $2.30 to $2.65 in 1978, with yearly increases to $3.40 in 1981.

The hijackers of a Japan Air Lines DC-8 commandered over India last week unwittingly let a flight attendant get off the plane in Bangladesh carrying nearly $2 million in diamonds: a spokesman for the airline said in New York yesterday.

ALAN LLOYD, a composer often associated with Robert Wilson (he did some of the music for Mr. Wilson's "The Life and Times of Joseph Stalin," among other projects) and with Mr. Wilson's longtime choreographic associate. Andrew deGroat (he's providing music for a deGroat dance program Oct. 15 and 16 at the Cunningham Studio in Westbeth), gave a concert of his music Wednesday night at the kitchen. It was a curious affair.

J.P. Morgan Co. and its subsidiary, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, announced major executive changes yesterday that will make Walter H. Page the new chairman and chief executive of both companies.
New York City officials said yesterday that if President Carter was serious about wanting to help the South Bronx, they had a plan for how to do it, a plan they sent to Washington last June.
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 6 The Swedish Academy awarded the 1977 Nobel Prize in Literature today to Vicente Aleixandre, a Spanish surrealist poet little known outside the Spanish-speaking world.

There will be a Himalayan harvest on Staten Island this weekend when the Jacques Marchais Center of Tibetan Art holds its Tibetan Harvest Festival tomorrow and Sunday from noon to 6 P.M. The festival will feature Tibetan food and fortune-telling and Tibetan and Oriental handicrafts, antiques, clothing and rugs.

Ron Guidry, the skinny Cajun the Kansas City Royals wanted last year and the Yankees nearly did not want last spring, pitched a three-hitter last night as the Yankees downed the Royals, 6-2, and sent the American League playoffs west in a 1-1 deadlock.

The largest baseball crowd of the year in Yankee Stadium numbering 56,230 at a $9 top hooted and yelled and littered the field last night as the New York Yankees tied the playoff for the American League pennant at l-1 and escalated their "grudge" against the Kansas City Royals.
Corn and soybean futures prices rose substantially yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly reflecting the possibility of increased buying of grains and soybeans by the Soviet Union.
The nation's two largest supermarket chains, Safeway Stores Inc. and the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, yesterday reported substantial declines in quarterly earnings.
Just how good is Dartmouth? Followers of the Ivy League will have the answer late tomorrow afternoon after Dartmouth collides with Yale in the Bowl at New Haven.

The prospects for a speedy settlement of the Atlantic and Gulf Coast dock workers' strike dimmed yesterday when the chief Federal mediator and representatives of the shipping industry failed to work out a "common approach" on the crucial issue of job security.
A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan ruled yesterday that the supersonic Concorde airliner could start flights to Kennedy International Airport at once.
Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt said yesterday after a meeting with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance that "things are moving" toward convening a Geneva conference on the Middle East.
The dollar slipped against most major world currencies today although its slide eased a bit in late New York Foreign exchange trading, The Associated Press reported.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 6 There was a time when racquetball players had to fight the handball players to get a court. But that was 40 years ago. Now the racquetballers have their own courts in gleaming glass and chrome centers and a $250,000 professional tour across the country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (Reuters) The Soviet Union has the fastest-growing merchant fleet in the world and will replace Japan as number one within two years, Senator Daniel K. Inouye said here today.

The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that an aerosol manufacturer could not recover damages from a public relations firm that first mounted a campaign against aerosol products through a related public relations firm and then tried to obtain the account of the manufacturer in order to combat adverse publicity.

Twenty-five members of Betar, an international Zionist youth movement, entered and occupied the lobby of the United States Mission to the United Nations yesterday and demanded to see Andrew Young, the United States delegate, in a demonstration of Jewish indignation at the American-Soviet statement on the Middle East. The sit-in was orderly and without incident.

The Pabst Brewing Company, Milwaukee, which has dropped a notch in its industry ranking, is seeking presentations from a number of Chicago and New York ad agencies. It has had its business at Kenyon Eckhardt sine 1959.

The other was Li Fu-sheng, a student at the People's Liberation Army Institute of Physical Culture in Peking.

The New York Botanical Garden and the Bronx Zoo will stage a Flora and Fauna Festival tomorrow and Sunday; featuring an animal parade, a plant sale, exhibits and entertainment. An admission charge of $1.50 for adults, 75 cents for children will cover the daylong activities at both places.

EVERY ARCHER knows that if you don't aim somewhat above the target you won't hit it, gravity being one of those harsh old laws that still has not been nullified by popular request. So more power to a musician who shoots high, as Jane Allen did in her piano recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night. Unfortunately, the targets she chose were sometimes so far above her abilities that she missed them entirely.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 After months of aggressive lobbying, organized labor won a major victory today as the House of Representatives passed a bill designed to help unions revive their flagging drive to organize workers.

READERS who have been alienated by the questionable activities of American intelligence communities will have no cause to reverse themselves after reading "The Secret Lovers." Charles McCarry's suspense novel takes the reader into the very interior of one of these apparatuses. One learns not only how the people there work, but what they think of their work, their department. their colleagues and their careers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 6 The United States and the Soviet Unian sidestepped a direct confrontation today in their opening statements at the 35-nation conference being held here to review progress on human rights, European security and economic cooperation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17 billion ton-miles, up 3.9 percent from the year-earlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 494,728 cars, up 2 percent from last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage rose 5.1 percent from a year ago.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 6 On June 12, 1961, a 23-year-old American soldier stationed in Orleans, France, was administered LSD without his consent or knowledge in an effort by an Army intelligence team to determine the whereabouts of classified documents the soldier was suspected of stealing, according to recently declassified Department of Army documents.

Then, as the music quickens, he hurls himself into a frantic, furious dance, lunging, rolling and leaping in response to his inner agony.

Jose Ber Gelbard, a former minister of the economy in Argentina and one of Gen. Juan D. Peron's closest associates during his third and final term as president in 1973 and 1974, died Tuesday in Washington after a heart attack. He was 60 years old.

Alexander's Inc, one of the metropolitan's largest retail chains, reported yesterday a fourth-quarter net loss of $384, 000 against an operating net profit of $397,000 in the 1976 period, mainly due to the promotional need to stimulate apparel sales that resulted in reduced margins.
A new corporate tactic of reducing an original tender offer has been tried three times recently with mixed results, raising questions in Wall Street about the strategy's overall worth.

Though more and more women are serving on corporate boards of directors, "even at the present rate of increase, it will take many years for women to win a significant percentage of corporate directorships," a recent survey by Burson-Marsteller, a publicrelations firm, shows.
The American Civil Liberties Union has decided to make its top priority for the coming year a campaign to preserve the right of women to obtain abortions if they choose.
The General Electric Company has been awarded $71.1 million in Navy contracts for nuclear power plant components and replacement parts.
A party to celebrate the 200th birthday of New York State will be given tomorrow on the Empire State Plaza in Albany, with about 100,000 people expected to attend.

DURING THE LAST two decades, when vibrant communities in many parts of New York City have declined, some times into virtual wastelands, a section of northwest Queens-Astoria-that was beginning to slump, has been turned around and is now booming. New homes have arisen, and old ones have been renovated. Empty, stores have become prosperous businesses, and desolate buildings have become thriving factories.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 7 Gov. Marvin Mandel, convicted of mail fraud and racketeering, was sentenced today to four years in prison.
Merger lightning is flashing with such frequency over the industrial horizon these days that one of the big investment games is trying to figure out where it is going to strike next.

School Chancellor Irving Anker, faced with a Federal finding that there are illegally segregated classrooms in some New York City schools that are racially mixed overall, said yesterday that he would not place the racial distribution of students above their educational needs.
Rudolph Bochco, a violinist, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 77 years old.

The United States, the Soviet Union, Israel and the Arab nations have agreed informally to aim for December for the start of a new Middle East peace conference in Geneva, a high-ranking State Department official said yesterday.

VIRGINIA WATER, England, Oct. 7 (UPI) Ray Floyd shrugged off a death threat and the youthful challenge of Severiano Ballesteros today to reach the 36-hole final of the $225,000 world match play golf championship.

LONDON, Oct. 7, (Reuters) The Bank of England today reduced its minimum lending rate by one-half percent to five and a half percent one year to the day after it was raised to an unprecedented 15 percent at the height of Britain's financial crisis.

Governor Carey yesterday released a list of projects totaling $1.5 billion that he said could be built in New York City if the state's proposed economic-development bond issue was approved by voters next month. His announcement immediately led Mayor Beame to warn that the city might have been shortchanged.

Public-television stations in Chicago, Boston, Atlanta, St. Louis, Dallas, Miami and Detroit, among other major cities, have rejected a controversial episode of "Black Perspective on the News" on which the leaders of the Ku Klux Klan and the American Nazi Party, as interview guests, make racist and anti-Semitic remarks.

Dr. Claude E. Heaton, who retired in 1967 as professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the New York University School of Medicine, died Sept. 30 in Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass., He was 80 years old and lived in South Orleans, Mass.

Thanks to an end run by a determined woman named Carolyn Pitts around the city fathers of Cape May, N.J., that community awoke one morning six years ago to find itself on the National Register of Historical Places, the official Federal listing of protected sites and buildings of architectural and historical value.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 7 Gov. Marvin Mandel, convicted in Federal District Court six weeks ago of mail fraud and racketeering, was sentenced today to four years in prison.
Walt Frazier is going the way of Julius Erving, Tom Seaver and Joe Namath, sports superstars no longer playing for New York teams.

The Metropolitan Opera does not officially open its season until Monday evening, but the house was buzzing with activity and resounding with music Thursday night. The occasion was the Met's third annual marathon drive for money, and 16 Met singers donated their services.

MOSCOW, Oct. 7 The Soviet Union today adopted a new Constitution, which, apart from minor changes in language, is essentially the same as the draft made public in June. The subsequent months of a carefully orchestrated discussion in the controlled press appear to have made little substantive difference in the final adopted version.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 7 (AP) The Vatican representative at the European security conference today criticized religious restrictions in Communist countries and asked freedom of worship for Eastern Rite Catholics in the Soviet Union.

New Jerseyans became the first targets yesterday of plans by New York City to sue out-of-towners with unpaid parking tickets. The action marks the second phase of a two-year-old effort to collect millions of dollars in such overdue fines.

Prof. Franz Boehm, who opposed Nazi racial policy during the Hitler regime and was instrumental in persuading West Germany to pay reparations to Nazi victims, died Sept, 26 at his home in Rockenberg, West Germany. Funeral services were held Wednesday in Frankfurt. He was 82 years old.
A police sergeant whose body is still riddled with fragments from the explosion last year of a terrorists' bomb was named commander of the New York City Police Department's bomb squad.

Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the United States Supreme Court yesterday reimposed the ban on flights of the supersonic Concorde airliner to New York to give the full court a chance to deal with the matter.

IIlli Kagan, a sculptor of contemporary art, and a former resident of 85 East End Avenue in Manhattan, died Thursday in G Geneva, where he had been living for I eight years. He was 92 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 John L. Moore Jr., head of the United States Export-Import Bank, disclosed today that Zaire had not paid $10.3 million in interest or fees on its $435 million debt to the bank since August and that prospects for repayment of principal on the loans in the near future were not promising. At the same time, Zaire has been making payments on its debt to commercial banks, he said.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 Senator Jacob K. Javits told the Senate today that the troubles of the ravaged South Bronx could be laid to poverty, unemployment and the "incursion of new citizens who don't know our way."

WASHINGTON Three scientists for the International Business Machines Corporation have invented a promising new technique for storing information in computer memories, in which the use of magnetic bubbles is amplified.

PARIS, Oct. 7 The President of the Common Market Commission launched a new drive today to give the nine member countries a single currency that could rival the dollar as a pillar of the international monetary system.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 7 Meadowlands racing officials have decided to ask for a return to harness racing at the start of 1978. They have the alternative of resuming the current thoroughbred meeting in January but will instead request harness dates as more practical for winter racing.
MCA Inc., the huge entertainment company, disclosed yesterday that it was prepared to pay about $140 million in cash for the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7-The nation's unemployment rate dropped slightly to 6.9 percent in September, the Labor Department reported today, but Government officials said that there was little long-term improvement in the situation, particularly for blacks.

Andrew Gunnar Hagstrom, founder and retired president of the Hagstrom Map Company, 450 West 33d Street, died Sept. 24 in a hospital in St. Thomas, V.I., after a brief illness. He was 87 years old. He had an estate in Englishtown, N.J., but had lived in St. Thomas in recent months.

JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 7 The South African Government, angered by the wide publicity given to the death of Stephen Biko in police custody last month, today moved to constrain reporting on the affair by making a forma complaint against one of the country's foremost newspapers, The Rand Daily Mail.
MIAMI, Oct. 7 Ronny Zamora has been convicted, but the jury is still out on television, which, in the minds of many, was the co-defendant in his much publicized trial here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) The Senate approved a $364.5 million supplementary military spending bill tonight that provides money to develop missile-carrying aircraft to replace the canceled B-1 bomber.
A prisoner who escaped Sunday night from Rikers Island held his wife at gunpoint for nearly nine hours in East Harlem yesterday morning before surrendering.

The State Energy Commissioner, Joel R. Jacobson, said yesterday that despite optimism on the part of suppliers of natural gas that there will be enough fuel this winter, he was, nevertheless, concerned.

Copper futures, which have been in the doldrums recently, managed to show some strength yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here. The December delivery closed at 57.30 cents a pound, up sixtenths of a cent. This compares with its contract high of 75.60 cents an July 6, 1976 and a low of 53.20 last Aug. 16.
HOUSTON, Oct. 7(AP) Amy Alcott shot a four-under-par 68 today to take the first-round lead in a $50,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association tournament.

Mario M. Cuomo said last night that if he was elected Mayor he would seek to resolve a growing controversy over the reassignment of public school teachers by race by appointing a citizens' panel to find "the least disruptive means" of balancing the racial composition of the 51,500-member teaching staff.
Wolfgang Rose, a New York pianist and teacher, died Sept. 6 while vacation ing in Bad Tatzmannsdorf, Austria. He was 70 years old.

CORONA DEL MAR, Calif., Oct. 7 (UPI)-Richard M. Nixon, in what may have been his first political speech since he resigned the Presidency three years ago, has told a group of Republicans that "fighting spirit" is more important to a political candidate than money.

The United States, the Soviet Union, Israel and the Arab nations have agreed informally to aim for December for the start of a new Middle East peace conference in Geneva, a high-ranking State Department official said yesterday.

Count Otto Lambsdorff was appointed yesterday by President Walter Scheel of West Germany to be Economics Minister, succeeding Hans Friderichs. Mr. Friderichs announced last month that he would resign to become a director of the Dresdner Bank in Frankfurt, filling the vacancy left when the bank's chairman, J rgen Ponto, was fatally shot by terrorists in an attempt to kidnap him from his Frankfurt home on July 30.

MATAWAN, Oct. 7 Associate Justice Alan B. Handler of the New Jersey Supreme Court ordered the release today of 35 Matawan school teachers who were jailed yesterday for disobeying a court order to end their strike, which began Sept. 16.

Dr. John Clifford, who retired this spring as dean of student affairs at St. Francis College in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack on Thursday on the campus of St. John's University. He was 46 years old and lived at 255-13 East Williston Avenue in Floral Park, Queens.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 While the New York Yankees beat the Kansas City Royals in their drama tonight half a continent away, the Los Angeles Dodgers watched, waited and prepared to pitch Don Sutton against the Yankees in the opening game of the World Series on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9-Increasingly concerned about the sluggish pace of investment, Administration planners have expanded by several billion dollars the tax reduction for business that President Carter is likely to propose to Congress as part of a broader tax reform package, Administration sources said today.

Sister Mary Michael Simpson, who earlier this year became the first Episcopal nun to be ordained a priest, was installed yesterday as a canon residentiary at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine the first woman to hold that title in this country.

Lending in the United States by foreign banks has been growing despite a period of poor demand for business loans that has resulted in a decline in domestic commercial and industrial lending by major United States banks, according to statistics released by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston at a conference here.

All the music that the cellist Seymour Barab performed Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall was either written for or dedicated to Mr. Barab himself. It was an impressive and stimulating collection, representing nine wellknown American composers and spanning a broad spectrum of styles.

Women's mountaineering in America is finally coming of age. In the fall of 1978 the American Women's Himalayan Expedition will attempt Annapurna, a major peak of 26,504 feet. WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Existing firefighting methods could not extinguish a large fire of liquefied natural gas on, water, according to a report to be released tomorrow by the Office of Technology Assessment.

Beth Alison Meltzer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Meltzer of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., was married yesterday to Philip Alan Binder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Binder of Brooklyn. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel performed the ceremony in the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y.

HOUSTON, Oct. 9 Natural gas producers and energy economists here are charging that the Carter Administration, in its fight to retaing Federal price controls on natural gas, has resorted to grossly exaggerated cost projections for unregulated new gas an derroneous assumptions about the rate of future gas discoveries.

Asia House at 112 East 64th Street began its 1977-78 season of Sunday afternoon concerts yesterday with a recital of Japanese music by Fusako Yoshida and Chikako Kawaji. BALTIMORE, Oct. 9 The Baltimore Colts have had a number of great days, and this day was the equal of any. In a clash of unbeaten teams of the Colts fell 18 points behind the Miami Dolphins during a wild first half in which 52 points were scored but came all the way back to win an exceptional game by 17 points. The score? Baltimore 45, Miami 28.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 10 The Israeli Government has approved six new Jewish settlements in Israeli military and police bases ringing the Samarian hills in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River, Israel's Deputy Defense Minister said today.

An amicable divorce was brought about here unobtrusively last month When the Nassau-Suffolk Bridge Association broke away from the Greater New York Bridge Association. He was 78 years old and had retired five years ago from his practice in Newark to live in Boca Raton.

The Dana Corporation, manufacturer of parts for trucks and automobiles, announced yesterday that net income in its fourth fiscal quarter, ended Aug. 30 increased 17 percent from the year-ago period. The board raised the cash dividend to $1.20 year from 84 cents to shareholders of record Nov. 29.

Laurence L. Bunker, a retired Army colonel who served as Gen. Douglas MacArthur's chief aide and later became a leading member of the John Birch Society, died yesterday at New England Baptist Hospital in Boston. He was 75 years old and had been under treatment for cancer for the last five weeks.

Robert S. Strauss, the president's special representative for trade negotiations, said yesterday that he and Mr. Carter were determined to press forward with new multinational tariff and trade agreements, but would seek meanwhile to ease the steel industry's "adjustment" to import competition.

The faces were different and the names were different, but the drama and memories were the same last night when the New York Yankees beat back the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-3, in 12 innings as the old rivals opened baseball's 74th World Series in Yankee Stadium.

Charles L. Schultze, the Administration's chief economic adviser, said yesterday that he saw "no major distortions or imbalances in the economy that might precipitate a downturn or prolonged pause." But he conceded that the outlook beyond mid-1978 "has become more uncertain" because by that time the current economic stimulus program will no longer be adding fresh impetus to the recovery.

PEKING In the summer of 1973, a young man named Chang accompanied his girlfriend to an out-of-the-way place in their factory where they proceeded to make love. Some fellow workers happened upon them in the middle of their love-making.
If anyone had suggested a 914-foothigh building of glistening aluminum with a sloping roof on top and a cluster of stores, a church and a plaza at the bottom to Citicorp when it ....

The Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. seemed tired at times yesterday as he talked of his efforts in the civil-rights movement and, at 77, fatigue was understandable. But there were moments, too, when his eyes widened to punctuate a point and his voice surged like the sea.

THE WOMEN from Action for Children's Television, one of the more sensitive and effective lobbying groups for better programming, have come a long way in a hard-nosed industry. Several years ago, when first organized, they were dismissed contemptuously as "those Ladies from Boston." Today, especially when ABC wins another award for its series of "After School Specials," they are praised as courageous pioneers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Joseph A. Califano Jr., said today that it was "grossly unfair to hold the vulnerable people of our nation and thousands of Federal and state employees hostage" in a dispute over paying for abortions for poor women.

The Rev. William Henry Pickford, rector of Christ Episcopal Church, Broadway and 71st Street, for 35 years, died yesterday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived on Trinity Pass, Pound Ridge, N.Y.

IT IS LATER than it should be at night, in life, Eleven o'clock, and he is still watching a baseball game on television, in the bowels of the house, after the other inmates have gone to bed. Why, he wonders, are the New York Yankees always whining? What liturgical significance attaches to a tantrum? Is Billy Martin necessary?

Detectives searched the area near the Sherry-Netherland Hotel yesterday in hopes of finding a delivery man or passerby who saw the departure of the four robbers who looted the hotel's safe-deposit boxes Monday morning.

Joan Mondale, the arts advocate in the Carter Administration, journeyed deep into the heart of Brooklyn yesterday to visit two cultural institutions and to assure a group of women artists that the White House had their best interests at heart.

IN THE LAST SEVERAL years Meyer Kupferman has com posed full-length concert programs for several different performers, and at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night Daniel and Machiko Kobialka introduced the concert of works for violin and piano that he wrote for them.

Carmine Galante, reputedly one of the nation's most powerful leaders of organized crime, surrendered to Federal marshals in Manhattan yesterday and was held in jail for allegedly violating his parole by associating with known criminals.
Both comments are true, depending on the person in the job.

New York City is "worse off today than it was when the fiscal crisis hit in 1975," Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday. Only a Mayor free of political commitments, he said, will be able to avoid the "Band Aid solutions, gimmicks and tricks" that have been used thus far.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) President Carter tried to persuade a group of influential senators today to support the Panama Canal treaties, but the Senate Republican leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., said afterward, "I don't think anybody changed his position."

DAVIS, Calif., Oct. 7 This town and the adjoining campus assume nearmystical status for many of their residents, who speak of the place as an oasis of serenity and civility in a world of conflict and confusion.

Colleges and professional schools are vigorously engaged in affirmative-action admissions programs, and any restrictions on their freedom to use race as a criterion for acceptance could substantially reduce the participation of minority students in higher education, according to two officials of the Educational Testing Service.

LONDON, Oct. 11 While the Nobel Peace Prize was publicly welcomed in Northern Ireland today, there was a strong private feeling among some political leaders and others that the peace movement recognized by the prize has lost much of its momentum.

WASHINGTON The Consumer Product Safety Commission has proposed that Warning labels be voluntarily put on grocery store carts to alert parents to the possible dangers of leaving children unattended in the carts.

Dr. Mason Welch Gross, president of Rutgers University from 1959 to 1971, died yesterday in Riverview Hospital, Red Bank, N.J., after a long illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 18 Monmouth Avenue, Rumson, N.J.

There are some sobering questions to be asked about American science beyond those raised in the fresh public debate over the future of D.N.A. research, over laetrile and over artificial sweeteners. Whatever the outcry over these scientific disputes, an essential element in this debate is largely missing: What ought to be our national investment in our scientific future?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (Reuters) President Carter and the Nigerian head of state, Lieut. Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, agreed today that progress was being made on the American-British proposal for bringing black majority rule to Rhodesia, the White House said.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 The Supreme Court agreed today to consider whether the death penalty could be imposed on a person who participates in a serious crime that results in murder but is not involved in the actual killing.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 11 The Americans are coming back to Beirut, and the . return is like an injection of hope for the Lebanese capital, still half stunned from the devastating civil war.

JOHN ANTHONY is exhilarated about two new sewing machines that will enable him to make clothes look lighter and more airborne than they ever have been before. Bill Blass is returning to ruffles, Halston is concerned with the new romanticism and Calvin Klein is thinking in terms of combining jacquards with crepe de chine.
Interest rates climbed sharply yesterday as the credit markets continued to worry about a big increase in the money supply this week.

The political dealings of their fathers and trafficking with the Republican Party were once again raised as key issues in the campaign for Manhattan Borough President yesterday by Andrew J. Stein and Robert F. Wagner Jr.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) Judge Luther B. Eubanks of Federal District Court today ordered an Oklahoma City trucking company to pay more than $1.8 million to 46 black persons who were found to be victims of the company's policies of racial discrimination.

Let computers run the factory. Technology has been urging that notion on American industry for some time now, with mixed success. Industry seems impressed by breakthroughs in this area, but, by and large, really sophisticated computer-based manufacturing systems have been slow to take root in the nation's factories.

CURRENTLY, with free agents and multimillion-dollar players' contracts, it is difficult to imagine major-league baseball players' attempting to fix a game. It is just not financially feasible for a top player to become involved. But in "Eight Men Out," an account of the infamous Black Sox scandal of 1919, Eliot Asinof clearly demonstrates why it was not always so.

Over the abusive shouts and protest of 100 peddlers in the gallery, the New York City Council passed a bill yesterday to license and regulate both food and general-merchandise vendors. The vote was 33 to 1.
Mayor Beame yesterday welcomed a move by three major corporations to New York City and a long-term lease renewal by a fourth company. The three new corporations are expected to provide 750 jobs.

Frank J. Reed, who retired a year ago as vice president of SSC Inc., I Dag Kammarskjold Plaza, died Sunday in Manchester (Conn.) Memorial Hospital after a short illness. He was 66 years old and lived on Crescent Beach Road, Pine Point, Rowayton, Conn.

Five symposiums on the past, present and future of New York's "Great White Way" will be sponsored by the Graduate School of the City University of New York and the New York Council for the Humanities, beginning Oct. 18.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) The Senate voted unanimously Monday to confirm the nomination of Charles D. Ferris, the lawyer to Thomas P. O'Neill, Speaker of the House, to the Federal Communications Commission.

Activities of Representative John M. Murphy of New York in attempting to facilitate an oil deal between Iran and Nicaragua during the oil embargo of 1973-74 have come to light in documents made available to The New York Times.
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 11 The 1977 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded today to two Americans and a Briton, and the Nobel Prize in Chemistry went to a Belgian scientist.
After closing his jewelry store for the day. Ernie Levy retreats to the basement of his home in Liberty, N.Y., to do what he likes best make furniture. Very special furniture.

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 11 The Conservative Party survived today the threat of a divisive split over the question of its relationship to the trade unions the question that brought down the last Conservative government in 1974.

FRANKFURT, Oct. 11 This year, even more than in the past, the 29th annual book fair that opens tomorrow in Frankfurt am Main is a political, commercial and, if you look hard for it, literary event. Seventy-five nations from Afghanistan to Zaire are exhibiting, which is just over half the number of states in the United Nations.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 11 The decision by the Meadowlands to apply for harness-racing dates starting in January seems already to have eased a potential horse shortage for Aqueduct's winter meeting.
James Kenneth Huntington, a general insurance broker who was president and chairman of the New Rochelle Agency, died yesterday at New Rochelle, N.Y., Medical Center. He was 81 years old:
A behind-the-scenes drama was watched almost as closely as the baseball game when the Yankees opened the World Series last night against the Los Angeles Dodgers at Yankee Stadium.

SPETSAIS, Greece Tantative arrangements are now under way to start exploring the sea-bottom wreckage of a great naval battle which changed the strategic balance in the Mediterranean here more than seven centuries ago. The little-known battle was between this inland sea's two great fleets, those of Genoa and Venice.
The RCA Corporation reported yesterday an 88 percent jump in its third-quarter earnings and a 50 percent increase for the first nine months of the year.

BANKSVILLE, N.Y. ALTHOUGH THE GUESTS were expected at 7 P.M. on Sept. 27, the preparation for the dinner really began a week earlier in the kitchens of La Cremaillere, the gracious French country restaurant in this Westchester County community, about 80 minutes by car from New York City.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) The United States Customs Service plans to drastically reduce the number of airplanes used in looking for smugglers along the Texas border, a spokesmen said today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 10 The United States today brought up four Soviet and Czechoslovak actions that it said reflected "a continuing pattern of disrespect for the pledges we have all made" on human rights.

ANYONE WHO has ever stashed a bunch of greenish bananas in a brown paper bag to ripen, only to forget about them until they turned into a soggy mass will be pleased to note a special fruit ripening bowl new to the market. Called the RipenRight Fruit Bowl and developed at the University of California at Davis, the fruit-shaped, clear-plastic container works to ripen fruit evenly and quickly at room temperature.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the producers who market more than 95 percent of the nation's broiler chickens are "farmers" and thus exempt from some antitrust laws.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 President Carter submitted to Congress today a plan to combine the United States Information Agency and the State Department's Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs into a single Agency for International Communication to direct American information and cultural exchange programs.
The Thiokol Corporation and the Hoover Ball and Bearing Company announced merger plans yesterday in a stock deal that would involve some $181 million for Hoover Ball shareholders.

BERKELEY, Calif. The first of three groups of six women has checked into the "Penthouse" of the University of California at Berkeley's Nutritional Science Department Oct. 4 as subjects in a study of the nutritional needs of pregnant women.
Gamble-Skogmo Inc., a diversified retail store operator, disclosed in Minneapolis that it had withdrawn from takeover discussions with the AgacheWillot group of Lille, France.
FRANKFURT, Oct. 11 (AP) A man and woman brandishing pistols hijacked a Czechoslovak airliner on a domestic flight today, surrendered a few hours later in Frankfurt and asked for political asylum..

UNCOMPROMISING ON ABORTION The House will vote tomorrow on a proposal crafted by its members of a conference committee who were instructed three months ago to find a compromise with the Senate on Federal abortion policy. The proposal before the House, however, is no compromise.
Four new members have been added to the baseball executive council, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday.

The Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Los Angeles, one of the biggest soft-drink bottlers in the country, said yesterday that its directors had rejected a $410 million takeover bid by MCA Inc., the big entertainment company, as "inadequate."

In less than a month, the Carter Administration must tell the International Labor Organization whether the United States will remain a member. A Cabinet committee met last August to review the issue and adjourned without a decision. It meets again this afternoon. The case for staying in the I.L.O. was strong in August. It is even stronger now.

The dollar dropped to its second-lowest level against the Japanese yen since World War II in foreign exchange trading yesterday, but fared better against most European currencies, The Associated Press reported.
The Department of Energy yesterday ordered the Getty Oil Company to pay the Government more than $85 million to offset overcharges resulting from alleged illegal foreign oil exchanges.

Fears of rising interest rates and a slackening economy the worst of all worlds for a discouraged stock market sent the Dow Jones industrial average down nearly 8 points yesterday to its lowest level since December 1975.

We thought we knew everything there was to know about the friends with whom we were to share a summer house. But what we could not predict since our families had been living in different cities for some years was that Donald, an old buddy of my husband's, had turned into a variety of man-yak.

MENTOR, Ohio Grandmaster Walter Browne, held to draws by International Master Bernard Zuckerman in the eighth round and by International Master Dumitru Ghizdavu in the ninth, nevertheless retained his lead with a 6-3 score in the United States Championship Tournament here in the Mentor Inn.

Lester M. Levin, a lawyer who served in the Department of Labor in the early years of the National Labor Relations Board, died Monday morning in a fall from the apartment building at 25 East End Avenue, where he lived. Detectives of the 19th Precinct listed the death as a suicide.
A partial eclipse of the sun will be visible from the United States this afternoon, but people farthest west will get the best view, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
Once upon a time, genealogy was the pursuit of retired ministers, prospective members of patriotic or hereditary societies and wealthy moguls hoping to discover they had Mayflower ancestors.

Joe DiMaggio, one of the great stars of the past for the New York Yankees, was scheduled to throw out the first ball of the first World Series game last night, but instead he watched the New York-Los Angeles opener on television.

IN A SWEEPING SERIES of charges, Michael Straight, acting chairman of the National Endow ment for the Arts, contends that the arts endowment and its twin agency, the National Endowment for the Humanities, have become politicized by vested interests, pressure groups, Congress and the Carter Administration.

Federal District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr., President Carter's nominee for Director of the Federal Bureau of investigation, has developed a common type of hernia in his groin, Judge Johnson's physician said in a telephone interview yesterday.
Morris Blake, a principal and dress buyer of Magerfield, Chernoff Associates, a New York resident buying office, died Monday night at his home in Co-op City, the Bronx. He was 54 years old.
Another big Wall Street merger was proposed yesterday when Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette Inc. announced that it planned to acquire Pershing Company and Wood, Struthers Winthrop.
Robert Six, chairman of Continental Airlines, said the carrier would report a record profit this year and may resume paying dividends next year after a seven-year lapse.

One of the most satisfying experiences for a defender at the bridge table is the play that diverts a declarer from a winning plan to a losing one. A simple but elegant example of this matador technique was played at the Cavendish Club by the late John Percy, a lawyer who contributed many interesting deals to this column.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) The United States Commission on Civil Rights today endorsed affirmative action programs in professional schools, including the use of numerically based admissions programs.

Seventy policemen, more than twice the normal contingent, were assigned to the Madison Square Garden area for last night's rock concert, to prevent a recurrence of the Monday night rampage by youths who were turned away from a sold-out concert. Last night's performance was not sold out, and there were no incidents or arrests, in contrast to Monday night.
Isidore Godfrey, conductor of the D'Oyly Carte Opera for 43 years, died at his home in Sussex, England, on Sept. 12. He was 76 years old.

OVER at the Juilliard School where he is a freshman, the lanky, smiling violinist is known as Jimmy, but now that he has won his first international contest, he would prefer to be known professionally by his own name: ChouLiang Lin. There probably are professions in which a Jimmy could be a success, but Mr. Lin feels that a virtuoso of the violin requires something more formal.

ATLANTA, Oct. 12 Transportation Secretary Brock Adams and a House subcommittee chairman called today for a long-term financing plan for urban mass transit projects similar to the national trust fund for highways.

LEST WE FORGET The public is invited to a free program of films and discussions titled "Sacco Vanzetti: Fifty Years." The 50th anniversary tribute to the two Italian anarchists executed in 1927 is being presented at City University's Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street. Tonight, at 6:30, there is a screening of the Italian film "Sacco and Vanzetti" (1971).
MILAN, Oct. 12 The big guns of the fashion world rolled in today in full force, marking Milan's coming of age as an international fashion center rivaling Paris and New York.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 12 (UPI) The Conservatives under Sterling Lyon ousted Premier Edward Schreyer's eightyear-old New Democratic Party government with an upset victory in Manitoba elections yesterday.

MADRID, Oct. 12 (UPI) Bjorn Borg recovered from a first-set loss against Belus Prajoux of Chile and went on to a 3-6, 6-0, 6-1, victory in the third round of the $100,000 Madrid Grand Prix tennis tournament today.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 12 At about a quarter to 10 this morning Willis W. Ritter walked to work at the Federal Courthouse across the street from his apartment in the old Newhouse Hotel on Fourth South at the foot of Main Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct.12 Responding to persistent calls by developing countries that the industrialized nations of the West write off third-world debts. Sweden announced here today that it planned to cancel more than $200 million in debts owed by the governments of eight poor countries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 After 12 years of maneuvering and off-and-on negotiations, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and the Chicago Board of Education have agreed on a citywide plan for desegregating public school faculties and providing bilingual education for children whose English is deficient.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) The Japanese Government was asked to approve questionable payments a Japanese company made to the head of the Indonesian state oil company for a New York restaurant, United States records showed today.

Ruben F. Mettler has been elected chairman of the board and chief executive officer of TRW Inc., Cleveland, a diversified company engaged in the manufacture and design of technically oriented products.

Four teen-agers were throwing a Frisbee around near a Long Island shopping center on a recent night, "horsing around," in the words of one of them. Because it was after midnight, such horsing around attracted the police.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) The Senate adopted a resolution today calling for vigorous enforcement of laws against trade discrimination and other unfair competition by foreign steel producers that have an adverse effect on the American steel industry.
Museum stores have grown in the last two decades from purveyors of postcards to full-scale establishments carrying everything from art reproductions to tableware and furniture.

MONTREAL, Oct. 12 The highest rates of unemployement in Canada and Quebec since the Depression years of the 1930's were announced today, spurring further unrest here and heating the political warfare between the Federal and provincial Governments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 In a concession intended to break a three-month deadlock on Medicaid abortions, the House voted today to allow Medicaid financing for "medical procedures," such as dilation and curettage, for some victims of rape and incest.

Shipping company representatives from North Atlantic ports are scheduled to meet with Gulf Coast officials in New Orleans today for further discussions of a common approach in settling the 12day dock strike.
A self-proclaimed inveterate gambler from Queens won $1,000 a week for life yesterday in the New York State lottery, and a Pennsylvania hospital worker won the same amount in the New Jersey lottery.
J.P. Morgan Company said yesterday that operating earnings in the third quarter rose by 9.7 percent from a year earlier, to $54.98 million or $1.35 a share, from $50.11 million, or $1.24 a share.

Last July's blackout in New York City and Westchester County could have been shortened by four or five hours and the "backbone" of the system restored before 5 or 6 A.M., according to testimony yesterday to the city's special commission of inquiry. Power was out in some areas for as long as 26 hours although isolated sections started getting service within four hours after the blackout began at 9:36 P.M. on July 13.

When a convention becomes popular in tournament play it is not long before its practitioners experiment with modifications. This has recently been the fate of the "splinter bid," which allows a player to show a singleton or a void, a good fit with partner's suit and slam ambitions by jumping to a meaningless level.

THERE IS HOPE for those who believe they have brown thumbs. It's called an amaryllis bulb. With practically no care at all, the bulb will flower in about eight weeks. And if there is an occasional flop, it's usually because someone cared too much.
PHOENIX, Oct. 12 (AP) Tracy Austin, the 14-year-old Californian, toppled Francoise Durr, 6-0, 6-3, in the first round of the $75,000 Thunderbird tennis tournament tonight.
Arlane C. Danlos and Peter Mapes Dodge, both of New York, were married yesterday in Paris. The Episcopal ceremony was performed in the American Cathedral by Canon Frederick Northup.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 12 Police officers here began a "new and concentrated" investigation today into the murders and disappearance of three American diamond dealers after the charred body of a man believed to be a missing New York diamond merchant was found.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Short on funds and under attack because of service cutbacks, Amtrak, the embattled national rail passenger system, is telling Congress and the Administration to provide adequate funds for a properly operated system or to consider junking it altogether.

SAIGON, Vietnam You still fly here by Air Vietnam, but from North Vietnam only. The fuel-starved airline is forced to use those economical relics of the French colonial era, DC 4-'s. There was no co-pilot on our flight, and as the aircraft droned southward the flight attendant sat next to the pilot and sang Vietnamese songs over the intercom after serving a meal of green bananas, oranges and Russian brandy in plastic cups.

A fire raged through an abandoned elementary school in the Melrose area of the Bronx last night, causing no injuries but providing spectacular viewing for television fans of the game at Yankee Stadium.

In a little while Marina Oswald Porter would read a statement to a room full of reporters, reiterating her conviction that Lee Harvey Oswald, her husband at the time, had assassinated President John F. Kennedy and had done so alone.
Governor Carey, abandoning his own party's candidate in the November election, yesterday endorsed Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Republican-Liberal nominee for Manhattan Borough President.

FORT WORTH, TEX. ONE evening, when Martha Hyder was still doing major renovations on the house that was then a Victorian version of English Tudor, her husband, Elton, returned home and almost passed out.
The Eastman Kodak Company reported yesterday a 10 percent increase in its third-quarter earnings, marking the first rise this year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 The United States sent to Arab capitals today for their consideration the "working paper" for convening a Geneva conference on the Middle East. The paper was formally approved by Israel's Cabinet yesterday.

Los Angeles won Round Two of the baseball war between the cities last night when the Dodgers hit four home runs in Yankee Stadium, routed Catfish Hunter inside three innings, overpowered the Yankees by 6-1 and tied the World Series at one game apiece.

AT HIS BEST, John Guare does two things superlatively well. He is an authentic absurdist: That is, he speaks sense through comical and far-fetched distortions. It is not the rock-hard and intellectually spacious sense of a Ionesco, but it has a lovely lyrical and intuitive quality of its own.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 President Carter, sensing that public assessment of his first year in office largely rides on the outcome of his energy program in Congress, has ordered an all-out campaign to swing public opinion behind the Administration's efforts to rescue the program from the battering it has taken in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) The Senate voted today to extend a Federal pro gram of legal aid to the poor for three years and to allow the program's lawyers to engage in courtroom battles for school desegregation.

THAT MORRIS COTEL is a composer-pianist of unusual capabilities seems beyond question. For his recital at Carnegie Re cital Hall on Tuesday night, he had memorized a group of Scriabin Preludes, Schoenberg's Five Piano Pieces (Op. 23), Webern's Variations, Messiaen's "Modes de valeurs et d'intensites" and Xenakis's "Herma" to play as the first portion of the program. The second was given over to the premiere of Mr. Cotel's own Piano Sonata (1976).

Michael Blumenthal's tax package has been on the President's desk for a few weeks now, but Mr.Carter, though he was involved at many stages in its development, has not yet given it his bless ing. And Mr. Blumenthal has stressed that, no matter how many elements in the tax package may have leaked out, no one can count on any of them until the President sets down his seal of approval.

TRENTON, Oct. 12 Ten months after the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that minority quotas for state government jobs were illegal, Governor Byrne signed an executive order today directing the Civil Service Commission to, in effect, reinstitute quotas that emphasize promotions of women and minority-group people.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 12 Yemen's new military rulers imposed martial law today following the assassination yesterday of the President, Lieut. Col. Ibrahim al-Hamdi, and his brother, Lieut, Col. Abdullah al-Hamdi.
The rejection of entrants in wheelchairs for the New York City Marathon has stirred a controversy among officials and competitors affiliated with the Oct.23 race.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 The Carter Administration, surprised and frustrated by the continuing controversy in Western Europe over proposed United States development of a neutron bomb, has begun to question existing procedures for consulting with key allies on sensitive nuclear matters.

BARI, Italy, Oct. 12 European nations of the Atlantic alliance, declaring that cruise missiles are vital to the defense of the continent, expressed concern today to Defense Secretary Harold Brown about the Carter Administration's plans to limit the range of the weapons in strategicarms talks with the Soviet Union.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 (AP) Sol M. Linowitz, one of the United States negotiators of the Panama Canal treaties, says the accords will not eliminate the United States' right to keep the waterway open and neutral.

Four teen-agers were throwing a Frisbee around near a Long Island shopping center on a recent night, "horsing around," in the words of one of them. Because it was after midnight, such horsing around attracted the police.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the General Electric Company announced record third-quarter earnings yesterday a gain of 22.7 percent for Westinghouse and 18.1 percent for G.E.

MONTREAL, Oct. 12 (UPI) Guy Lafleur, the National Hockey League scoring champion, tallied two goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens opened their defense of the Stanley Cup with a 7-3 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

NEWARK, Oct. 12 The State Energy Commissioner, Joel R. Jacobson, today proposed a drastic overhauling of the electricity pricing structure in New Jersey that would eliminate discounts to highvolume residential customers while reducing the costs to low-volume users, usually the elderly and low-income families.

American and alien doctors who graduated from foreign medical schools and then trained in American hospitals fared far worse on certification tests than did doctors who graduated from American medical schools, according to results of a study being published in a medical journal today.

Hildegarde Halliday, who made her New York stage debut as a bit player in the, 1923. Theatre Guild production of "The Failures" and who subsequently became a principal performer in the three editions of "The Garrick Gaieties," died of cancer Monday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 75 years old.

New York City's Federally financed summer job program designed to provide jobs for youths and give them skills, instead made them unemployable by teaching them bad work habits, Representative Elizabeth Holtzman charged yesterday.

LONDON N NOV.1 the annual "Lyle Official Antiques Review" will be published for the eighth year. Within hours of its appearance, antiques dealers all over Britain will be rushing to change price labels on their stock.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) The Government agreed today to lift its $250 million loan guarantee to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation because of the company's improved financial position.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 After 12 years of maneuvering and off-and-on negotiations, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and the Chicago Board of Education have agreed on a citywide plan for desegregating public school faculties and providing bilingual education for children whose English is deficient.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) The number of serious crimes reported dropped 7 percent in the first six months of this year against the same time last year, but the number of reported rapes and assaults increased, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

WEST BERLIN Adolf Hitler seems an unlikely candi date to figure in a musical, but two young Hamburg composers have done the unthinkable and made the Nazi leader the star of their new rock opera. Fittingly entitled "Der Fuhrer" and designed for eventual stage production, the work has just come out in a tworecord version, produced for the Electrola Company by the composers, Walter Quintus and Lothar Siems, two rock musicians in their late 20's.

BUFFALO, Oct. 13 If near-misses counted for anything, the New York Islanders would have beaten the Buffalo Sabres easily tonight as both teams opened their National Hockey League seasons at Memorial Auditorium.
PARIS In the square around the assertively modernistic new Georges Pompidou National Center of Art and Culture on the Plateau de Beauborurg, a medieval tradition has been revived.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 President Carter said today that he and Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, the Panamanian leader, might have to issue a joint statement after their White House meeting tomorrow to clear up problems that have caused concern even to Senate supporters of the recently signed Panama Canal treaties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 President Carter tried to put new life into his badly mangled energy program today by angrily accusing the American oil industry of being uninterested in solutions to the nation's energy problems and intent on staging "the biggest rip-off in history."

JERUSALEM, Oct. 13 In a surprise move, Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan divulged at a public session of Parliament today the contents of the secret "working paper" outlining procedures for convening a Geneva peace conference on the Middle East.

ELLEN STEWART'S La Mama is an international treasury of theater. There are affiliated La Mamas around the world and the New York base (at 74A East Fourth Street) frequently plays hostess to visiting foreign companies and also to local companies whose roots extend to other cultures. Currently, Tisa Chang's Pan Asian Repertory Theater is in residence for a six-week season.

SAIGON, Vietman There are still an estimated 150,000 former South Vietnamese officers in the so-called reeducation camps, many living in conditions that are primitive and may be brutal, but the policy toward the south appears to remain one of reconciliation.

THE WHOLE FABRIC of the lives of American women has changed profoundly in the last decade as a result of the women's movement. Once an overwhelmingly urban and professional concern, feminism has touched women on all levels and in all corners of the country, however unconscious the level of communication. And as the pace of the movement has quickened and its ideals become clarified, the intensity of the opposition has grown.

Nationwide Mutual Insurance Companies, one of the major automobile, fire and commercial insurers in New Jersey, said yesterday that it would phase out its operations in the state because of chronic operating losses and no prospect for improvement in the foreseeable future.

THE DIVIDING LINES between dance, drama and music have been smudged almost beyond recognition by the mixed-media fever of the 1960's. Keith King and William Schimmel presented a concert of music and theater pieces Wednesday evening that was definitely of the hybrid variety. The concert was part of the "Loftdance Festival," featuring performances scattered throughout the SoHo area.

There was a time, just about a century ago, when Staten Island seemed to be well on its way to being the Newport of New York. Mansions and gracious villas dotted the shoreline, churches and boat clubs were built, and beautiful gardens created. Then came industrialization, pollution and the Hamptons, and the island's affair with the haut monde was over.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused Morris A. Shenker, operator of the Dunes Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, of fraudulentty obtaining nearly $29 million in loans for a California resort that closed last winter after losses of more than $20 million.

Robert Hacha, actor and director, died at his home in Pleasant Valley, N.Y., on Oct. 9. He was 54 years old.

WASHINGTON Her job is to represent a large out-of-town organization here, both on Capitol Hill and in the bureaucracy. She is charged with keeping watch over decisions involving hundreds of millions of dollars, money that can make the difference between success and disaster for her employer.

DETROIT, Oct. 13 Sales of new cars by the nation's big four car makers for the first 10-day period of October were up 15.1 percent from the level of sales for the same period a year ago, according to industry reports released here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 The Securities and Exchange Commission today settled charges against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and Lazard Freres Company stemming from the agency's six-year investigation into I.T.T.'s acquisition of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut yesterday ordered an investigation of a sharply criticized state police report that called for the re-indictment of Peter A. Reilly, the youth whose conviction for the slaying of his mother four years ago was overturned.

PARIS, Oct. 13 In seven months in office, Jacques Chirac, the first Mayor of Paris in more than a century, has offered ample vindication to critics who maintained that he would use the post as a trampoline for higher office and to sympathizers who hoped that he would give the French capital a measure of political autonomy from the national Government.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 13 The United States, seeking to cement relations with Belgrade, agreed today to expand military ties with the Government of President Tito.
MCA Inc., the big entertainment company, which has been sued by the Coca-Cola Company of Los Angeles after MCA made a $140 million takeover bid, filed a countersuit against the West Coast bottler.
Worries about rising short-term interest rates and an explosion in money-supply growth rocked the stock market yesterday and sent the Dow Jones industrial average to a two-year low.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 Senate leaders of both parties criticized President Carter's comments today on the reasons his energy program had been suffering setbacks and instead blamed the White House.
MADRID, Oct. 13 Four months after Spain proudly held its first free elections since 1936, the nation has begun to sink into a mood of despondency and uncertainty.
A worker was killed and three others suffered smoke-inhalation injuries yesterday when an explosion started a fire in a water tunnel under construction in the Bronx.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 13 Defense Minister Ezer Weizman said today he had sus pended negotiations with representatives of the Beirut Government concerning a settlement in southern Lebanon until fire across the border had subsided.

Federal officials coordinating the Carter Administration's plans for the South Bronx said yesterday that Washington's efforts would be based on existing programs and would not involve new legislative efforts.

The New York State Public Service Commission granted a temporary $245 million rate increase to the New York Telephone Company yesterday, but rejected its request to raise a pay-phone call to 20 cents from the current 10 cents.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 13 The brother of a missing New York diamond dealer today identified the charred body of a murder victim as that of his brother, Abraham Shafizadeh.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) Claude C. Wild Jr., former Washington lobbyist for the Gulf Oil Corporation, pleaded guilty yesterday to a misdemeanor charge of making an illegal corporate contribution to the 1972 election of Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 The industrial states of the northern Middle West have a host of natural advantages including abundant water, transportation and labor resources, and they were all recounted by speakers at a two-day conference on Midwest economic growth that ended here today.

TACHING, China Every day 3,000 to 4,000 workers and managers from every part of China arrive at this great oilfield to "learn from Taching" techniques that Chairman Hua Kuo-feng hopes will lead his country into the modern era.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 The Carter Administration was irritated today by the decision of Foreign Minister Dayan to divulge the Israel-American working paper.

SAN ANTONIO, Oct. 13 (AP) Charles Coody, returning to the Professional Golfers' Association tour after a three-week layoff, shot a sparkling seven-under-par 63 one stroke shy of the course record-and took the first round lead today in the $150,000 Texas open.

H. J. Kracke has been named executive director of the Publishers Association, of New York City, it was announced yesterday by John H. Mortimer, senior vice president of The New York Times, and Gregory L. Thornton, employee relations director of The Daily News.
