Ignoring its custom of informing the press and the Washington inflation monitors before raising prices, the aluminum industry has quietly notified its customers that prices on about a third of its products will increase by 4 percent next Monday.

The Chemical New York Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter operating earnings rose 16.2 percent from a year earlier, due in large part to continued growth in overseas lending, increased holdings of United States Government securities, a lower provision for possible loan losses and continuing cost control programs.

MIAMI, Oct. 13 Bernard Barker, the convicted Watergate burglar, has been hired here by the city as a building inspector. He was selected over two other applicants with higher Civil Service test scores and more construction experience.

GREENWICH VILLAGE'S loss is clearly the Upper East Side's gain. The charming, simple and original French restaurant, La Petite Ferme, an entrenched if minuscule "Village" landmark for the last seven years, moved uptown about six weeks ago to Lexington Avenue between 70th and 71st Streets, to slightly larger, if no less crowded, and noisy quarters.

Inside the majestic, Colonial-style auditorium of the New York County Lawyers' Association, 100 prominent lawyers and advocates for the poor gathered yesterday to celebrate the 10th anniversary of Community Action for Legal Services. They discussed the history, future and philosophical underpinnings of providing free legal services to the poor.

Manhattan-bound subway commuters, accustomed to having local political candidates accost them as they rush to board their morning trains, were somewhat surprised yesterday at the terminal of the IRT Flushing line in Queens when the hand thrust at them was that of Vice President Mondale.

Even in the realm of Italian grand opera, few enduring works of the lyric theater are as easily ridiculed as "La Fanciulla del West" ("The Girl of the Golden West"), the 67-year-old Puccini melodrama that the New York City Opera will stage Sunday night at Lincoln Center for the first time in the company's history.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 The light changed in this resort's main intersection today and an armored truck began to move when one of its twin back doors flew open and thousands of dollars in quarters were spilled out on New York and Atlantic Avenues.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 13 The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority formally approved today plans to build a 20,000-seat arena within the shadow of its lucrative year-old Meadowlands Race Track and Giants Stadium. IT IS NEARLY a year since the Joffrey Ballet was last in its home town, for its customary spring season was canceled because of the company's financial difficulties. Last night at the City Center 55th Street Theater it opened its new five-week season, a season that, incidentally, celebrates the 21st anniversary of the Joffrey Ballet.

Donald Slesinger, an analytic psychologist who once served as the dean of the University of Chicago Law School, died yesterday at the Carlsbad Hospital in California after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

FOR THE SECOND TIME in less than six months, Christie's and Sotheby Parke Bernet, the giants of the international artauction market, are competing in New York with major sales of Impressionist and modern art.

The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission has said that one of the S.E.C.'s main accusations against the banks that they sought to reduce their holdings of New York City securities in 1974-75 was a staff interpretation based on facts that might lead others to a different conclusion.

The first strike in the history of the Hartford Symphony Orchestra went into its third day yesterday with musicians picketing the offices of the Symphony Society of Greater Hartford, its owner. NEW HAVEN, Oct. 13 (AP) Lonnie McLucas, whose murder arrest with 13 other Black Panther workers became a cause for liberals in the late 1960's, was denied bail today in Federal District Court in Hartford. LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 Two thousand eight hundred twenty-five highway miles from where it started in the South Bronx, the big rounders tournament proceeds tomorrow in this earthly paradise. STOCKHOLM, Oct. 13 Three Americans, including a woman from the Bronx, were awarded the 1977 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine today for their pioneering research in the role of hormones in the chemistry of the human body.

Officials of Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipping companies met in New Orleans yesterday in a new attempt to devise a formula for settling the 13-day-old dock strike that has tied up 95 ships and sharply curtailed import and export activity.

Autumn time, and the livin' is easier, thanks to the return of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. This admired organization, now in its ninth year, has as usual assembled some of the best musicians around, worked up a series of interesting programs, and is performing everything with style and polish.

TOKYO, Oct. 14 Fueled by heavy speculation at home and abroad as well as continued strongly favorable trade reports for Japan, the yen today surged to its highest value here since the end of World War II.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 14 From several light, airy rooms in her modest one-story home here, former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is working hard to engineer a political comeback.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 Gabe Paul, executive producer of the Yankees' smash hit soap opera, spoke out today in support of controversy and Manager Billy Martin, but stopped short of saying that the Yankees would bring Martin back for another year as a co-star in the continuing saga.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (Reuter) The United States today gave the Soviet Union a copy of the United States-Israeli "working paper" on steps to reconvene the Middle East peace conference at Geneva, the State Department announced.

QUIDI VIDI, Newfoundland A broad smile creased Jim Ring's sunreddened fisherman's face as he helped heave buckets of live squid from his boat to a dock in this tiny fishing village, an enclave in the Newfoundland capital city of St. John's.
Belmont Park's 42-day meeting comes to a close this afternoon with the $300,000 added Jockey Gold Cup and the $125,000 added Champagne featuring the richest program in the history of American racing.

BURBANK, Calif., Oct. 14 Strikes against the Lockheed Corporation here and the Boeing Company in three cities threaten to halt much of the nation's output of airliners just when the slumping aerospace industry has been enjoying a resurgence of orders for jet transports.

The season's rains have been good for something: wild mushrooms. And while mushroom lovers are delighted that the moist weather has produced a larger than average crop, area mycologists are issuing warnings against the picking and eating of wild mushrooms by the uneducated.

LONDON, Oct. 14 Middle-aged Americans used to loutishness in the young and famous may find His Royal Highness, the Prince of Wales, too good to be true when he arrives in Chicago Tuesday to begin a 13-day, 10-city visit to the United States.
Clay on the shores of ancient seas may have played an important role in the origin of life on Earth, scientists said yesterday.

Viewers of "60 Minutes" on CBS-TV at 7 o'clock tomorrow night will see three middle-aged men who had been crippled by heart disease transformed back to active, working, seemingly healthy and decidedly happy individuals by four weeks of a rigid diet and exercise program.

CAIRO, Oct. 14 (AP) An Egyptian newspaper said today the assassins of the Yemeni chief of state, Lieut. Col. Ibrahim al-Hamdi, were three men who disguised themselves as women to elude security guards; Yemeni tradition forbids stopping women on the street for identity checks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill announced today the appointment of Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of Brooklyn, as chairman of a new select committee on population. Mr. Scheuer was the principal sponsor of a resolution, passed by the House Sept. 28, to set up the new committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) The House and Senate conferes agreed today to raise the nation's minimum wage to $3.35 an hour by 1981 from the current $2.30. The current minimum would go to $2.65 an hour next Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) John D. Ehrlichman today was granted a reduction in his sentence for the "plumbers" break-in and may leave Federal prison in two weeks.

Christopher Hampton, the talented young British playwright, has indicated that his play "Treats," at the Hudson Guild Theater, was written as a reaction to "A Doll's House." His heroine, unlike Nora, does not get away from her impossible domestic situation. She is trapped, and her entrapment becomes a call to arms to victimized and self-victimizing women. "Treats" could be considered a feminist play written from the male point of view.

A gale pounded the East Coast yesterday with 50-mile-an-hour winds and raised eight-foot tides that caused flooding in many areas, forcing the removal of residents from some New Jersey shore communities.

One of the serendipitous advantages of using the Lightner slam double is that it prevents players from making foolish doubles based on general strength. If the double means that an unusual lead is required, normally in dummy's suit, a player cannot be tempted into doubling because he has some high cards and is hoping for a one-trick defeat. WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP)--Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that although the behavior of the nation's oil companies is unsatisfactory, he does not think it would be appropriate to use the threat of divestiture "as a club."

Anne Jordan Cashin, a psychologist at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, was married yesterday at Harvard University's Memorial Church, in Cambridge, Mass., to Dr. Paul David Goldenheim, a resident in internal medicine at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston.

BONN, Oct. 16--The Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt refused today to meet the demands of the two sets of terrorists who have hijacked an airliner with 87 hostages and who have kidnapped a prominent West German busi nessman.

Rosenbluth of Valley Stream, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Edward Saltz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Saltz of Mount Vernon, N. Y. Rabbi Arnold Marans performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I. Cantor David Abikhzer assisted.

LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP)--An estimated 2,000 people were at Westminster Cathedral today for a memorial mass for Bing Crosby, the entertainer who died Friday in Spain.

Carl Ally Inc. has picked up its fourth new account since May, Dunkin' Donuts of America. The Randolph, Mass., company, which has over 900 mostly franchised locations, is spending $2.7 million on national advertising this year and says it expects to increase the budget substantially in 1978.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 16 (AP)-- The Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Johnstown area coal mines will be closed indefinitely starting tomorrow, adding to a Cambria County unemployment rate that has risen to 17 percent because of summer flooding.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 16--Today in a small chapel on the campus of Yale University, 200 people gathered to pay tribute to Bonnie Joan Garland, the 20-yearold Yale student who was slain on July 7 as she slept in her parents' home in Scarsdale, N.Y.

ANTWERP, Belgium--Diamonds may be a woman's best friend, but they also make for strange bedfellows. For the first time in its 34-year-old history, the New York City Opera has staged Puccini's "La Fanciulla del West." The new production was unveiled last night at the New York State Theater, giving local audiences once again the chance to sample Puccini's ideas about the Wild West. Or, one should say, David Belasco's ideas, for the libretto was substantially derived from his smash hit of the early 1900's, "The Girl of the Golden West."

The gold rush continued yesterday in the futures and cash markets for bullion. On New York's Commodity Exchange, all deliveries rose $2 an ounce, with the expiring October contract closing at $162.60 an ounce.

In a surprise move, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced plans for a public offering around Nov. 9 of 12 million common shares, an action valued at more than $700 million.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 President Carter told Democratic House conferees on the energy bill today that he would make "no deals" to compromise his energy stands to win support from Senate conferees, Congressmen at the meeting said.

No. 745 FIFTH AVENUE, one of the city's more pleasing midtown office structures, not long ago began to sport blaz ing yellow window shades on a few of its upper floors. They followed by a short time the appearance of a new corporate logo and canopy in front of another fine Manhattan office building of the 1930's, 1230 Avenue of the Americas at Rockefeller Center.

TRENTON, Oct. 19 The New Jersey Supreme Court, in its first definitive opinion on the state's so-called Sunshine Law, ruled today that to comply "substantially" with the law, which requires government to be in the open, is not sufficient, and that it had to be strictly observed.

Anthony L. Conrad, former board chairman of the RCA Corporation, has been ordered to appear at a state hearing in Baltimore next month that will decide whether to grant a New York extradition request, New York State's Assistant Attorney General, Moses Weintraub, said here yesterday.

Unusual suit plays are, self-evidently, quite rare. For two players to have an opportunity to make an unusual play on the same trick happens once in a blue moon. And for three players to have such an opportunity on the same trick could be unique. But it happened in the recent Summer Nationals in Chicago on the diagramed deal.
LEGHORN, Italy, Oct. 19 (Reuters) Policemen fought a running battle today with four leftist guerrillas who tried to kidnap the son of a wealthy shipbuilder in this Italian port, the police said.

STEVEN DE GROOTE entered a piano competition the other day and won not only the first prize of $10,000, but also two years of unemployment insurance. In the next two years, the South African-born musician will play concerts and recitals all around the world as part of the spoils he earned by capturing the Fifth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition in Fort Worth.

Doctors at a small but growing number of medical centers in this country and elsewhere are now diagnosing some cardiac problems by examining the heart for an unlimited period of time with ultrasound. Other physicians are using the technique, which "sees" with sound, to examine the fetus in the womb for diagnostic and research purposes.

In the jet age, people travel light and leave their troubles at home preferably in a trunk. Whether in gleaming chrome or wicker or standard black, the trunk hasn't packed it in as a useful item. In fact, the welltraveled truck has come home to roost, enjoying a new lease on life as a space saver that can double as a table.
"Housewife! Superstar!!," the one-man show by the Australian comedian Barry Humphries, gives new depths to the phrase "Down Under." It is abysmal.

When St. Francis Prep meets Holy Cross High at Flushing Memorial Field in Queens Saturday, the St. Francis coach will have "the best lineman on the team" back in the lineup. But it took a ruling from the city Department of Health to get Larry Carbone back on St. Francis's freshman team, even though he is its captain, because Larry has only one arm.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The longawaited hearings by the House ethics committee on its Korean investigation got off to a slow start this afternoon when witnesses went over previous evidence of the South Korean Government's covert plans to influence the American Congress.

The perils of winter, strikes and municipal bankruptcy will chill us soon enough, but put it all aside. Let the Dodgers wait till next year; let next year wait. The Yankees have given us much to celebrate and to savor:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI) The National Collegiate Athletic Association objected today to proposed legislation aimed at making the United States Olympic Committee the coordinator for all domestic sports and providing ways to resolve disputes between sports organizations.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., Oct. 19 (AP) A bus commandeered by several state prison inmates ran through three police roadblocks today before being stopped at a fourth when shots were fired at the bus, the authorities said.

Governor Carey said yesterday that a restructuring of the state's Emergency Financial Control Board, the fiscal monitor for New York City, might be too "cumbersome" for a special legislative session and, in any case, should wait for word from the new city administration.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (Reuters) A Commonwealth committee today recommended to the 35 member governments that South Africa be asked for effective guarantees that petroleum products it imported would not be exported to Rhodesia.
MOSCOW, Oct. 19 The 18-year-old son of Vladimir Slepak, a prominent dissident, refused induction into the Soviet Army today, thereby risking a three-year prison sentence.

Former president Gerald R. Ford yesterday urged a $20 billion to $25 billion annual tax cut and called on the Carter Administration to seek action on it immediately, rather than wait until Congress reconvenes next January.

A Federal Environmental Protection Agency plan to allow six large chemical plants to continue dumping their wastes in the Atlantic Ocean off New York and New Jersey drew virtually no opposition at a public hearing yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 19 Embarrassed medical officials here reversed an earlier autopsy finding tonight and said that the missing New York diamond dealer. Abraham Shafizadeh, had indeed been shot four times and his body deliberately set afire last July.

An Israeli witness in tightly guarded immigration hearing room in Manhattan pointed out a silent, bespectacled 73-yearold Long Island man yesterday as the former Latvian guard he said he saw beating Jews at the Riga ghetto in the summer of 1941.
FRANKFURT, Oct. 19 A ruse spared the lives of the hostages rescued by West German commandos yesterday from a hijacked plane in Somalia, an American woman said here today.
JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 19 Following is the text of Justice Minister James T. Kruger's statement on bannings and detentions of Government opponents issued today.

JAKARTA, Oct. 19 (Reuters) The Indonesian Government seemed unmoved today by Amnesty International's announcement that it plans to begin a worldwide campaign for the immediate release of what the organization said were Indonesia's 100,000 political prisoners.

SILVER, SCREENINGS A real bargain for movie buffs is tomorrow's free midtown screening of "Reunion in Vienna" (1933), adapted from Robert E. Sherwood's Broadway hit, with John Barrymore and Diana Wynyard in the roles originated by Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 19 The Meadowlands' stewards tonight ordered $40,987 in refunds on the winner of the seventh race, Brushnell, because the 6-year-old gelding had gained "an unfair advantage" at the start.

A Federal grand jury in San Francisco yesterday returned a 382-count indictment against Deak Company of California, the West Coast arm of the currency exchange and investment banking firm. A former vice president of Deak of California was also named in the indictment.

Clifford L. Porter, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Cahill Gordon Reindel and a leading tax authority, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 61 years old and lived in Sands Point, L.I., after making his home for many years in Fort Washington, L.I.
JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 19 Following is a partial list of organizations banned by the South African Government and of individuals banned or detained. A full list was not released.

Broadway, for nearly a mile from Bowling Green to City Hall, was a huge smile and triumphal shout yesterday as hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers staged one of the city's most memorable tickertape parades to honor the New York Yankees for their first World Series victory in 15 years.

Pottery used to be a hobby for David Heger, while he was teaching Hebrew at the Dalton School. When the school cut down its language department and left him without a job, his hobby was a natural thing to turn to as a second career. Friends encouraged him to show his pottery to stores, and almost immediately he was launched. Mr. Heger's clay baskets, bowls and other containers are all taken from nature.
JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 19 The telephone rang in Percy Qoboza's tiny bungaslow in Soweto at 5:25 A.M. today.
The Dow Chemical Company, the nation's third-largest chemical compny, reported yesterday a 13.4 percent drop on third-quarter earnings 'despite an 11 percent sales increase.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 Diplomats and United Nations officials moved here today to try to galvanize the General Assembly to take more stringent measures against air piracy and the taking of hostages.

After a 19-month battle, the supersonic Concorde airliner made its maiden flight into New York yesterday with modest noise, no organized demonstrators to greet it and nonpaying officials and test teams as its only passengers.

Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the Los Angeles Lakers' 7-foot-2-inch center and the National Basketball Association's most valuable player in five of his eight pro seasons, suffered a fractured bone in his right hand Tuesday night. The injury occurred when Abdul-Jabbar hit and floored Kent eBnson, the Milwaukee Bucks' 6-11 center, in the first period of the game.

Three weeks after the body of Pinchos Jaroslawicz was found stuffed in a box in the Manhattan office of a diamondcutter, New York City detectives are still trying to unravel with no reported success so far the mystery of who killed the 25-year-old diamond broker and what happened to the $1 million in gems he was carrying.
MEMPHIS, Oct. 19 (AP) Ten drugs were present in Elvis Presley's bloodstream when he died in August and they probably contributed to his death, a published report said today.
The Trailways bus network said today it would begin testing movies for passengers on long-distance bus trips.

Both Air France and British Airways are planning big newspaper advertising efforts to mark the inauguration of the Concorde's commercial service to New York.

A business executive accustomed to making multimillion-dollar decisions on the basis of consumer research would have left the two-day annual conference of the Advertising Research Foundation rather shaken. Just too much honest talk about error and the need for a code of ethics.

Governor Carey's proposal to issue $750 million in bonds to promote economic development was ruled unconstitutionally broad and ordered off the ballot yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice in Albany.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The Carter Administration said today that it was "deeply disturbed" about the crackdown by the South African Government on blacks and their supporters and warned that the latest actions had "implications" for future South African relations with the United States.

Imports of crude oil rose in the week ended Oct. 14, to 6.6 million barrels a day against 6.2 million barrels a day in the preceding week, according to the latest weekly supply statistics released by the American Petroleum Institute. MINEOLA, L.I, Oct. 19 Emergency transportation plans to help Long Island Rail Road commuters in the event of a strike within the next few days were announced today by officials of Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The Commerce Department reported today that the nation's economic activity slowed markedly in the third quarter. Pinball machines those light-up, flipper-clicking, bell-ringing, boldly painted descendants of bagatelle have lately been upgraded in two ways here: now they are legal and some call them art.

For years Ohrbach's has been known for its line-for-line copies of European couture styles for women. Now it is adapting the process for men's clothes. The custom tailor chosen is Angelo Litrico of Rome and the styles are not the kind that fade into the woodwork.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 20 (AP) Walt Frazier, the epitome of coolness under pressure when he played with the New York Knicks, fired a fourth-quarter surge tonight and led the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 107-104 National Basketball Association victory over the New Orleans Jazz.
Stock prices staged a mild recovery yesterday afternoon amid Wall Street estimates that weekly money-supply figures would show a decline after soaring $4.9 billion in the preceding reporting week.

MOGADISHU, Somalia, Oct. 20 (AP) The people of this hot and humid captal on the Indian Ocean are jubilant over their Government's part in rescuing 86 hostages from a hijacked Lufthansa jet three days ago. But the jubilation is tempered by fear of terrorist revenge.

MANILA, Oct. 20 A cease-fire with Moslem rebels in the southern Philippines deteriorated further today as hundreds of rebels, armed with mortars and rockets, attacked troops on Mindanao island's Zamboanga Peninsula, according to a Government report.

NEWARK, Oct. 20 Joel R. Jacobson, the State Energy Commissioner, called today for suspension of plans for a floating nuclear power plant off the New Jersey coast near Atlantic City until "serious and unresolved" safety questions were answered by the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Agency.

Inco Ltd., which produces about half of the non-Communist world's supplies of nickel, reported yesterday that its third-quarter earnings plunged 63.3 percent and that its quarterly dividend would be cut to 20 cents a share on the class A and tax-deferred B stocks from the 35 cents paid in the last three years.

Mario M. Cuomo, appeared in the press room at City Hall yesterday to detail what he said were "major policy difference" separating him from the Democratic nominee for Mayor, of New York City, Representative Edward I. Koch.

Commissioner Lawrence F. O'Brien, who abhors violence in the National Basketball Association, levied a record $5,000 fine yesterday against Kareem Abdul-Jabbar for punching Kent Benson to the floor in the league's opening night on Tuesday.
A Long Island woman who refused to deplete her children's savings and odd-job earnings to become eligible for welfare will not have to face any more legal battles for her welfare rights.

THE REASSESSMENT of America's musical culture that pro duced such streams of evidence during the Bicentennial observances last year continues, thanks to such enterprises as the Alliance for American Song, which presented its first program on Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital hall.

JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 20 Prime Minister John Vorster said today that any move by the United States to review its relations with South Africa because of the crackdown on blacks was irrelevant since he was more concerned with internal security than with international standing.

When the boys from down the block come visiting on Sunday, Holy Cross will be ready. The Knights have a date with their Queens rivals, St. Francis Prep, Sunday at 1:30 P.M. and for fans of the two teams, pro football may as
SARASOTA, Fla., Oct. 10 (AP) Directors of the American Society of Newspaper Editors voted here today to condemn the suppression of three South African newspapers and the detention of an editor.

An electrical power failure stopped all train service into and out of Pennsylvania Station for four hours yesterday morning, delaying 90,000 rush-hour commuters and several thousand more longdistance riders who came from points as far away as Montreal.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 21 Thailand's military, junta, in a coup that met no resistance, last night deposed the civilian Government it installed after a coup a year ago.

ATLANTA, Oct. 20 An alleged bank robber who hijacked a Frontier Airlines jet from Nebraska to Atlanta shot himself to death aboard the aircraft here tonight after releasing the last of his hostages unharmed.

The National Steel Corporation, with headquarters in Pittsburgh, has filed a complaint about dumping of steel with the Treasury. National charges manufacturers from six European nations are dumping cold-rolled and galvanized-steel sheets in the United States "at less than fair value." The United States company said it was charging that the dumping margins are as high as 47 percent on galvanized sheets and as high as 43.5 percent on cold-rolled sheets.

THE POLITICALLY oriented dance that was so much a part of the 1930's has virtually ceased to exist in the modern dance world. An interesting exception was "At That Point in Time," wihch Pearl Lang choreographed in the spring and summer of 1974, when Watergate became a painfully familiar locale. She revived it this season and presented the work Wednesday evening at the Entermedia Theater.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 20 (AP) Six schools have formed a new basketball league that will be called the Big Apple Conference, officials at Marist College said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 The House and Senate conferees on energy legislation reached their first significant agreements today, but bypassed enough difficult decisions on the way to create a bulging agenda for future weeks.

PHOENIX, Oct. 20 Wesley Bolin, a 68year-old lifetime Democrat, was sworn in today as Arizona's 15th Governor, replacing Gov. Raul H. Castro, who was sworn in today in Washington as United States Ambassador to Argentina.

The Port of Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday the formation of a three-member panel to advise the agency on the possible "advance-refunding" of up to all its $1.9 billion in outstanding bonds.

The scene seems culled from a space movie a herd of humans penned in by the imposing towers and rows of metal on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. But in reality, it is the start of the New York City Marathon.
Members of the executive board of the International Longshoremen's Association were reported yesterday to be considering a possble expansion of the 20-day dock strike.

OTTAWA, Oct. 20 Finance Minister Jean Chretien announced tonight a $700 million income tax cut and the phasing out of the controversial wage and price controls next year, among other steps to revive the faltering Canadian economy.

LONDON, Oct. 20 An American lunch guest swallowed the last of his wine and rose to leave the bank's elegant private dining room. As he did so, one of his six hosts gestured toward the end of the table.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 20 The Jet coach"s eyes narrowed today when someone mentioned the Oakland Raiders.
It may be getting easier for the home buyer in New York State to get a low down-payment mortgage.

Philip J. Brennan, a statistician in the business/financial news department of The New York Times and a former international vice president of The Newspaper Guild, died early yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital following a short illness. He was 63 years old.

SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 20 After four days of intensive negotiations, the United States and South Korea failed to reach agreement today and broke off talks on an American interrogation of Tongsun Park, the current central figure in an alleged influence-buying scandal involving Congress.

The supersonic Concorde airliner, in its first takeoff from Kennedy International Airport, met the legal noise limit by a wide margin yesterday, according to the . Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. And Federal officials said it proved slightly quieter than some subsonic jets when it came back in to land three hours later.

Because of an editing error, an article in The Times Wednesday about the cleanup of PCB's from the Hudson River, incorrectly identified the General Electric Company as responsible for removal of a hydroelectric dam near Fort Edward, N.Y. The dam was removed by the Niagara-Mohawk Power Corporation.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 20 Prime Minister Menahem Begin's Likud-led coalition Government was assured today of a comfortable and broad-based majority with the addition of a new political party.

MILL VALLEY, Calif., Oct. 20 (AP) Jenifer White, a newsman's wife who brought the first word to thousands of Americans during World War II of their relatives in Manila's Santo Tomas internment camp, died yesterday of cancer. She was 65.

INAUGURATED by one disaster (the Crash), the era of the 1930's staggered through another (the Depression) only to be terminated by a third (World War II). Small wonder that its limp esthetic production has been eclipsed by the rowdier movement of Abstract Expressionism. Though the period is now enjoying a revival of interest, its art is proving no less difficult to reassess.

SRIMATI M.S. SUBBULAKSHMI is not well known in this coun try. She hasn't toured here since 1966, and her records are only Indian imports. That explains why, except for the entire Indian diplomatic community from Washington and New York and such Indian celebrities as Ravi Shankar, Miss Subbulakshmi's re cital Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall was sparsely attended. But for those who were there, it was one of the finest concerts in recent memory.
The latest wrinkle in money market funds produces variable interest income depending upon what is happening in the money market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20?The Carter Administration sought today to resolve a classic confrontation between environmentalists and Alaska Eskimos over the hunting of bowhead whales, but the proposed solution elicited a charge from the Eskimos that they had been "betrayed."
In an unusual move, the White House yesterday warned the Federal Reserve Board without addressing it directly against raising interest rates and thus hurting the economy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 The United States is preparing to open pivotal negotiations next week designed to end the 30-year trusteeship over the Pacific islands of Micronesia and give it a wide degree of independence.

Joseph McNevin, who is now 85 years old, knows Charlotte Street, the South Bronx block where President Carter took a walk, as it was in the 1920's, a street of fine brick apartment houses, some with elevators, with embossed tin and carved-granite cornices, wroughtiron stair rails, polished-brass mailboxes and marble lobbies.

MANILA, Oct. 20 Experts from five countries are nervously pacing around the Peninsula Hotel here today, taking stock of the rivals they will have to face during the next week in search of the world team title, symbolized by the Bermuda Bowl.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) Two Filipino dissidents who escaped from a Manila prison three weeks ago urged the United States today to end military assistance to the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

In a dingy, makeshift courtroom on the sixth floor of the Kings County Psychiatric Center yesterday, David R. Berkowitz, accused of being the .44-caliber killer, contended that not he, but evil demons commanding his body, had carried out six murders with which he has been charged.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) Though he was at his Minnesota home and unable to attend, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey was the talk of the party tonight as a long line of friends and dignitaries gathered to salute his career in public service. Senator Humphrey has not returned to Washington since surgeons discovered inoperable cancer on Aug. 18.

STUTTGART, West Germany, Oct. 20 (Reuters) A search in a top-security prison here has shown that three guerrilla leaders conversed through a communications system hidden behind the walls, prison officials said today.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa Human rights is a complex issue that is in danger of becoming just a politically useful slogan. I should personally be very distressed to see this valuable concept reduced to sanctimonious political cant.

I have not to date come across any responsible black leader who has advanced the theory that whites are expendable and must be thrown into the sea. We have, on the contrary, over the years emphasized that whites are South Africans and have the right to exist in a common fatherland; and that all of us, around a conference table, must devise a formula acceptable for future co-existence.

NEWARK, Oct. 20 Sounding very much like a candidate himself, former President Gerald R. Ford put in a full day of campaigning in North Jersey for the state's Republican choice for Governor, Senator Raymond H. Bateman; called Governor Byrne's record "dismal" and found time to take jabs at the Carter Administration.
The deadline for President Carter's decision on whom he wants to preside over the nation's monetary policy after next January is fast approaching without any indication of his choice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Last-minute appeals by the House Speaker and a powerful committee chairman reversed an impending rebuff to President Carter today and persuaded a tumultuous House not to reinstate $1.4 billion for the B-1 bomber.

Dr. Chiang Yee, an author, poet, painter and professor emeritus of Chinese at Columbia University, died last Monday in Peking during an extended visit to China, his homeland, according to a Columbia spokesman. He was 74 years old and lived at 520 West 123d Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 All morning long, the White House guards were busy opening and closing the iron gates, leaning through the windows of the big cars to check credentials, and pointing helpfully up the long asphalt drive to the West Wing where the string of arriving senators had appointments today with the President of the United States.

Congress is rushing ahead to a new retirement law and the country had better pay close attention. Hardly anyone can be sure about the consequences of the pending act, portions of which came into being without even a committee hearing.
The kiddie corps will compete with 5,000 other runners in Sunday's New York City Marathon, led by 8-yearold Wesley, Paul of Columbia, Mo.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 20 Tomorrow was the day when Cleveland's schools were scheduled to close for lack of money unless either a Federal court or the State Legislature did something to prevent it.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd asked the Civilian Complaint Review Board yesterday to investigate charges that city policemen used excessive force in their efforts to control spectators who surged onto the field after Tuesday night's deciding World Series game at Yankee Stadium.

Joseph McNevin, who is now 85 years old, knows Charlotte Street, the South Bronx block where President Carter took a walk, as it was in the 1920's, a street of fine brick apartment houses, some with elevators, with embossed tin and carved-granite cornices, wrought-iron stair rails, polished-brass mailboxes and marble lobbies.
Mrs. Barbara M. Dille is an innovative obedience expert responsible for the instruction of approximately 3,000 dogs over the last 15 years in the Westchester area.

The 150th anniversary of Ludwig von Beethoven's death will be marked with a chamber-music concert at 8 P.M. on Sunday at Sarah Lawrence College. On the program will be Beethoven's Duo for Clarinet and Bassoon, Serenade for Strings, and Septet in E flat (Op. 20).

The Parachute Jump, which became a Coney Island fixture after a successful run at the 1939 World's Fair and which has become a rusty hulk after years of disuse, moved a step closer to demolition yesterday when the Board of Estimate refused to make it a city landmark.

The image of women, as seen through the eyes of male artists of the 19th and early 20th centuries, is the focus of a free exhibition of prints opening Sunday at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts in Roslyn, L.I.
BUFFALO, Oct. 20 Bruce L. Beyer, who fled the country in a Vietnam War protest seven years ago, came home today for the first time in seven years.

MOSCOW, Oct. 20 Five years after the United States and the Soviet Union inaugurated a new era in trade relations, business is stagnating, American companies have lost interest in opening new branch offices here and the expectations for the future are modest, if not yet pessimistic.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Oct. 20 (AP) Jerry Pate, the 1976-United States Open champion who has been hampered by an injury this year, fired a six-underpar 64 today and took a one-stroke lead after the first round of the $125,000 Southern open golf tournament. Dave Eichelberger was one stroke back at 65.
Bond prices declined moderately late yesterday afternoon as traders became disappointed that the money supply this week remained unchanged instead of declining, as much as Wall Street had expected.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) The Supreme Court today granted a request from oil companies that own the transAlaska pipeline to temporarily charge rates higher than those set by the Government for use of the 800-mile line.
A strike on the Long Island Rail Road today was averted yesterday when its unions announced a "number of major new developments" in their stalled contract negotiations.
George Lascu, the 82-year-old superintendent at 1500 Boston Road, the only apartment house in the Charlotte Street neighborhood in which people still live, would not dream of being anywhere else.

NEWARK, Oct. 20 Sounding very much like a candidate himself, former President Gerald R. Ford put in a full day of campaigning in North Jersey for the state's Republican choice for Governor, Senator Raymond H. Batsman, called Governor Byrne's record "dismal" and found time to take jabs at the Carter Administration.

December gold futures, which have fluctuated widely recently, jumped ahead more than $2 an ounce yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. The December contract closed at $162 an ounce, up from $160 1/5 on Wednesday.

ASTAGE representation of Dracula is a challenge not so much to modern performers as to the modern audience. It comes to us with a stake through its heart, beyond real revival although capable of useful adornment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 The white-winged guan, a bird believed extinct for a century, has been sighted in northwestern Peru, it was announced here today, and the American ornithologist who found it says that there may be several hundred of the birds in Peru and perhaps some in Ecuador.

TOKYO, Oct. 20 (AP) A United States tennis team of four men and four women defeated a Chinese squad by 7-1 in Peking today, the official Hsinhua news agency reported. Four matches in Peking Stadium ended in ties, Hsinhua said.

ROME, Oct. 20 Left-wing demonstrators fired pistol shots and threw firebombs at riot policemen outside Rome University tonight after several thousand students had gathered there to honor the memory of three German terrorists found dead in their prison cells in Stuttgart, West Germany, yesterday.
In an unusual move, the White House yesterday warned the Federal Reserve Board without addressing it directly against raising interest rates and thus hurting the economy.

Those who take their football by television will get a break on Sunday when the top game of the day will be seen in the New York area for a change. Channel 4 will televise Baltimore at New England starting at 4 P.M., and
Dr. Harry Helson died Oct. 13 in Berkeley, Calif., where he had retired after 50 years as a psychologist, author and educator. He was 79 years old.

Philip J. Fitzpatrick, a lawyer who was chairman of the Richmond County Republican. Party from 1973 until last month, when he annouced that he would not seek a third term, was indicted yesterday on charges of perjury.
LONDON, Oct. 20 (Reuters) A judge awarded a San Diego psychologist $81,000 as a result of injuries suffered in an accident during a 1974 bus tour of Britain.

JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 20 A few hours before the South African Government closed Percy Qoboza's newspaper and took him to jail, he and the editor of another major newspaper were consoling each other over the bind in

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) Pan American World Airways said today it had proposed cutting the cost of transPacific travel in half next year by introducing in that area the same sort of budget fares now offered between New York and London.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 African countries, protesting the crackdown against blacks in South Africa, requested today an urgent meeting of the Security Council. The Council will meet Monday or Tuesday on the request made on behalf of the 49 African countries by Mahmoud Mestiri of Tunisia.

PEOPLE TALK often about "risk" in rock-and roll, but risk can take various forms. Sometimes it means the projec tion of the illusion (however real) of a life lived at the edge. The risk in that case means a personal image that suggests something dangerous and out of the ordinary, a life perilously close to death.

McCOMB, Miss., Oct. 20 (AP) Six persons were killed when a twin-engine airplane carrying about 25 persons, including members of the rock band Lynyrd Skynyrd, crashed in a swampy area of southwestern Mississippi tonight, medical officials here said.
WASHINGTON, Oct 20 (Reuter) Defense Secretary Harold Brown has tentatvely approved a one-third cut in Navy shipbuilding plans for the next five years, Government sources said today.

FRANKFURT THERE WERE two fairs-one was unannounced held at the Frankfurt International "Buchmesse" (the German word for book fair) that wound up here this week. The big official one brought together the world's publishers. The unofficial one mirrored the world's problems.

Beginning this weekend, Sundays at 4 P.M. will be a family affair at the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., at Lexington Avenue. A five-part concert-discussion series, "Instruments on Trial," invites parents and children to explore the world of musical instruments with performers, who will discuss their instruments after each hourlong concert.
For a man whose Princeton team faces Harvard, the undefeated Ivy League leader, tomorrow in Cambridge, Mass., Coach Bob Casciola seems to have not lost his sense of humor.
Three weeks ago, while he was still president of CBS-TV, Robert J. Wussler broke with convention, and shocked the industry by attacking a rival network's programming ABC's as "junk."

WHEN AMERICAN FORCES began operating in the New Hebrides during World War II in the South Pacific, they were warned that those inhabiting the mountainous jungles of Malekula Island were "savage and treacherous," occasionally resorting to cannibalism. Those of us who repeatedly sailed past that island, gazing at its savage, volcanic landscape, were moved by a special awe and curiosity.
Is major league baseball regaining "No. 1 status" as a spectator sport that professional football has held in recent years?

Did you ever wonder where all those1930's gangsters and wayward Depression-era kids really went when they were sent "up the river"? Why didn't they go down the river or simply get "sent over," the way Sam Spade sent Brigit O'Shaughnessy over in "The Maltese Falcon"?
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) Congress today sent President Carter legislation raising the current minimum wage of $2.30 an hour to $2.65 in January. Five million workers would benefit from this.
BONN, Oct. 20 Officials began today what they termed the greatest dragnet in West Germany's 33-year history to track down those implicated in a series of recent terrorist crimes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 The Environmental Protection Agency notified 11 Federal agencies today that they must take immediate action to end air and water pollution at their facilities around the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Representative Edward I. Koch, Democratic nominee for Mayor of New York, went to see President Carter this morning to ask for a White House "coordinator" of steppedup Federal action to help the South Bronx and to obtain some kind words in support of his own campaign.

ATLANTA, Oct. 20 An alleged bank robber who hijacked a Frontier Airlines jet from Nebraska to Atlanta in an effort to free a friend from prison shot himself to death aboard the aircraft here tonight after releasing the last of his hostages unharmed.

AFTER THREE DAYS of major modern art sales here, both Sotheby Parke Bernet as well as Christie, Manson Woods will switch gears today to focus on earlier material including autographs and manuscripts as well as 19thcentury art.

The New York State Comptroller's office charged yesterday that at least 35 executives and employees of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey had bilked the agency of an estimated $1 million or more over the years through "apparently fraudulent," inflated or improper expense-account claims.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 A former officer of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency disclosed today a new facet of the covert lobby intended to influence American Congressmen, an operation code named Ice Mountain that was aimed at 50 prominent Americans.

Anticipating that labor negotiations will be one of his first priorities if he is elected mayor, Edward I. Koch has been meeting for conversations with municipal labor leaders, although he is giving no signal of any shift in his stiff stance on labor.

When the Viennese pianist Paul Wittgenstein lost his right arm in World War I, he prevailed on some of the best known composers of the day to create a modern repertory for the left hand alone. That was how Ravel's familiar concerto for the left hand came to be written, as well as Prokofiev's Concerto No. 4.

PANAMA, Oct. 20 Gen. Omar Torrijos, the Panamaian leader, said tonight that the new Panama Canal treaties obliged the United States to assist Panama against a military attack that could affect the security of the canal.
Two of the world's largest aluminum companies the Aluminum Company of America and Alcan Aluminium Ltd. reported yesterday earnings gains in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30.

TRENTON, Oct. 20 A cigar-chomping state legislator, Assemblyman Francis J. McManimon, today challenged the authority of the New Jersey Public Health Council to adopt regulations prohibiting smoking in public places.
PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 20 The first close-up photographs of Deimos, the outer, smaller moon of Mars, obtained last Saturday by the Viking 2 orbiter, have shown its surface to be unexpectedly smooth.

INDIANA, Iowa, Oct. 20 Democratic Presidents faced with rising discontent and mounting protests in the Farm Belt are almost making a habit of dropping in on Woodrow W. Diehl at his 1,600-acre farm in the rolling hills just southeast of here.

Because of an editing error, an article in The Times Wednesday about the cleanup of PCB's from the Hudson River, incorrectly identified the General Electric Company as responsible for removal of a hydroelectric dam near Fort Edward, N.Y. The dam was removed by the Niagara-Mohawk Power Corporation.

DAVID MAMET is a playwright who loves the theater the mystery, the illusions, the code of behavior. His glori ous new comedy, "A Life in the Theater," which opened last night at the Theater de Lys, is a short play written with humor, affection and sophistication. It is an evening of pure theater.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 "I'm sitting here with some second thoughts," Margaret Costanza, a White House assistant, conceded as she pandered the criticism she has encountered for holding a fundraising cocktail party to pay off her old campaign debts two months after she took a White House post.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Oct. 21 (AP) The former chairman of the Northwestern Bank, Edwin Duncan Jr., whose lawyers cited the case of Bert Lance, the resigned Federal Budget Director, in his defense, was convicted today on six counts of misapplying $257,000 in bank funds. i
A new housing strategy for the South Bronx that favors low-rise buildings instead of the tall apartment towers the city has been erecting there was announced yesterday by the Beame administration.

Wilgar Coleman, a former director of the editorial department of the Edison Electric Institute of New York City, the principal association of the nation's investor-owned electric utilities, died Thursday in Barre, Vt. He was 83 years old.

Michael Pauker, board chairman of the Barclay Knitwear Company Inc., which he had founded almost a half century ago, died Thursday at his home at 150 Central Park South after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 21 (UPI) Vitas Gerulaitis defeated Phil Dent by 6-2, 6-2 today to give the United States three players in the semifinals of the $125,000 Australian Indoor tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 The House ethics committee saw documentary evidence today that Tongsun Park was paid $9.2 million in rice commissions over seven years, much of which was apparently intended to cover his covert lobbying expenses.

LONDON, Oct. 21 The chairman of British Leyland, the state-controlled automobile company, resigned today amid a public uproar over disparaging remarks he made at a private dinner last month about nonwhites, trade unions and the Labor Party Government. The remarks came to light yesterday.

PANAMA, Oct. 21 (Reuters) The most vocal Panamanian opposition group to the new Panama Canal treaties charged today that the Government had framed the rules of Sunday's ratification plebiscite here to allow for electoral fraud.

Representative Edward I. Koch denied yesterday that he was waffling on the Westway, fudging on the city's fiscal crisis or sneaking out on Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, one of his running mates on the Democratic ticket all of which he had been accused of by his mayoral opponent, Mario M. Cuomo.

MONTREAL, Oct. 21 The Quebec government threatened today to take over the Asbestos Corporation, which is controlled by the General Dynamics Corporation of St. Louis, if the American company continued to refuse to sell its interest.

HONG KONG, Oct. 21 Chinese universities are to require entrance examinations for the first time since the Cultural Revolution, and some high-school students are to be permitted to go directly to college without having to spend several years working in the countryside, Peking announced today.
Radio City Music Hall musicians who called a strike last Tuesday began voting yesterday on an accord reached by their union and the theater management for a new contract.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 21 John Frosch Skillman, the head coach of squash racquets at Yale University from 1934 until 1975, died of a heart attack at his home here yesterday. He was 70 years old.

HOUSTON, Oct. 21 A state civil court jury in Houston today cleared Davis Ashton Robinson, a 79-year-old Texas oilman, of charges that to avenge the death of his daughter, Joan Robinson Hill, he conspired in the murder of his son-in-law, Dr. John Hill, in 1972. Dr. Hill, a prominent Houston plastic surgeon, was shot to death in the foyer of his home.

In a document mailed to the United States just days before he was "banned" by the South African Government, the Rev. Beyers Naude, a prominent white church leader, said he expected growing turbulence in the business and economic affairs of South Africa.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 203.2 from 205.2 last week.

Gold prices, followed by silver prices, went on another price-rising spree yesterday. The impetus came from a comment by Secretary of the Treasury W. Michael Blumenthal that the Government had no intention of supporting the weakening dollar.
FREEHOLD, Oct. 21 Thirty-four Matawan high school teachers facing the late afternoon start of a jail term were granted a last-minute reprieve today by a state appellate judge.

A case of pneumonia in the United States has been traced to a germ that is almost totally resistant to penicillin, the drug that has been used for decades against bacteria of that type, Federal health specialists reported yesterday.

WRITE PLAINS, Oct. 21 The I.B.M. Corporation, with 10,000 workers, the largest employer in Westchester County, has acquired options to buy 640 acres in Somers for a new office facility, possibly a division headquarters.
Scott Bodie glanced at his watch, then swung his black-and-gold-striped "doctor's bag" over his shoulder and walked out of his West 82d Street apartment. It was time to make a house call.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct.21 Justice Minister James T. Kruger today defended the South African Government's crackdown on opposition elements as an attempt to halt the "total disruption" of blacks' lives by groups using terror and intimidation to stir perpetual anti-Government unrest.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 The University of Pennsylvania, inhabited mostly by climbers in the groves of American academe and retaining some of its leaf-covered walls here in West Philadelphia, is suffering an identity crisis.

The Government's mediation chief renewed his efforts yesterday to find a formula for settling the 21-day-old strike of longshoremen that has halted containership operations on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts.

Bowing to the combined pressure of Governor Carey, Mayor Beame and the Carter Administration, Democratic legislative leaders agreed yesterday to seek passage of a bill to meet New York City's credit needs at a special session in Albany next Tuesday.

Prince Charles, heir to the British throne, will take in an American college football game today when he attends the Georgia-Kentucky match at Sanford Stadium in Athens, Ga. It was 20 years ago that his mother, queen Elizabeth II sat in on the 1957 Maryland-North Carolina game at Byrd Stadium in College Park, Md. The Prince was only 9 years old then, so he stayed in England.
MANILA, Saturday, Oct. 22 The United States team began strongly in its attempt to retain the world team title here yesterday, scoring maximum points in the first round of qualifying play.
Public-television stations that use the "Live From Lincoln Center" telecasts as vehicles for their own fund-raising may have to share the income with Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

Under a $6.4 million Federal grant, 500 unemployed performing, literary and graphic artists will be hired for one year of community-service work at a salary of $10,000 each, Mayor Beame announced yesterday.

Consumer prices rose moderately in the country but fell slightly in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area last month, the Government reported yesterday. It was the first September drop in metropolitan area consumer prices in 10 years.

Despite his guileless gaze and his friendly low-keyed phrasings, Rick Nelson is very much a man of mystery. He has resolutely pursued a pop-singing career ever since the early days of his stardom, even though most of his later albums have sold only modestly. He has always, even during the less successful stages of his career, been able to attract top-flight backup musicians.

By finding David R. Berkowitz competent to stand trial, a justice in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn made it clear yesterday that he thought the man accused of being the .44-caliber killer was capable of understanding the proceedings against him and was able to assist in his own defense.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance recalled the American Ambassador to South Africa today for consultation on what steps the United States should take in reaction to the crackdown on blacks and their supporters.

WEST ORANGE, Oct. 21 The world head of the transcendental meditation movement, Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, today dismissed as "insignificant" a Federal District Court order barring the teaching of transcendental meditation in New Jersey's public schools, but pledged that "as a law-abiding body" the organization would "go by the law."

SHANGHAI Eleven years ago every university and secondary and primary school in China closed down during the Cultural Revolution. WASHINGTON A designer and consultant who lectures on architectural writing at Yale and Princeton graduate schools has patented a desk-level lighting fixture for office use. It is described as providing good illumination while substantially eliminating direct glare and annoying reflections.

LOWELLVILLE, Ohio, Oct. 20 When the Rockets, Lowellville's high school football team, faced the Tigers from nearby Springfield High School last Saturday they had 18 players on the bench compared with 59 for their opponents.

TRENTON, Oct. 21 State Senator Raymond H. Bateman's campaign for Governor of New Jersey will be drained of more than $100,00 in the closing weeks of the race as a result of a ruling today by the state's Election Law Enforcement Commission voiding a campaign spending plan.

LONDON, Oct. 21 (Reuters) Britain is inviting leaders of the parties in the Rhodesian independence dispute to a series of talks in Africa next month with Sir Michael Carver, the resident commissioner-designate, the Foreign Office announced today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 21 Thailand's military rulers, who dismissed the year-old civilian government yesterday, said today that they would govern through a committee of civilians until elections could be held.

The St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, the United States' only full-time professional chamber orchestra, began a three-concert engagement in Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night with a solid, well-balanced program. Bettina B. Davis, who won international recognition as Bettina Bolegard, a fashion model in the 1940's and 1950's, died Oct. 9 of cancer at her family ranch near Elbert, Colo. She was 61 years old and formerly lived in Tarrytown and Pocantico Hills, N.Y.

ROME, Oct. 21 Mediterranean countries, prompted by fears of what pollution could do to tourism, public health and fisheries, reached agreement in principle today on a treaty that would control the discharge of industrial and other wastes into coastal waters.

THF FAMILY budget tools another battering last week as the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City climbed by nine-tenths of 1 percent, the City Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

After a title-closing Sept. 30 a large owner-developer of office buildings in Canada, Olympia and York Developments Ltd., has become one of New York City's largest landlords. Most prices of gold bullion futures managed to close 10 to 20 cents an ounce higher yesterday despite heavy profit taking after the recent advances.

ALBANY, Oct. 25--State officials argued in a special session of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court today that Governor Carey's proposal to issue $750 million in bonds for economic development should be restored to the ballot and were asked sharp questions by two of the five justices that seemed to indicate their skepticism of the bond issue's constitutionality.

A dinner of Italian lentil soup kicked off the cold turkey treatment. Vainly, I searched for a bit of stray meat. All vegetables. I spooned down two bowls of steaming stuff, along with three thick slices of Deb's fresh-baked bread, still warm from the oven. Somehow, I was full. We toasted meal No. 1 with Gallo Chenin Blanc. So far, so good.

THE BEST FRIENDS in "Some of My Best Friends" are a tree, a baby and a dog, all of whom talk. To mangle the old talking dog saying: you are not surprised they are doing it--this being a play of the most conscientious feyness--but they don't do it well at all.

CLIFTON, Oct. 25--Kenneth M. Curtis, the national Democratic chairman, told a luncheon audience of 200 today that this was his third trip to New Jersey to campaign for Governor Byrne in his uphill drive for re-election "and every time I come back I find the race is getting closer."

IT'S hard to be clever at Halloween time--almost everything has been tried before. Parents who are looking for some inspiration might find it in Arnold Dobrin's "Make a Witch, Make a Goblin" (Four Winds Press, $6.95). This simply written and carefully illustrated book offers a host of clever costumes, masks, decorations, favors and Halloween recipes that are both inexpensive and easy to make.
A pattern of flat third-quarter earnings for oil companies emerged yesterday despite solid demand for petroleum products.

The race for Governor of New Jersey appears to be one of the closest in the state's history, with Governor Byrne and State Senator Raymond H. Bateman in a virtual tie in the closing weeks of the campaign.

Lewis, associate dean of the Cornell University Graduate School of Business and Public Administration. The year before, 39 percent did not accept the highest offer, he added in a telephone interview.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--A House subcommittee today demanded that the Commerce Department turn over all internal memoranda and written comments from private business, foreign governments, and other executive agencies concerning the department's proposed regulations to enforce the new antiboycott law.

WITH THE exception of some of the soles and flounders, few fish are so closely twinned as the mako shark and the swordfish. Both follow the same ocean currents, going north as waters warm in summer, then turning south as winter approaches. They travel not only because of temperature, but in search of their natural prey: mackerel and herring for the swordfish, mackerel, herring and swordfish for the mako.

What's better than a chic shopping bag? It could be a 14-karat gold bag that looks as though it's overflowing with diamonds, or simply a gold metal bag with no glittery pretensions. Both bags are tiny, attached to either gold kid or a chain and are meant to be worn as necklaces.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--Hubert Humphrey came back to the Senate today, broken in health but not in spirit and responding joyously to a 30-minute tribute in which he was enveloped by the affection of his colleagues.

THE SYMPTOMS of bowel disease are familiar to more of us than are likely to admit it: abdominal cramps, gas, or diar rhea alternating with constipation. The amount of distress and embarrassment they cause millions of Americans vastly exceeds the frequency with which they are discussed among friends and acquaintances.

Hoechst Fibers Industries, a division of the American Hoechst Corporation, announced yesterday the development of an inherently flame-resistant polyester fiber for use in children's sleepwear.
The Harlem Commonwealth Council has temporarily withdrawn a plan to build a housing project for the elderly in Harlem on the site of a Muslim school operated by the Atlas Nation of Five Percenters.

A neighborhood gang has seized a six-story apartment house in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, terrorizing the more than 100 tenants by ripping out the building's pipes, punching out its windows and smashing its furnishings. Only two tenants remain, and the gang has boasted of plans to burn the house down. As of late last week, the police seemed unaware of what has happened.
Dr. Bernard Chiego, the director since 1933, of Bioresearch Labs in Bloomfield, N.J., died Wednesday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N.J. He was 73 years old and lived in Bloomfield.

The race for Governor of New Jersey appears to be one of the closest in the state's history, with Governor Byrne and State Senator Raymond H. Bateman in a virtual tie in the closing weeks of the campaign.

Zelda Fichandler, producing, director of the Arena Stage in Washington, has announced the appointment of David Chambers as associate producing director. Mr. Chambers will be responsihlc for the next two seasons at Arena Stage--1978-79, and 1979-80 --Mrs. Fichandler said, She added that she planned to disengage herself from the responsibilities of artistic administration and direct her energies to other aspects of Arena Stage activity.
On March 13, 1964, Kitty Genovese was stabbed to death in Kew Gardens, Queens, in the murder that became a symbol of the indifference of witnesses to violence.

UAL Inc., holding company for United Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, reported yesterday record earnings for reporting periods ended Sept. 30, with profits in the quarter climbing 77.7 percent and for the nine months, up more than fourfold.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 25--The new superintendent of the United States Military Academy, Lieut. Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster, said today that he had taken steps to eliminate the "abuse, harassment and denigration" of first-year cadets.

WASHINGTON, Oct.25 (UPI)--Workers began planting a 32-foot blue spruce behind the White House today to serve as the nation's permanent Christmas tree. Last year's permanent tree is rotting and will be used as this year's yule log.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--A State Department official said today that some political prisoners had been released in more than a dozen countries after the United States had communicated its concern.

ROSAMOND, CALIF. The chef in top hat and tails who represented England put beer--English beer--in his chili; the Texans' secret ingredients included Texas water; the Tennesseeans used raccoon meat, and the North Dakotans used pheasant.

SoHo, ever burgeoning with art galleries, boutiques and restaurants, has an addition in the area of gourmandise which has no counterpart in SoHo, or, safe to say in terms of ambiance, uptown. It's a food and kitchen shop called Dean and Deluca, which recently opened its doors at 121 Prince Street. "Not a gourmet shop," said Jack Ceglic, its designer, who normally devotes himself to painting.

NICE, France, Oct. 25 (Reuters)--Felix Gouin, former head of the French provisional government set up after General de Gaulle's resignation in January 1946, died today, his family announced. He was 93.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 25--Electric Boat, the second largest employer in Connecticut and the largest employer in Rhode Island, began laying off 3,000 to 4,000 workers today.

THE DANCE that has been worked on too long frequently ends up looking just that: la bored, without the spontaneity essential for performance life. The Wetzig Dance Company presented "Statement of Patterns" at the Cubiculo Monday evening with a program note that indicated the piece has been developing since 1971. Its long gestation lost something vital along the way.
In the spirit of the state's new marijuana law, Governor Carey yesterday commuted the sentences of seven men serving prison terms for marijuana offenses under the previous, more stringent, law.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--The White House said today that "as far as this Administration is concerned" a series of allegations that Israel had stolen or had diverted weapons-grade nuclear material from the United States were unproven.
Murder and robbery charges against Joanne D. Chesimard were dismissed in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday on the ground that the state had delayed too long in bringing her to trial.

BONN--The new type of antiterrorist operation developed by Israel and the German Federal Republic at Entebbe and Mogadishu to rescue innocent hostages from skyjacked planes has manifold implications. It demonstrates that no haven or any country amoral enough to serve as accomplice to terroristic acts can be safe from retribution legitimized by either written or unwritten international codes of honor.

THE 15 major exponents of realism in American painting about whom Mahonri Sharp Young has chosen to write biographical essayS were all artists of strong individuality and diverse character, yet they shared a common point of view. "All the artists in this book painted what they saw, not what they felt."

SHAPES Some 60 artists well known and new, are represented in the 40th annual exhibition of the Sculptors Guild, going on view today and running through Nov. 17 at Lever House, Park Avenue at 53d Street. New works in plastics and glass are on display, along with pieces in traditional bronze, wood and clay. These classical materials also used experimentally.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25--Responding to the urgent appeals of Philadelphia's top school officials, the state moved today to avert a fiscal crisis that threatens to close this city's 285 public schools.

Concern over the high levels of refined sugars and junk foods and the need for more flexibility in meat alternatives were discussed yesterday on a hearing on the national school lunch program. It was the first of two days of hearings held by the United States Department of Agriculture to discuss the effectiveness of the Government's child nutrition programs.

HONG KONG, Oct. 25--China's planning chief has said that industry is on the road to recovery after years of disruption, but that there are still difficulties in agriculture, consumer goods, fuel and power.

The refusal by the New York City police to raid a midtown hotel Oct. 11 that was suspected of being used by pimps to house teen-age prostitutes erupted yesterday into an open dispute among city, state and police officials.
REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Oct. 25 (AP)-- Bing Crosby, who guarded his privacy in life, apparently has managed to maintain his privacy after death.

JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 25--An autopsy report on Stephen Biko showing the primary cause of death to have been brain damage has been completed and delivered to the Attorney General of Transvaal Province, who will decide within days whether to order an inquest or criminal proceedings.

Detroit and Memphis were awarded franchises in the North American Soccer League yesterday, bringing the number of clubs in the league to 21. There are at least five other cities still under consideration for franchises next year.

Thomas F. Galvin, the Republican-Conservative candidate for Borough President of Queens, bolted the ranks of both parties supporting him yesterday by endorsing Mario M. Cuomo, the Liberal Party candidate for Mayor.

Three of the nation's major steel companies reported declines in third quarter earnings yesterday with the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest producer, showing a sharp drop of 75.9 percent.

JON HENDRICKS, who was the lyricist and sparkplug of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross, the celebrated jazz vocal group of the 1950's, is making his first appearance in New York in 10 years this week, through Saturday, at Hopper's, where, Janus-like, he is looking ahead, looking back and sometimes doing both simultaneously.

LONDON, Oct. 25--A nine-week-old strike by British air-traffic control assistants seemed to be nearing an end tonight following a new pay offer from the Civil Aviation Authority.

The message for North Americans from Panama's plebiscite on the canal treaties is not that two-thirds of the voters approved but that a third did not. And their disapproval, it is safe to say, came because they felt that the treaties concede too much to the United States.

LIKE "II Pagliacci," its traditional partner on opera programs, "Cavalleria Rusticana" falls into the special category of "audience favorite" and, given at least an adequate performance, is almost immune to criticism. Based on a short story by Giovanni Verga, the book is drenched in passionate love, jealousy and revenge, Sicilian style. Pietro Mascagni's score is a solid chain of soaring melodies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI)--The Defense Department today made public names of 20 servicemen and 1 civilian whose remains were turned over to the United States by the Vietnamese Government last month.

BETHESDA, Md.--My wife and I bought two cars in one day recently, and by the time it was over, we were feeling like oil sheiks. Writing two checks for almost $7,000, when you don't have the money in your account, has its exhilarating aspects, as long as you don't think too much. We had became full-fledged, card carrying suburbanites, with a vengeance.

RUSSELL BAKER, that inexhaustible fount of wit, was once heard to disclaim that he was a "funny man"; he was, he insisted, usually dead serious. The first merely entertains, the second also instructs, and hence deserves more than passing attention.

DETROIT, Oct. 25--Domestic new car sales for the second 10-day period of October were 16.7 percent ahead of last year's level, according to industry reports released here today. The "Big Four" auto makers sold a total of 291,658 passenger cars for this period.
Three new conductors have been appointed to posts with major American symphony orchestras in the Exxon/ Arts Endowment Conductors program. They bring to 10 the number of participants this season.

OF THE GREAT COMPOSERS, Mozart must strike the listener as the healthiest and least morbid, white Mahler goes about in dark clothes, introspective and tortured. The Federal Reserve, under pressure from the Carter Administration not to push up interest rates, showed its independence yesterday afternoon by raising the discount rate for the second time in less than two months.

Dave Bristol was dismissed yesterday as manager of the Atlanta Braves after the team had two last-place finishes.
