Yogi Berra indicated yesterday he would be interested in managing the Atlanta Braves, although he said he hadn't been approached about it.
North Atlantic port associations said yesterday that they had agreed to bargain with the striking longshoremen on a local basis, port by port, on the issue of a guaranteed annual income.

ONE OF THE FINEST things about Brooklyn happens to be situated in Philadelphia it is the Pennsylvania Bullet, the resident ballet company of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The Pennsylvanians, happily enough, officially opened the 1977-78 season at the academy on Tuesday night. It was the academy's resurgence following the disastrous flood of Sept. 5, which at one time seemed to threaten the academy, or at least its immediate future.

TRENTON, Oct. 26 Documents released today by the State Senate show that Governor Byrne asked Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes of the New Jersey Supreme Court to help him lobby for a judicial appointment in the Senate last year.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 26 Hudson County Democratic candidates for the State Legislature are not wondering whether they will win or lose but whether they will bring a fellow Democrat, Governor Byrne, to victory with them.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 26 The president of the International Federation of Airline Pilots Associations, in an unusual appearance at the United Nations, chastized its members today for what he called their "pathetic" record in ratifying international conventions on hijacking, which nearly a third of the countries represented here have not signed.

Paul Blair, an eight-time golden glove winner who was used largely as a defensive replacement for Reggie Jackson in right field by the New York Yankees, signed a three-year contract wth the team yesterday. No other terms of the contract were announced. The 33-year-old Blair was acquired from the Baltimore Orioles last January in exchange for Elliott Maddox. In 82 games for the Yankees Blair batted .262 and hit four home runs.

THERE'S A BIT OF TRUTH in that snide old story about the audiophile who found his first live concert disappointing: There were no tone controls for him to play with. Today, audio enthusiasts might be dissatisfied even if the Metropolitan Opera House or Avery Fisher Hall came equipped with treble and bass knobs. Now they'd insist on more elaborate controls, called "equalizers."

BONN, Oct. 26 Franz Josef Strauss, the conservative politician and former defense minister today called recent disclosures concerning the raid by West German commandos at the airport of Mogadishu, Somalia, "absolutely irresponsible" because they had supplied valuable information to would-be hijackers.
The Asbury Park Press was published on schedule despite a strike by a union representing delivery truck drivers, the newspaper said.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 When Jimmy Carter was elected President last year, a new world seemed to open for Gerald Rafshoon, the Atlanta media specialist whose television commercials helped lift Mr. Carter from relative obscurity to national prominence.

IN the three years since she left Twyla Tharp's company, with which she danced for nine years, Sara Rudner has picked up a large following. In any case, the house was full Tuesday night at the Entermedia Theater, where the Dance Umbrella series is presenting the Sara Rudner Performance Ensemble this week, alternating with Dianne McIntyre's Company.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) Foreign direct investment in American business rose 9.1 percent last year to $30.2 billion, the Commerce Department said today.

JOE HENDERSON, the jazz saxophonist who is at the Village Vanguard through Saturday, is a particularly striking example of the respected jazz musician who chooses to live elsewhere from New York, the jazz capital. In fact, he hasn't performed here for four years. But Mr. Henderson says he has no regrets about basing himself in the quieter San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Dr. Donald Kennedy, the head of the Food and Drug Administration, issued letters of admonition today to two high officials of the agency and made a formal apology to 12 of its employees and consultants as a result of a series of investigations of internal operations.

About 61,000 people who filed claims in a class-action suit against three widely known Fifth Avenue stores for credits on alleged overcharges have learned from the United States District Court that about 30 percent of a settlement offer is going to their lawyers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The Carter Administration's ranking Soviet specialist told a House committee today that the Soviet Union was on the verge of a "wholesale generational turnover" at the top and the new leaders should be encouraged to enter into constructive relations with the United States.

A majority of those who intend to vote in the New Jersey gubernatorial election on Nov. 8 will apparently base their choice principally on their feelings about Governor Byrne and not on their perceptions of his challenger, State Senator Raymond H. Bateman.
The New York Times Company yesterday reported a 35.9 percent increase in third-quarter earnings, to $5.8 million, or 51 cents a share, compared with the yearearlier $4.3 million, or 38 cents a share.

WASHINGTON Oct. 26 A major reduction in Amtrak passenger service, involving the elimination of 22 of the 120 daily trains in the Washington-New YorkBoston corridor, was postponed today until Nov. 6 as Amtrak continued to hope for more money from Congress.
Rarely do civilians other than presidents, prime ministers, visiting monarchs, or retired generals "take the review" at a dress parade of the United States Corps of Cadets.

WE DON'T know if Estee Lauder has been lying awake nights worrying about the contenders who keep popping up to usurp her crown as queen of the beauty makers. Everybody, these days, is getting into the cosmetics business. Not just Halston and Calvin Klein and anyone with a name on a dress label, but actresses, Queens, housewives and nature buffs who mash up herbs and strain mud on remote farms.
DETROIT, Oct. 26 If crime has been reduced in Detroit, a questioner asked Mayor Coleman A. Young in a campaign debate this week, does that mean the streets are safe?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 A new bill to set up a consumer protection agency, backed by the White House and by consumer groups, cleared its first barrier today when the House Rules Committee voted to send it to the House floor.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 26 Bob Tucker's old locker was filled today at Giants Stadium. The one next to it remained empty. The Giants won't admit it, but they have a fullback problem.
Robert Powell, formerly a leading dancer with the Martha Graham Dance Company and until recently its associate artistic director, died Monday in New York. He was 38 years old.

CORETTA SCOTT KING will be presented he United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization's "Ceres" medal tomorrow morning at the United Nations headquarters here. Mrs. King, a member of the United States delegation to the General Assembly, will receive the award from Edouard Saouma, director general of the F.A.O. The medal portrays Mrs. King as Ceres, the Roman goddess of agriculture.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Oct. 20 Peter Lougheed, the Premier of Canada's most dynamic province, is waiting for Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau to put forward some "dramatic proposals" to overcome the crisis in the country's federal system.

LONDON, Oct. 26 The British Government, in a sort of mid-course correction to its economic policy, laid out today a wide-ranging plan it hopes will stimulate business activity and reduce unemployment.

A majority of those who intend to vote in the New Jersey gubernatorial election on Nov. 8 will apparently base their choice principally on their feelings about Governor Byrne and not on their perceptions of his challenger, State Senator Raymond H. Bateman.

LOS ANGELES (AP) Mike Murphy drilled in a five-footer with 3 minutes 28 seconds to play tonight to give the Los Angeles Kings a 2-2 National Hockey League tie with the New York Islanders and snap a three-game losing streak.

HAVING RECENTLY become a statistic in the marriage fall-out charts, I was forced to take stock of myself. There is a lulling complacency about being married that al- lows the aging process to follow a natural course and to mercifully avoid critical scrutiny in the looking glass.

SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 26 Foreign Minister Park Tong Jin hinted today that the South Korean Government might soon oust Kim Dong Jo, Seoul's Ambassador in Washington from 1967 to 1973 and now national security adviser to President Park Chung Hee.
WASHINGTON (UPI) Vegetables are the main item left on plates in school lunchrooms, and the National Advisory Council on Child Nutrition has a suggestion: replace them with more fruit.

NEW HAVEN A Yale University biologist who periodically travels to Vietnam reports that the Hanoi Government has embarked on full-scale development of its scientific research facilities, and is likely to name its supreme military commander, Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, to head the scientific program.
PASSAIC, N.J., Oct. 26 (AP) A 21year-old woman and her make friend wre being held without bail here today in connection with the death of her 2year-old daughter.

Competition in the computer textediting business intensified yesterday with the introduction by the Xerox Corporation of its 850 line of "word processing" equipment at a briefing and demonstration for newsmen at the Essex House.

Leroy A. Emmerich, a senior partner in and founder of Management Communications Inc., which helps corporations improve communications with employees and clients, died yesterday in Sarasota, Fla., after a short illness. He was 58 years old and lived in Warwick, N.Y.

SIENNA, an 8-month-old Ches apeake Bay retriever, chases boats. "Most dogs run after cars," said the retriever's owners, Edmond and Sandford Downing of Rye, N.Y., "but Sienna just dives in and swims for the boats."

After finally winning the cooperation of a reluctant neighborhood, Brooklyn homicide detectives arrested Joseph D'Amico yesterday evening and charged him with the murder of his neighbor, Angelo Treglia, on a crowded Bensonhurst street over the wekend.
Those who do not hunt deer may be unaware that the animals have a marvelously keen sense of smell, relying on it more than on hearing or eyesight for survival.
CARNEGIE HALL last night was part concert hall, part theater. Seiji Osawa, leading the Boston Symphony, gave the Berlioz opera, "Betrice et Benedict" in its entirety.
CAIRO, Oct. 26 A new Egyptian Cabinet was sworn in today with a limited shuffle of officials, as had been expected, aimed at improving economic performance and efficiency in the vast bureaucracy.
Budget-conscious travelers who had to pay in advance for low-cost charter flights abroad can now buy tickets right up to the hour of takeoff, a tour spokesman said yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 26 Defense Minister Pieter W. Botha said tonight that South Africa had a strong enough arms industry to surmount an international embargo and to "put up a fight that will astonish" opponents seeking to end white rule.

EVERY YEAR for the past three years, a small book of interiors has come quietly from a pub- lisher with the evocative name of Quick Fox, and while they could not exactly be called subversive books, there is something about them that suggests an assured kind of counterchic. Offbeat is not the right world, either, because these books are much better than that.
PARIS, Oct. 26 The ready-towear collections shown this week are billed for the spring and summer season. Actually, they pass lightly over the first part and concentrate on things to wear in the sun.

There appears to be some hope yet for owners of 3.5 million shares of common and preferred stock of Schenley Industries who have tried since May 1971 to get more for their shares than they were offered when the company was taken private by the Glen Alden Corporation.

These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fast-selling record.

YONKERS, Oct. 26 The Australianbred Amlin, who, at the age of 13, has been captivating Yonkers Raceway fans, will seek his fourth straight victory tomorrow night at the Westchester County harness horse track.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger proposed today an end to Federal price controls on motor gasoline. The move would leave controls on only a small number of petroleum products.

Michael Roth, a Republican who has sorted as chairman of the State Liquor Authority for three and a half years, resigned yesterday. Governor Carey immediately named Hugh B. Marious, a Democratic member of the authority, as acting chairman.

Macy's is mostly devoid of music, except for those bingk-bingk-bingk signals of the department store code sounding through the shoppers' babble. So Louis Yelnick, who runs men's sports footwear in the midtown store, has an excellent point when he tells how his daytime salesman's job contributes contrast to his nighttime profession of turning the pages for pianists in concert halls around the city as they nod and throb with both hands on the keyboard.

Two New York City policemen have been indicted and a third is being investigated in connection with the heating of seven prisoners while they were in a police van awaiting transportation from one precinct to another.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) Caught in a tangle with no legal precedents, a House Judiciary subcommittee has asked the Justice Department and legal experts whether Congress can give states seven more years to ratify the equal rights amendment.
TORONTO, Oct. 26 (AP) The Respirion Corporation said yesterday that it would test a formula that an 89-year-old woman from Bracebridge, Ontario, says is useful in the control or cure of cancer.

UNITED NATIONS,N.Y., Oct. 26 Egypt led off an attack in the General Assembly today on Israel's establishment of settlements in occupied Arab lands, asking the United Nations to respond vigorously to what it called Israel's "illegal" acts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The Environmental Protection Agency, under pressure from big utilities and their supporters in Congress, reversed itself today and decided to suspend enforcement of the key provision of a new law protecting unpolluted air.

A second member of the board of didectors of The Trib, the daily newspaper scheduled to come out in January, resigned yesterday in a controversy involving charges by the paper's publisher that William E. Simon, former Secretary of the Treasury, had attempted to gain editorial and financial control of the paper to further his own political ambitions.

A smoky, early-morning fire in a kitchen exhaust duct sent guests at the St. Moritz Hotel to the lobby in all manner of nocturnal attire. There were no injuries, damage was minimal and there was no panic.

The prosecution in the perjury trial of Justice Andrew R. Tyler of New York State Supreme Court rested its case yesterday after presenting to the jury the parts of his grand jury testimony in which it is alleged he lied.
A three-inch scar on the shoulder of the mystery horse in Belmont Park's ringer case emerged yesterday as a major clue to the puzzle.

GROTON, Conn., Oct. 26 As he left the engineering building of the Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics, his arms laden with a 19 year accumulation of office paraphernalia, Richard L. Herbert unhooked his security badge and placed it on a table.

ALBANY, Oct. 26 New York State installed a new Commissioner of Education today in a ceremony rich with the academic pomp and heraldry of the Middle Ages, but tempered by modern-day concern about education costs and other problems.

Harold McCrae, acquitted last August in State Supreme Court in Manhattan of charges that he raped and stabbed a 13year-old girl, was arrested yesterday on charges of having stabbed to death a woman whose body was found Tuesday in the building where he lives.

Sheila Younge, a former editor of Essence magazine, died at her family's home in Berkeley, Calif., last Thursday. She was 32 years old and had lived in New York City before returning to her parent's home last fall.

When he was appointed president of Michigan State University eight years ago, Dr. Clifton R. Wharton Jr. was identified mainly as the first black to be president of a major predominantly white college in the United States.

"We made the shower curtains," said Dino Di Gerlando, "because the bathroom is one part of the home that has no art in it." The shower curtains, done by Mr. Di Gerlando and Robert Schneider, are airy paintings on cotton canvas: a splash of color here, a broad stripe there, dots, spatters, a few squiggles or stylized flowers.

ART IS THE STUBBORN tendril that cracks the pavement. Calypso, that barbed and bobbing Trinidadian art, was a crooked, lively assertion that darted through the poverty, apathy and social layering of a small, colonial island.
The police in Brooklyn arrested three teen-age boys yesterday in an apartment house that had been seized by a neighborhood youth gang. Other gang members had left the building, the police reported.
MANILA, Oct. 26 There was little excitement in the final qualifying round of Bermuda Bowl play for the world team championship.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The Environmental Fund unveiled outside its offices today a huge digital clock that measures not time but the rate at which the group contends that the world is overpopulating itself.

I HAVEN'T looked at the statistics lately, but presumably a great many people are still migrating to California under the mistaken assumption that the grass is greener in my native state. Actually, the grass is brown, which was one of many reasons I couldn't wait to grow up and leave California altogether.
The dollar was stable in foreign exchange trading in Europe yesterday and was mixed against the Japanese yen; gold prices were mixed, The Associated Press reported.

The New Jersey Nets have twice missed the deadline for a $320,000 indemnification payment due the Knicks as part of the $4 million owed them for permitting the Nets entry to the National Basketball Association for the 1976-77 season.

Twenty-nine demonstrators who occupied the Statue of Liberty on Tuesday were released on minimal bail yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan. They were charged with a misdemeanor involving trespassing on Federal property.

SOME OF THE LEADING lights of the literary world did two things last night they don't normally do: They donned evening clothes, and they gathered under the same roof the roof of the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

John J. Tuohy, chairman and chief executive officer of the Long Island Lighting Company, said yesterday that he planned to relinquish those positions at the end of the year. Mr. Tuohy, who is 61 years old, will be succeeded by Charles R. Pierce, 55, who is president, Wilfred O. Uhl, 50, senior vice president of engineering and project management, will become president.
BOSTON, Oct. 23 A growing investigation by Federal and Massachusetts authorities into the misuse of education funds has uncovered evidence of a national scheme to bilk Government grant programs.

DEARBORN, MICH. (AP) The Henry Ford Museum used to brag that its "Great Brewster Chair" was a bona fide Pilgrim-era relic. But now the chair is locked away, gathering dust for it seems the chair is not a rare 350-year-old relic after all, but the 1969 work of a Rhode Island woodcarver.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 26 Representatives of some of the nation's most powerful advertisers have met with TV program producers and the networks in hopes of preventing a glut of sex from replacing the glut of violence in network programming.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The House of Representatives will not even consider President Carter's request to transfer $800 million worth of weapons to South Korea because of Seoul's refusal to cooperate with House investigations of alleged Korean influence-buying, the chairman of the International Relations Committee said tonight.

MANILA, Oct. 26 The Italian Bridge Federation was threatened today with suspension from the world bridge organization on the ground that it had failed to investigate thoroughly the socalled "smoke signal" scandal, in which bridge players were accused of cheating by signaling their partners with cigarettes.

Despite the fact that the nation's stockpile of corn on Oct. 1 was the highest in five years and slightly more than Government experts earlier envisioned, futures prices of corn made gains of about 3 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 House and Senate energy conferees agreed today on a program of federally subsidized loans for domestic solar heating units and ruled out mandatory Federal standards for fuel efficiency of pumps and motors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The House of Representatives will not even consider President Carter's request to transfer $800 million worth of weapons to South Korea because of Seoul's refusal to cooperate with House investigations of alleged Korean influence-buying, the chairman of the International Relations Committee said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 A Carter Administration effort to explain its Middle East policies today turned into a forum for American Jewish leaders to express anger over what they perceive as an antiIsrael drift in those policies.

The decline in coffee demand and a $17.5 million writedown for coffee inventories caused earnings of the General Foods Corporation to fall 36.7 percent in the September quarter, the big packaged foods producer reported yesterday.

Michael Roth, a Republican who has served as chairman of the State Liquor Authority for three and a half years, resigned yesterday. Governor Carey immediately named Hugh B. Marious, a Democratic member of the authority, as acting chairman.

STUTTGART, West Germany, Oct. 26 A commission investigating the deaths of three imprisoned terrorists last week said today that "there can be no doubt" that they committed suicide. But, it added, "it can be assumed" that in doing so they tried to make their deaths look like murder.

A labor union analyst charged yesterday that Governor Carey had become a "parttime Governor" who was neglecting to keep up with his job in part because of "a hectic social life" and late-hour attendance at a bar.
A 40-year-old Bronx man shot and killed his wife in a crowded midtown variety store yesterday and seconds later killed himself, the police reported.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The general manager of Electric Boat Company was summoned here today by members of the Connecticut Congressional delegation to explain his sudden decision yesterday to lay off more than 3,000 workers. His visit succeeded primarily in infuriating the legislators and raising the possibility that there might be further layoffs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 "They have never recognized the right of Israel to exist," said President Carter of the Soviets, explaining to an interviewer why he was proud of the joint U.S.S.R.-U.S. statement on the Mideast.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 26 The spaceplane Enterprise made a bumpy touchdown here today, but it was apparently good enough for project officials to declare the landing test phase of the multibillion-dollar space shuttle program a success.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 26 No one, not even a linebacker hobbling around on a severely bruised ankle, is immune from pro football's put-down humor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 A Carter Administration effort to explain its Middle East policies today turned into a forum for American Jewish leaders to express anger over what they perceive as an antiIsrael drift in those policies.

MARILYN FRENCH'S first novel, "The Women's Room," is a history of women from the 1950's through the 70's, and the best compliment I can pay it is that I kept forgetting that it was fiction. It seized me by my preconceptions and I kept struggling and arguing with its premises.

Mario M. Cuomo sought yesterday to put some flesh on the bones of the Neigh borhood Preservation Party, a second spot on the Nov. 8 ballot that the Liberal Party candidate hopes will attract enough dissident Democrats and independent voters to enable him to edge out Repre sentative Edward I. Koch for the mayoral ty.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) As a result of the Bert Lance case, the nation's 14,700 Federally insured banks have been ordered to supply information to Congress on several banking practices such as overdrafts, it was formally announced today.

What should the world do now about South Africa? What can it do? The questions arise from last week's shutdown of leading black newspapers and virtually all organizations working to break down racial barriers. Clearly, Prime Minister Vorster and his Afrikaner colleagues have no intention of ever recognizing even moderate black political leadership.
The New York and American stock exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports of changes in stock of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 26 Five months ago, the best Gail Goodrich could do was shuffle. The knifing pain in his right ankle after Achilles tendon surgery during the offceason was so great he couldn't jog.

President Carter was generally perceived as a liberal in the 1976 Presidential campaign, but now a plurality of those polled consider him a conservative, according to the results of a Gallup Poll made public yesterday.

MALE, Maldive Islands, Oct. 26 (Reuters) President Ibrahim Nasir disclosed today that a $1 million offer to lease the former Royal Air Force base on Gan Island, turned down by his Government early this month, had come from the Sovi et Union.

BAYTOWN, Tex., Oct. 26 Exxon's enlarged Baytown refinery was formally dedicated here today as the nation's largest such facility, and Gov. Dolph Briscoe used the ceremonies to criticize President Carter's energy policies.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 26 (UPI) Judge Joseph F. Dufresne munched 10 pieces of pizza and sat at a kitchen counter taking testimony in an effort to decide whether the Pillsbury Company has too big a slice of the market.

EDWARD L. KOCH, who according to the polls will probably be the next Mayor of New York City, unlocked the gleaming new Segal lock on his front door and led the way into what has become a compaign issue of sorts his $250-a-month rent-controlled apartment just off Washington Square.

JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 26 The beginning yesterday of the trial of Winnie Mandela, the wife of a jailed black nationalist leader and a heroine of the nationalist movement in her own right, has focused attention on a unique form of punishment here the "banning" of people.
The experienced player will always take advantage of a superior position to extract the maximum number of points from the game.

In yet another executive shuffle at the television networks in a hotly competitive season that has already seen two network presidents fall, NBC-TV yesterday appointed Paul L. Klein chief of programming, with the title of executive vice president.
Successful testing of a vaccine in chil dren against a major cause of pneumonia, meningitis and ear infections that can cause deafness was reported yesterday by medical scientists in California.
A candidate for the Jesuit priesthood has been dismissed by the order a year after he was told that he would be denied ordination because he was an admitted homosexual.
THE 92d STREET Y.M-Y.W.H.A. has expanded the range and quantity of its musical offerings enormously in recent seasons, and in so doing has tried out some unconventional programming ideas.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to reduce the Federal penalty for possession of small amounts of marijuana.

A bank robber who took two hostages while trying to make a getaway was fatally shot yesterday and a policeman and three civilians were wounded in a fusillade of bullets on a busy street near Gramercy Park.
A spool and tube manufacturer who had been on the point of moving to New Jersey announced yesterday that his company and its 125 jobs soon to grow to 200 jobs would remain in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) President Carter has "no intention" of asking Kenneth M. Curtis, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, to resign, a White House spokesman said today.
The battered stock market finally put together a strong, broad-based rally yesterday afternoon as the Dow Jones industrial average moved ahead almost 12 points for its best advance in six months.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest steel producer, reported yesterday a net loss of $477 million in the third quarter, the largest ever for a quarter for an American company.
LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 27 The bubble burst for the United States riders at the Washington International horse show tonight at the Capital Centre.
A 40-year-old Bronx man shot and killed his wife in a crowded midtown variety store yesterday and seconds later killed himself, the police reported.

SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, Oct. 27 (AP) Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser announced today that national elections would be held Dec. 10, more than a year before they were due, and called on Australians to re-elect his conservative Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Arthur F. Burns, implicitly rebuking the Carter Administration, today defended the Federal Reserve Board's policy of encouraging higher interest rates as a means of checking "what would otherwise have been an explosion of the money supply."
Defense Secretary Harold Brown, declaring that the United States faced a "potential energy disaster," said yesterday that lagging fuel supplies posed the single largest threat to national security.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) The International Women's Year Commission today published 26 proposals, including support for the equal rights amendment, abortion and lesbian rights, to be debated at a national meeting of women next month.
The writer of the following dispatch covered the Vietnam War for The Daily Mail of London from 1968 to 1973. He returned to Vietnam last month with a West German tourist group.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Ibsen's "An Enemy of the People" is set in a towm known for its mineral baths. Dr. Stockmann discovers that the baths are polluted. When he advises town leaders, he finds that the truth is not welcome.

The overall softness of oil company profits in the third quarter was confirmed yesterday with the Mobil Corporation, the nation's third-largest oil producer, reporting a 5.1 percent decrease, to $239 million, or $2.26 a share.
KUWAIT, Oct. 26 (AP) Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal says he has "learned not to clear my throat" lest it affect the dollar.
"People think they're kinetic sculpture," said Dean Kamen. "But I don't really consider them art, I just like making machines."

Operators of the supersonic Concorde airliner said yesterday that a New York City official was correct in stating that the plane had emitted excessive noise climbing over the Rockaway peninsula after its takeoff from Kennedy International Airport last Friday.

NORTH PALM BEACH, Fla. Those who seek a "wilderness experience" by rushing off to Yellowstone National Park or the Great Smoky Mountains often find they have quite an experience, but with very little wilderness involved. They are more likely to find milling throngs, shuttle buses, and trails with belt-to-belt traffic.

A bank robber who took two hostages while trying to make a getaway was fatally shot yesterday and a policeman and three civilians were wounded in a fusillade of bullets on a busy street near Gramercy Park.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The Senate delayed today a key test vote on the tax aspects of the energy program to give Republican members time to try to arrive at a common position.

After finally winning the cooperation of a reluctant neighborhood, Brooklyn homicide detectives arrested Joseph D'Amico yesterday evening and charged him with the murder of his neighbor, Angelo Treglia, on a crowded Bensonhurst street over the weekend.

JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 26 South African officials decided today to open an inquest on Friday into the death of Stephen Biko, the country's foremost young black leader, who died in police custody six weeks ago. An autopsy has already found that the cause of death was extensive brain injuries.
Dr. Clifton R. Wharton Jr., the president of Michigan State University, was named yesterday to be the next chancellor of the 345,000-student State University of New York, the largest in the country.

PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 26 Though the Nets still have not won a game with New Jersey in front of their name, they came as close as it is possible to come tonight before falling to the Atlanta Hawks, 113-110, in overtime.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest steel producer, reported yesterday a net loss of $477 million in the third quarter, the largest ever for a quarter for an American company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The House of Representatives killed a provision in the pending Social Security financing bill tonight that would have made Social Security coverage mandatory in 1982 for all Federal civilian employees and for those state and local government employees who do not participate voluntarily.

AFTER A RESTORATION project that called for detective work, serendipity, extraordinary craftsmanship and meticulous attention to detail, the all-but-hidden Manhattan brownstone on the site where the 26th President was born 119 years ago today is back in business.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration took a first step today toward requiring manufacturers to include warning brochures with some tranquilizers.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday affirmed a lower court ruling that Governor Carey's proposal to issue $750 million in bonds to stimulate the state's economy was unconstitutionally broad and should not be on the ballot next month.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 26 The price of imported meat has climbed by 12 cents to 39 cents a pound while supermarket and grocery store shelves normally filled with canned goods are bare as a result of the 26-day longshoremen's strike that has crippled cargo shipments from Maine to Texas.
Marie-Louise Yorck, the former Countess Yorck Von Wartenburg, of Germany, died Tuesday at her home, 118 Huntington Road, Port Washington, L.I. She was 64 years old.

Clarke Warren Costikyan, president of Kent-Costikyan Inc., an oriental rug company at 305 East 63d Street, collapsed and died Tuesday as he was leaving his office. He was 75 years old and lived at 167 Highland Avenue, Montclair, N.J.
Marie M. Lambert, the Democratic candidate for Manhattan Surrogate, has been accused of unethical conduct and has been rated "not approved" by the executive committee of the City Bar Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) The House Republican whip, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, today called on Margaret Costanza, a presidential aide, to resign, charging she violated Federal election law by failing until recently to report campaign money raised early this year.
WAYNE TOWNSHIP, Oct. 26 Former Gov. William T. Cahill said today that State Senator Raymond H. Bateman "will be the best Governor New Jersey will ever have had."

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday affirmed a lower court ruling that Governor Carey's proposal to issue $750 million in bonds to stimulate the state's economy was unconstitutionally broad and should not be on the ballot next month.

NEXT TO HIGH prices, one of the things that frustrates consumers most is their conviction that warranties on such big ticket items as automobiles and home appliances aren't worth the paper they are written on.

THERE ARE ominous signs in the suburbs that the city may be due for another severe winter. Flocks of our winter birds are already on the wing. Evening grosbeaks and red polls have moved down from the north well ahead of schedule.

THE FABRIC world may not be the same after Les Levine, the Canadian conceptual artist who lives in New York, completes his one-year stint starting this week as one of the three artists-in-residence at the Philadelphia College of Textiles and Science.

Once again the nation's furniture manufacturers have looked to the past, producing a diverse harvest of historically based or nostalgic designs at the Southern Furniture Market, which ends here Friday. The backward looks range from period Oriental to 18th-century American to Edwardian to Art Deco, from reproductions to "in-the-style-of" adaptations.

If designers of furniture tend to look backward for inspiration, their colleagues in lighting are moving full speed ahead with 20th-century design ideas. Atleast those supplying George Kovacs Lighting this season are. A roll-about spotlight on casters, with a shade in white, brown, red or yellow, should make lighting in the living room as functional as it is in a photographer's studio. The light, "Butler," by Louis Poulsen of Denmark, will be $150.

The world of Phyllis Schlafly is peopled with homosexual bogeymen, underspanked children, copulating teen-agers, and housewives who earn love at the feet of their slightly simian husbands, these last being just a lawnmower or two away from the jungle. Pressing at the doors of this shaky stable is a phalanx of "Typhoid Marys" threatening to annihilate the tot with the germ of women's lib.

HARTFORD A VISION of the kind of city Hartford could be coupled with the confidence that they could build that city inspired Hartford's voters in 1970 to approve funds for the construction of a civic center in the heart of the decaying downtown area.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 Philadelphians proper and in some cases not so proper are taking in stride the ups and downs of autumn life in the nation's fourth largest city. At different, sometimes overlapping, social strata, Philadelphians and their suburban neighbors are doing what they can about some things and talking about the rest.

Sharon Kay Roman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Siegbert Roman of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Stephen Golden, son of Civil Court Judge Elliott Golden and Mrs. Golden of Brooklyn. Rabbi Gitbert Klaperman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I.

A. Louis Oresman, for more than 50 years senior partner of Aronson Oresman, certified public accountants, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a heart attack. He was 82 years old and lived at 115 Central Park West. He maintained a summer home in Shrewsbury, Vt.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis Lyman Hine of Bridgeton, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Priscilla Jordan Hine, to Charles Homer DeLong of Kansas City, Mo., son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen R. DeLong of Greenwich, N.J. A December wedding is planned.

The closing date for the $15 million sale of the Boston Red Sox to a group headed by Haywood Sullivan and Buddy LeRoux has been postponed from tomorrow until Friday and the hank officer who agreed to lend the group $8 million is no longer with the State Street Bank and Trust of Boston. Asked

Dr. and Mrs. John Crapo Bullard of South Dartmouth, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Bullard, to Martin Clark Madden, son of Dr. and Mrs. Carl Halford Madden of Alexandria, Va.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I. "You know it's myth that there are an abundance of centers and organizations out here in Nassau County that give women the opportunity to communicate about their particular problems and needs as suburban women," Judith Ungar was saying during a break in a day-long session of workshops on independence sponsored by the Women's Resource Center of Long Island, of which she is co-founder.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua After 41 years of absolute rule, the Somoza family is losing its grip on Nicaragua. Leftist guerrillas have won the backing of non-Marxist groups and have started an open struggle to topple the regime. A power struggle has erupted within the ruling elite. President Anastasio Somoza Debaye is recovering from a recent heart attack and the Somozas are no longer assured of the automatic backing in Washington.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 The American Bar Association, in the first of four national seminars for lawyers, has taken up how to deal with issues such as whether governments can and should regulate obscenity; what exactly is obscenity and how to combat pornography without eroding the First Amendment protection of free speech and expression.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 29 It remained something of a mystery today just why Navy persists in playing Notre Dame in football every year. Little changed in this nation's longest continuous intersectional rivalry as Notre Dame eased to a 43-10 victory over the Midshipmen before 59,075 persons who filled Notre Dame Stadium.

SOME women feel obliged to do their own housework. However else they may spend their time working outside the home from 9 to 5 or raising a bunch of children they feel guilty if they don't keep their homes sparkling clean themselves. This anxiety is probably the result of years of television commercials featuring women smiling proudly at gleaming kitchen floors.

OXFORD, England Cecil Rhodes, the empire builder, said in his will that those chosen for the scholarships that he was underwriting should exhibit, in addition to an outstanding capacity for scholarship and leadership, the "qualities of manhood."

MAMARONECK It WAS good to attend the opening of the third season of the Westchester-Rockland Regional Theater with a packed house. Word from out in the lobby of the Emelin Theater here was that subscriptions have doubled this year from about 500 to more than 1,000 for the four-play season. Westchestes theatergoers are to be congratulated.

TEANECK THE dilemma for Richard Schiffman is not that the New York Giants have won their last two games. The dilemma is trying to believe that something good is about to happen after years of frustration and famine.

SINGAPORE, Oct.33 (AP) Four armed hijackers took control of a Vietnamese airliner on a domestic flight today, killed two Vietnamese crewmen aboard the plane and forced it to land in Singapore, where they surrendered to the authorities, Government officials said.
Football, tennis and boxing will be the focus this week of the most extensive Congressional inquiry into the relationship between television and sports.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 29 (AP) Leonard Thompson broke out of a three-way tie with a solid, six-underpar 65, established a two-stroke lead today and confidently looked ahead to a victory in the $125,000 Pensacola open golf tournament.

North Edison (5-0-1) cruised to a 28-0 victory over Edison as Greg Chapkowski established a school record by booting three field goals. Chapkowski connected from 27, 25 and 33 yards in addition to kicking one conversion placement. Chapkowski has converted 18 of 22 extra-point attempts this season.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29 When Maiava Iulai Toma says that he is not only Samoa's chief delegate to the United Nations, Ambassador to the United States and High Commissioner to Canada but also a tourism promoter, trade negotiator, chauffeur, mail clerk and part-time telephone operator, he says it with a smile. He is not exaggerating.

A 24-year-old civilian employee of the Police Department was arrested last night and charged with picking a wallet from the hip pocket of a decoy police officer on a sidewalk in Jamaica, Queens.
Jim Watson, a senior tailback for East Islip, scored five touchdowns and rushed for 214 yards yesterday to lead the Redmen past Commack North, 54-0, and raise their won-lost record to 5-1.

Morton P. Hyman, the newly appointed vice chairman of the State Health Planning Commission, said last week that he hoped to spur the development of neighborhood health centers in the city.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 29 Nearly a year after the Lebanese civil war ended in a truce, a new wave of insecurity has spread through the country. There are daily reports of violence among the factions that took part in the 19-month civil war. Some are unconfirmed, but the number of known cases of what appear to be acts of vengeance is growing.
LANDOVFR, Md., Oct. 29 After trying without success for almost a week, Canada and West Germany each won an open international class tonight at the Washington International Horse Show.

MANDASOR, India Landowners in Madhya Pradesh in central India who have lagged behind their compatriots in such agriculturally progressive states as Punjab and Tamil Nadu are adopting new methods based on the use of hybrid seeds, fertilizers and lift irrigation with impressive results. As in other places, the initiative has come from affluent farmers.

THE dispute over whether the State Commission of Investigation has allowed itself to be used for political purposes con tinues to simmer. The final verdict is not in, but the preliminary answer seems to be: May be or probably.

THE Sea Crest Clam Bar, one of those storefront restaurants with wonderful word-ofmouth reputations, has always been highly thought of, always crowded. Recently, it received statewide recognition as one of New Jersey's best seafood restaurants.

GEORGIA O'KEEFFE, by Georgia O'Keeffe, (Penguin, $14.95.) The images of houses, barns, flowers, bones, crosses and New Mexican mesas and mountains that made Georgia O'Keeffe one of the most esteemed of living American artists are beautifully reproduced in this album of 108 paintings. She provides the commentary, a series of brilliant yet impersonal glimpses into the working of an independent imagination.

PURCHASE N.Y. THE outstanding exhibition of the early works of Franz Kline at the State University of New York's Neuberger Museum should be a neat and direct lesson. CHERRY HILL UNIFORMED guards still man the gates leading to Garden State Race Track, but the crowds of yesteryear are but a glimmer in the eyes of bartenders along Route 70. Trenton and only Trenton can return to the track the glory of great races and big purses.

ALBANY, Oct. 29 (AP) Potentially dangerous human-subject experiments were conducted at the State University of New York at Albany without proper supervision and prior approval, university officials admitted this week in a negotiated settlement with the State Health Department.

WESTBROOK SIX years ago Edward Norton was a plumber. Mr. Norton has built a reputation as one of the finest miniature-furniture craftsmen in the country.

WILLIAM SLOANE COFFIN was young, at least for that kind of job, when he was appointed University Chaplain at Yale at age 33. He remained as Yale's chaplain for 17 years. To undergraduates, he was one of the most powerful presences, even forces, on the campus charismatic, mobilizing, with a style of speaking, a combination of the upper-class and the streetwise, that was engaging and demanding but also lent itself to a rather humorous mimicry.

Kinney, president of Mattatuck Community College, the beginning of the realization of "a dream that many of us have had for the last 10 years. JOHANESBURG Mymoena Salie, a bathing beauty from Cape Town, recently became the first black woman to win a multiracial beauty contest in South Africa. Miss Salie found herself unable to accept her prize a two-week seaside vacation because the hotel did not admit blacks.

THE CITY Buenos Aires (known as B.A. for short) is the Big Apple South. Everything creative and destructive of which the Argentine people have been capable in the brief, turbulent life of the nation is concentrated here. As an urban achievement, the Argentine capital is impressive.

AMERICUS, Ga., Oct. 29 Pat Medlock is a taciturn man. He especially dislikes talking about his troubles. And he seems somehow embarrassed by his failure to produce his normal good crop this year and even more embarrassed by the need to go calling on the Government for help.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 On the evening of Aug. 9, 1975, a United States Air Force transport carrying 11 Congressmen and 10 of their wives touched down at Kimpo Airport in Seoul. As the plane taxied to a stop, a flock of Korean National Assemblymen, senior officials of the Foreign Ministry and other leaders surged to the red carpet at planeside to bid the Americans welcome.

The Barbizon Hotel for Women, an aging dowager that has just had a major face lift, celebrated her 50th birthday yesterday with a cake, a fashion show and tales of some of her more glorious past residents.

OLIVET, Oct. 28 After more than a quarter of a century, J.D. Salinger's novel, "Catcher in the Rye," is still stirring controversy. For all practical purposes, this week marks the end of the corn harvest and the start of the annual battle of money and wits in the futures market for America's most important crop.

Augustus B. Weller, who played a key role in the development of Hofstra University and the National Bank of North America, died Thursday night at South Nassau Community Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. He was 83 years old and lived in Massapequa.

Less than two years after he was widely praised for staving off the bankruptcy of New York City and a possible fiscal collapse of the state, Governor Carey has been the target of such heavy criticism even within his own party that the possibility of a primary challenge of his renomination once unthinkable and still unlikely is being raised by some Democrats.

Armed with the knowledge that wealthy free agents helped the Yankees win the championship and helped major league baseball set an attendance record, the owners of the 26 clubs are checking their checkbooks this week to find out how many millions of dollars they have for spending on the second class of free agents.

Lazar Berman, who has apparently become an idol of New York audiences, attracted a full house for his Carnegie Hall recital yesterday afternoon. THE 17-YEAR history of oral contraceptives has been marred by an intermittent stream of unsettling reports describing newly discovered health hazards associated with the pill. For the 10 million American women taking the pill, and for their families and friends, these reports have created mounting concern about the safety and wisdom of using these synthetic hormones to prevent pregnancy.

Masterpiece Theater, public television's acclaimed showcase for British imports, begins a 13-episode series that once again set new standards for superb quality in popular entertainment. Dr. Salo Rosenbaum, a psychoanalyst, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital of a heart attack. He was 57 years old and lived at 50 East 72d Street in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) Eugene T. Barwick, former board chairman of E.T. Barwick Industries Inc. of Atlanta, pleaded guilty today to a one-count charge of making a false statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Justice Department said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 Scientists in California have successfully grown in bacteria a substance that is normally produced in animal and human brains and is believed to have important potential for treating diabetes and other serious disorders.

MOST OF the time, Mark Traynor works behind the scenes, making pretty models look even prettier for photography. He teaches courses for professional makeup artists. And he also does "realies" the magazine word for real people, as opposed to professional models. The expression amuses him.

URBANA, Ill., Nov. 2 Scientists studying the evolution of primitive organisms reported today the existence of a separate form of life that is hard to find in nature. They described it as a "third kingdom" of living material, composed of ancestral cells that abhor oxygen, digest carbon dioxide and produce methane.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 2 The Islanders don't get no respect.

Fraser, chairman of a House subcommittee engaged in the investigation of alleged Korean influence buying, tried today to remove suspicion that Representative Edward J. Derwinski, the senior Republican on the subcommittee, had disclosed information endangering a South Korean intelligence officer who was defecting to the United States.

Today will be a busy day for Jacob Druckman. The 49-year-old Pulitzer Prize-winning composer will attend this afternoon's concert in Avery Fisher Hall by the New York Philharmonic, because it is playing one of his works. SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 3--The South Korean Government has agreed to let American officials question Tongsun Park in the United States Embassy here, according to sources close to negotiations between the two Governments over the Park case.

CATANIA, Sicily, Nov. 3 (AP)--Mount Etna erupted today and sent a stream of lava nearly a mile down the north side toward the city of Randazzo, 12 miles away. Experts said the volcano, which erupted several times last summer, was not threatening any populated or cultivated areas.

Western jazz, rock and classical musicians and composers began turning to the East for both musical inspiration and spiritual sustenance during the 1960's. The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants proposed yesterday that the section of the auditor's report on financial statements that calls attention to potential losses be replaced by a more comprehensive system of disclosure.

A State Supreme Court jury in Manhattan last night found Justice Andrew R. Tyler guilty of first-degree perjury arising from his testimony before a grand jury about his relationship with a racketeer. The crime is a felony punishable by up to seven years in prison.

Mississippi's two United States Senators, James O. Eastland and John C. Stennis, will have served together in Congress for 30 years and a day as of tomorrow. New Yorkers who have never sailed forth on a professionally geared trek with a guide-narrator would do well to start with this Sunday-afternoon safari along the former "Ladies Shopping Mile," the city's Fashion Row from the 1870's until World War I.

Without any public announcement, Alcoa, the nation's largest producer of aluminum, rolled back a price increase of 3 cents a pound on its common alloy sheet and plate product to its distributors. Alcoa confirmed yesterday that it had taken the step for competitive reasons. Last Oct. 7, Alcoa put through the price increase on sheet and plate, which represents about one-third of total shipments of the company.
PARIS, Nov. 4 France made a further show of solidarity with Quebec today by agreeing to annual meetings between leaders of France and Canadian province.

Soybean prices rallied yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. A buying spree occurred in both soybeans and soybean oil futures influenced by a Government report, available before the opening of trading, that showed a sharp reduction in soybean oil stocks in September.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4, (Reuters) A Senate subcommittee today approved a bill that would allow consumers, small businesses, states, the Federal Government and others to recover damages against antitrust violators, even without direct dealings with these companies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 Representative Thomas L. Ashley, chairman of the House Ad Hoc Energy Committee, said today that unless Senate conferees agreed to rebate to consumers some of the receipts from the proposed oil equalization tax, no conference report could be passed in the House.

Governor Carey ordered tightened security measures at the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens yesterday in an effort to limit the activities of criminally insane patients who had been regularly walking in and out of the hospital without authorization or supervision.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 Unemployment across the nation rose, by a tenth of a percentage point, to 7 percent of the work force in October, keeping the jobless rate essentially the same for six months.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 4 (UPI) Shareholders of Corco the financially troubled petrochemical company on Puerto Rico's south coast, were told today that the acquisition of the company by the Ashland Oil Company might yet fall through and that Corco might still seek protection under the bankruptcy laws.

Botha said today the United Nations-decreed arms embargo against South Africa was an incitement to violence and would stiffen the resolve of South Africans to defend their country. STRATFORD WITH the American Shakespeare Theater faltering as a tourist attraction after two decades of success here, municipal and civic leaders have begun a drive to attract more visitors the year round.

WASHINGTON--Secretary of State Cyrus Vance, who runs one of the tidiest and hardest-working shops in this somewhat disorganized city, is at present engaged in two projects of what might be called rectification of the practice or methodology of United States policy, not its change in terms of national aims or aspirations.

LEAVES are on just about everyone's minds now. They cover the ground, cling to the trees, blow across the neighbor's lawn to yours and make a nuisance of themselves. A good wind storm will often make things progress rapidly--usually just after the lawns have had a good clean sweep.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--A bill to restrain rising hospital costs, described by President Carter as "one of my most important priorities," is dead for this session of Congress. Administration and Congressional forces will try to agree on a compromise early next year, but their experience so far has indicated difficulties for the legislation.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 5 (AP)-- Ohio State, held to one touchdown in the first half, erupted for three in the third quarter, including two within 13 seconds, and rolled to a 35-0 victory over Illinois today, remaining undefeated in the Big Ten conference.

LONDON--The Bank of England will bring out a new one-pound note next year. It will be considerably smaller than the current version--reflecting, some suggest, Britain's shrunken place in world finance--and it carries a picture of Isaac Newton, father of things that fall.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 5--While the Ethiopian Government has been fighting wars with separatist movements in Eritrea and Ogaden, chaotic violence and assassinations have increased in Addis Ababa, where two Government officials and a policeman were shot to death in broad daylight on Wednesday.

ALBANY THE Long Island potato crop is down 16 percent this year, according to the latest figures from the New York Crop Re porting Service here. When the harvest is complete, Suffolk County farmers will have picked 621 million pounds of potatoes, compared with 741 million pounds last year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. HAVING enjoyed the opening program by the Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester (about which I wrote in last week's column), I was especially eager to hear the county's other major avocational ensemble, the Westchester Symphony Orchestra.

Sachem clinched the AAA-1 championship yesterday, scoring an impressive 27-0 victory over Half Hollow Hills. The Flaming Arrows will meet the winner of next week's West IslipPatchogue game for the AAA championship.

IN the opening line of "Shadow Box," George Plimton gambles. "I never understood boxing," he writes, thus attempting to set up the reader for a sucker punch. The gambit is audacious, since boxing is the one sport that can bring out the prophet in a Quaker. Call it a literary right-hand lead.

Brad Jaworski, Hicksville's coach, was unconcerned last Friday night about the semifinal game on Tuesday against Roslyn, the team that eliminated Hicksville from the soccer playoffs last year.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 5--Kevin Huff Huff became the first runner in Hofstra's history to crack the 1,000-yard barrier running as he led the Dutchmen to a 27-7 victory over Wagner College today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 5--After years of severe financial problems incurred largely through overcommitments to the third world, the United Nations Development Program has made a dramatic fiscal recovery through management reforms and an aggressive fundraising campaign.

A DEATH IN CANAAN, by Joan Barthel. (Dell, $1.95.) In 1973, young Peter Reilly of Canaan, Conn. returns home to find his mother brutally murdered. Under great police pressure he confesses and is convicted of manslaughter. A defense committee wins him a new trial. This account of the case, written by a committee member, impressed our reviewer, C.D. B. Bryan, for its meticulous research, though he found its tone rather cold-blooded.

Shakti seemed to be an experimental gambit in 1975, when John McLaughlin, the guitarist, and three Indian musicians formed the group. Its approach to music was basically Eastern, with Mr. McLaughlin choosing to use Indian materials rather than to draw the other players into his own musical orbit.

The four major candidates for Mayor of New York City made the best of a dreary Sunday in their campaign for an election tomorrow that will highlight races throughout the state.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) The Soviet Union is prepared to seek an agreement with the United States drastically limiting the arms flow to the Middle East after a peace settlement is reached, according to Soviet Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin.

Charlotte Horowitz will sit before the United States Supreme Court this morning for the final stage of her fouryear-old legal battle against the medical school where she had a top academic record but was expelled on the verge of graduation.

WASHINGTON Election reformers, worried about the great power they were putting in the hands of a Federal Election Commission, thought they made certain of bipartisanship by requiring the commission to be made up of three Democrats and three Republicans.

VIRGINIA, Minn., Nov. 6-The deer season opened here yesterday, giving residents of this iron-range mining town of 12,450 something to talk about besides the miners' strike that has devasted some businesses, caused heavy losses to others and put hundreds of other workers out of jobs.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6 Black Rhodesian students enrolled at Carnegie-Mellon University have contended that they are being trained as political administrators for government positions when the black majority takes over in their country.

OYSTER BAY COVE, L.I, Nov. 6 Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, the dissident French prelate, today dedicated the new American headquarters of his Society of St. Pius X, promising 600 supporters he would follow "traditional" Roman Catholicism even though he has been suspended from his priestly duties by Pope Paul VI.

A quarterback from a school in Utah throwing against the University of Utah football team is a combination that has led to a major National Collegiate passing record twice in five years. A new economic study of the societal costs of unemployment concludes that if during the latest two decades, the United States had kept the unemployment rate at about 4 percent, instead of at an average of more than 5 percent, Americans would have enjoyed 17 percent more goods and services last year than they actually had.

Dr. Joseph S. Gould, an economist who served as consultant in many posts in the Far East, died Thursday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. At issue are the disability payments he and hundreds of other retired veterans have been awarded by the Veterans Administration.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., Nov. 6 More than 50 persons prominent in the performing arts directors, writers, trustees, government administrators and performers endorsed an "elitist" concept of the arts at the conclusion of the 53d American Assembly here today. Judge Barrington Parker strengthened that hope when he said Mr. Helms stood before the court "in disgrace."

Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch said yesterday that his immediate concerns in preparing to govern New York City would be labor negotiations, Federal loans and the assembling of a staff. Work on the last task got under way when Edward N. Costikyan agreed to become First Deputy Mayor.

As the dirty flood waters receded in the city and suburbs yesterday, homeowners and municipal officials began to clean up damages whose costs will run into many millions of dollars.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (Reuters) The Pentagon announced today a ninemonth test starting Jan. 1 to see if cash bonuses will ease manpower shortages in the Army Reserve forces.

The accounting profession's reaction to a Senate report recommending that the profession generally police itself is one of relief that no new legislation is being proposed.

The Singer Company disclosed yesterday the retirement of one official and the resignation of another after an internal investigation of exchanges of price information since 1973 with competitors of its American Meter division, with headquarters in Philadelphia.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Nov. 14 (AP) Evel Knievel, the motorcycle daredevil, was sentenced today to six months in the county jail for beating his former press agent with a baseball bat.

The fibula is the long, thin outerbone of the human leg between the knee and the ankle, attached at the ankle. Fractures of the fibula down near the ankle, which seldom are serious, happen with some frequency to skiers. But last Sunday they happened to three quarterbacks and that was serious.

ASSE, West Germany, Nov. 12 Twenty-two years after West Germany first gained access to atomic power, the Government is involved in acrimonious debate with industry and environmental groups over the future of nuclear energy in this densely populated industrial country.
It is impossible to describe the effect of Boris Belkin's violin recital Sunday night at the 92d St. Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. without saying a word about his appearance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt said today that he was prepared to address the Israeli Parliament within the next week once he had received a formal invitation from Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) The Central Intelligence Agency no longer uses secret organizations as fronts for financing human behavior research, its Director, Adm. Stansfield Turner, said today.
The appointment of Conrad C. Fink as executive vice president for administration of Park Broadcasting Inc. and Park Newspapers Inc. of Ithaca, N.Y., was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov 14 The Supreme Court ruled today that pipeline subsidiaries of seven major oil companies may continue to charge about $1.5 million a day more for use of the Alaska pipeline than the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended last June.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 With the warning that long-range weather forecasts are right only six out of 10 times, the National Weather Service predicted today that the early winter months in the Northeast and Central Mississippi Valley states would be colder than normal.
SEATTLE, Nov. 14 (AP) Negotiators reached a tentative agreement today on a contract that could end the six-week strike by 24,000 machinists and aerospace workers against the Boeing Company.
EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 14 (AP) John Pont, whose Northwestern team hasn't won this season announced his resignation today as head football coach. He will remain as the school's athletic director.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. charged today that the arrangement under which Richard Helms avoided a criminal trial could set a precedent for making intelligence officials immune to accountability before the courts or Congress.
David Murray, a former political writer in New York and Washington, is expected to be named Governor Carey's press secretary within a week.
Eleven years ago this month, a handful of women met in Betty Friedan's ruby and sapphire Victorian parlor on the West Side and announced they were seeking "true equality for all women in America."
TOCCOA, Ga., Nov. 14 (A.P.) The Toccoa Falls Bible College is to reopen tomorrow, nine days after a flood killed 38 persons in a low-lying area of the campus.

William R. Barrett, assistant managing editor for United Press International, collapsed and died yesterday at the Port Authority bus terminal in Manhattan. He was 55 years old and lived in Rutherford, N.J.

WILLINGBORO A bitter strike of 850 teachers and the jailing of striking teachers in Matawan last month have lent new urgency to efforts to find a better way to solve school labor problems, in New Jersey.

Federal agents raided a rented house in Tottenville, S.I, yesterday, subdued "two vicious German shepherd guard dogs," and arrested a 27-year-old pharmacist who they said was using the house to turn out millions of capsules of quaalude, a depressant.

TUNIS, Nov. 14 The foreign ministers of the Arab League condemned the recent Israeli air raids into southern Lebanon today and called on the "great powers" to take "all necessary measures" to halt what they called Israel's "aggressive acts."

The capital market, speaking through Moody's Investors Service, is telling anyone who will listen including, we trust, the Federal Government that New York City cannot be saved from ultimate bankruptcy by the bond-buying public, It requires a major policy decision in Washington.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 14 (AP)-The Louisiana Supreme Court refused today to consider a challenge of the New Orleans mayoral race, letting stand the election of Ernest N. Morial, the city's first black Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 In a sign of how seriously the United States Government has come to view the problem of international terrorism, the Pentagon recently simulated a hypothetical situation dealing with the theft of an American nuclear weapon by terrorists.

The quintet that Chico Freeman is leading at Sweet Basil on Sunday and Monday nights this month is a splendid indicator of the way youth and age are reinforcing each other in New York's new jazz. Mr. Freeman is in his early 20's, but his father, Von Freeman, is one of the most respected tenor saxophonists in Chicago and has taught his son, also a saxophonist, a great deal.

William G. Zehnder, president of the Cologne Reinsurance Company of America, Stamford, Conn., died Saturday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital after a lengthy illness. He was 55 years old and lived at Carriglea Drive, Riverside, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The Securities and Exchange Commission has failed to develop a national market system in securities trading and has exacerbated the potential for monopoly in securities clearing and settlement, a report issued by two House Commerce subcommittees concluded today.

PRINCETON, Ind. On the surface, the themes are heartwarming and inspiring. A young executive takes command of an aging small refinery that has been more or less shut down for eight years and, after a year of hard work, seems to be making a go of it.

Saudi Arabia and Iran, the two biggest exporters among members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, both appear to have decided to support an oil price freeze at an OPEC meeting that starts Dec. 20 in Caracas, Venezuela.
JACKSON, Tenn., Nov. 14 (AP) Charles B. Jones Sr., son of Casey Jones, the legendary railroad man, died at his home here Saturday. He was 89 years old.

TRENTON, Nov. 14 Bill Bradley, the 34-year-old former New York Knicks basketball player, formally opened a bid today for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate seat held by Clifford P. Case, Republican of Rahway, whose term expires next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-President Carter endorsed today a compromise full employment bill that would set, as a national goal, a reduction of the overall unemployment rate from the present 7 percent to 4 percent in 1983.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-Sounding a strong evangelical note that reflected a major new emphasis in Roman Catholicism, Archbishop Joseph L. Bernardin of Cincinnati urged the National Conference of Catholic Bishops today to seek vigorously the "true conversion" of millions of lapsed Catholics who have been "falling away from the faith."

NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 14 Official Ethiopian sources confirmed today that Lieut. Col. Atnafu Abate, nominally the second-ranking figure in the country's ruling military council, was subjected yesterday to "a revolutionary measure," a euphemism that in the past has meant execution.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 14 The Indian Government announced today that the four Indian news agencies that had been forced to merge during the emergency rule of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi would be reconstituted as independent units.

IRVING, Tex., Nov. 14 (AP) Jim Hart rallied St. Louis with a pair of fourth-quarter touchdown passes and the Cardinals knocked off the last of the National Football League's unbeaten teams with a wild and bitterly fought 24-17 victory over the Dallas Cowboys tonight.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 14 The Giants promised today to play offense for the rest of the season.

A Federal court decision that a news organization cannot be forced to disclose how it makes its editing decisions is being viewed by media lawyers as a major step in the extension of First Amendment protections.

It has been said that it takes at least 20 years to develop a major classic ballet company of international stature. It has taken Robert Joffrey 21, although, in fairness, his company did have about a year out in the middle, after a contretemps over his financial backing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Organized labor and the liberal wing of the Democratic Party, old comrades-in-arms that have been estranged for nearly a decade, are finding themselves fighting shoulderto-shoulder these days in a growing num ber of legislative battles.
A suspect was arrested yesterday in the murder of Harry Kassoff, a 68-yearold retired businessman who was stubbed to death Saturday in his apartment in the Sovereign, at 425 East 58th Street.

The bricklayers union in New York City, most of whose 4,000 members are unemployed as a result of the sagging construction industry, has agreed to a 14 percent wage cut in a three-year contract with major mason contractors.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The Air Force, breaking with the policy of the other armed services, plans to allow women enrolled in the Air Force Academy to remain in the school if they become pregnant.

MADRID, Nov. 14 The Spanish Communist leader, Santiago Carrillo, left today for an 11-day visit to the United States where he is expected to enhance his image as a democratic-minded Communist independent of Moscow. Following him tomorrow on a competing American pilgrimage will be Felipe Gonz lez, first secretary of the important Spanish Socialist Workers Party.

TRENTON Nov. 14 Flood damage in northern New Jersey last week totaled more than $94 million, state officials said today, and the Governor's office asked President Carter to declare four counties a major disaster area.

The dollar fell to a record low against the Swiss franc in foreign exchange trading yesterday and declined against most other currencies abroad before rebounding somewhat in late New York trading, The Associated Press reported.

RIVER GROVE, Ill., Nov. 14 (AP) A fight erupted between Nazis and antiNazis tonight outside a college auditorium where a noted Jewish hunter of alleged Nazi war criminals, Simon Wiesenthal, was scheduled to speak.

In what could be a precedent-setting case, a Brooklyn contractor has challenged a back-pay order by the National Labor Relations Board on the ground, in part, that the six workers involved were illegal aliens whom it had hired without knowing their illegal status.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 14 An accounting firm has determined that the Westchester Premier Theatre contains 61 more seats than it has been showing in its records.

MANILA, Nov. 14 A fire fanned by the winds of a typhoon swept through a hotel here early today, killing at least 44 people, most of them foreign tourists, and injuring nine. More than 100 guests were safely transferred to other hotels.

The Houston Oilers' suspicions that the Oakland Raiders used a helium-filled football for kicking last Sunday turned out yesterday to have the weight of a lot of hot air. Even if the ball, spirited away from Oakland after the Oilers' loss, had contained helium instead of air, it would not have mattered.

VIENNA, Nov. 14 The Viennese police asked law enforcement agencies throughout Europe for their help today in their hunt for the kidnappers of a 73-year-old Austrian millionaire, who was released late last night after four days in captivity.

One day in early November, the shares of Nevada Power, a utility that supplies electricity for the Las Vegas area, surged 5 points to 29 7/8. WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 House and Senate energy conferees took up the issue on which they may be furtherest apart today, electricity rates, and made no progress in a day of arguing.
NEWARK, Nov. 14 (AP) New Jersey taxpayers pay more than $5.4 million annually for abuse of the Federal welfare system by aliens, the General Accounting Office says.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 President Carter endorsed today a compromise fullemployment bill that would set, as a national goal, a reduction of the overall, unemployment rate from the present 7 percent to 4 percent in 1983.

Sambo's Restaurants, California coffee shop chain W.R. Grace Company had been interested in acquiring until yesterday when it suspended discussions, reported profit increases of 16 percent for the third quarter and 10.6 percent for the first nine months of this year.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 14 (AP) Pinkie Masters, a Savannah tavern owner for nearly a quarter century and a personal friend of President Carter, died yesterday. He was 64 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 African countries demanded economic sanctions, including an oil embargo, against South Africa today as the General Assembly opened debate on the country's racial policies.

Hughes, who controlled but did not own the assets of the medical institute that carried his name, once planned to use those assets as bait in a plan to help him divest a money-losing helicopter manufacturing company, according to records filed in a Houston court today.

With the cost of raw materials and energy rising and Federal regulations threatening the chemical industry, the Union Carbide Corporation yesterday introduced a process that could revitalize the production of low-density polyethylene used to make products from trash bags to communication cables.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14 An advisory group to the Casino Control Commission that will regulate casino gambling here tentatively approved today an affirmativeaction plan that calls not only for 20 percent minority hiring in casino construction, but also for implementation of the same quota in job categories and in man-hours of working time.

WASHINGTON-President Carter has prudently declined to agree with Richard Helms, the former C.I.A. director, that Mr. Helms's conviction on two misdemeanor counts was "a badge of honor." Mr. Carter did insist that the Helms plea bargain with the Department of Justice "upheld the law" but close scrutiny of this powder-puff deal casts serious doubt even on that.
For Police Officer James Carroll on radio-car patrol in Sector Five-Oh John Charlie in the Northwest Bronx, it was an unusually quiet tour.
