Calvin Collier yesterday resigned his seat on the five-member Federal Trade Commission, effective Jan. 1. Mr. Collier, who said he resigned for personal reasons, served as chairman from March 1976 until earlier this year, when Michael Pertschuk was appointed to the post by President Carter. Mr. Collier also is a former general counsel to the F.T.C.

Roger S. Hewlett, a writer and editor first at Time magazine and then from 1958 to his retirement in 1971 a senior editor at Sports Illustrated, died yesterday in Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middleton, Conn. He was 66 years old and lived on Sill Lane in Old Lyme, Conn.

A news magazine recently discovered a Los Angeles restaurant so exclusive that it has an unlisted telephone number. If you don't know the number, we don't want you, explained somebody connected with the place.
China, normally a modest exporter of soybeans, has recently bought 591,000 bushels of the protein-rich oilseeds from the United States, the Agriculture Department reported yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 An unseasonal brush fire roared through the rugged Topanga Canyon residential area here tonight, causing hundreds of people to flee their homes.

Steel production for the week ended Nov. 12 was down 2.9 percent to 2.3 million tons, The American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry produced 2.4 million tons in the preceding week.
Longshoremen and shipping companies in ports on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts began negotiating local agreements yesterday to supplement, the new master pact reached here on Sunday.
BOSTON, Nov, 14 (AP) Owners of the Boston Red Sox lost in court today in their effort to sell the team quickly.

Mark Alexander McCloskey, an educator concerned chiefly with young people in trouble, died Sunday night in a nursing home in Northfield, Vt., at the age of 86. Until his move to Vermont, he had lived at 145 East 35th Street.

Morris A. Schapiro, president of M.A. Schapiro Company, yesterday dismissed as "self-serving" and "baseless" charges in a Federal lawsuit brought by LITCO, a bank holding company. The suit alleges that Mr. Schapiro and his firm are centrally involved in a secret plan to acquire, at a premium price of $30 a share, a controlling 30 percent interest in LITCO for three Venezuelan investors.
Col. Irene R. McMahon of the Volunteers of Amrica died Sunday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y., following an extended illness. She was 65 years old and lived at 12 Elaine Terrace, Yonkers.
Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch paid his first visit to City Hall yesterday since winning the election, and he and his transition team met for an hour with Mayor Beame and his team.
Who will be the Jets' quarterback on Sunday in Baltimore against the ferocious Colts? Wait, until Friday, to see.

The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income rose sharply over the year-ago period, while its net income for the first three quarters of 1977 declined. Last week, the New York Stock Exchange reported higher net revenues from operations for both the three-month and ninemonth periods.

Conductors and brakemen agreed yesterday to delay further any strike action against the Long Island Rail Road until after Dec. 5, as the railroad and 16 other unions announced agreement on a new contract.

City, state and private voluntary hospitals in Brooklyn have agreed to replace a fragmented and admittedly chaotic system of mental-health care with one that will make each hospital directly responsible for mental patients in its respective area.

FOOD FOR THOUGHT "Is Marriage Necessary?" is today's topic in the Lunch Learn lecture series at the Schimmel Center of Pace University, one block east of City Hall. The speaker is Dr. George Shanker, professor of sociology, wno will examine the family scene today as many husbands, wives, daughters and sons go their separate ways with an upbeat conclusion.

OTTAWA, Nov. 14 The serious problems afflicting Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Government seem to have neither affected his ebullient personality nor lessened his popularity, though his standing with the voters is less easy to assess than his highly visible personal deportment.
If you're wondering why soccer is replacing football as the all-American fame in the schoolyards of the nation, consider what happened in a high school football game in Los Angeles recently.

King Juan Carlos of Spain presided yesterday over the opening of a yearlong celebration of the thousandth anniversary of the first appearance of the Spanish language in written form. The celebration, attended by cabinet ministers, 25 Latin American ambassadors to Spain and the entire membership of the Royal Academy of the Language, took place at the monastery of San Millan de la Cogolla, in the northern province of Logrono.

Donald Gramm, that stalwart singing actor whose star has been rising steadily in the international opera skies, has for many years followed a complementary career as a recitalist. As his Town Hall appearance on Sunday night made clear, the ebullient bass-baritone must now be regarded as the premiere American male singer of art songs, an important artist at his peak.
The stock market retreated moderately yesterday following its explosive rally of last Thursday and Friday that marked its best performance of 1977.

JOSEPH SMITH'S piano recital Wednesday night did not shoot or the moon. No late Beethoven sonatas, no Liszt in B minor, no "Symphonic Etudes," no "Diabelli" --in fact, the most significant item on his program at Carnegie Hall was Schubert's Moments Musicaux." Pramoedya Ananta Toer, generally regarded as the finest contemporary writer in Indonesia, has not written a word in 12 years. His "writer's block" can be readily explained: Since his arrest in 1965 he has been denied any access to pencil, pen or paper.

LANDOVER Md., Nov. 18--For almost two weeks, Elvin Hayes of the Washington Bullets, one of the best shooting forwards in the National Basketball Association, had been in the worst scoring slump of his 10-season career. He had failed to score a field goal against the Houston Rockets, and in eight games had totaled only 103 points. Since Hayes was nearing his 32d birthday, rumors had started that he might be traded.

Roger Peckinpaugh, who spent more than a quarter of a century in major league baseball as a player, manager and front-office executive, died in Cleveland on Thursday. Mr. Peckinpaugh, who had been suffering from cancer and heart disease, was admitted to University Hospital last week with a respiratory condition. He was 86 years old.

The indictment last month of Smithtown General Hospital on Long Island and four of its staff members for allowing a medical-supply salesman to help perform hip surgery has focused attention on the interrelationship between medicine and technology.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 18--ASouth African court ruling today effectively barred the lawyer for the family of Stephen Biko from summoning the Justice Minister to testify on how he came to issue an announcement suggesting that a hunger strike instead of brain injuries caused the black leader's death.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today ordered the shutting down of a Michigan reactor for replacement of electrical connectors used in safety systems that might fail in case of an accident.
